national football team|Poland]] |nationalcaps4 = 48 |nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 2 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 17:08, 10 February 2019 (UTC) }} '''Łukasz Fabiański''' ({{IPA-pol|ˈwukaʂ faˈbʲaɲskʲi|-|Pl-Łukasz Fabiański.ogg}}; born 18 April 1985) is a Polish professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for English {{English football updater|WestHamU}} club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] and the [[Poland national football team|Poland national team]].
Having begun his career at [[Legia Warsaw]], Fabiański joined [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] for £2.1 million in 2007, and was mainly used as back-up, but played as the club won the [[2014 FA Cup Final]]. On the expiration of his contract in 2014, he joined [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea]].
A full international for Poland since 2006, Fabiański has represented his country on over 40 occasions and was included in the squads for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] and [[UEFA Euro 2008]]. He played every match for Poland at [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]] after the first group match with [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]] due to first-choice goalkeeper [[Wojciech Szczęsny]]'s injury.
==Club career== ===Early career=== Fabiański was born in [[Kostrzyn nad Odrą]].<ref name="Hugman2010-11"/> After starting his career with [[Polonia Słubice]], Fabiański joined the noted independent football academy MSP Szamotuły at age 14, where he honed his footballing skills.<ref name="times">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/arsenal/article1774760.ece |title=Poland's new goalkeeping union not keen to send in the clowns |newspaper=The Times |date=11 May 2007 |accessdate=13 May 2007 |location=London |first=Nick |last=Szczepanik}}</ref> Fabiański then was signed in the 2004–05 season by [[Lech Poznań]].{{citation needed|date=December 2018}}
===Legia Warsaw=== In the winter of 2005, Fabiański was signed by [[Legia Warsaw]], where he competed with [[Artur Boruc]] for a place in the team. After Boruc was sold to [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]], Fabiański took over as starting goalkeeper on 24 July 2005 in a match against [[Arka Gdynia]], which ended 0–0.{{citation needed|date=December 2018}} The following season, he helped Legia win the [[2005–06 Ekstraklasa]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Football: Player profiles of Arsenal's impressive Carling Cup youngsters |first=Harry |last=Leech |work=The Guardian |date=13 November 2008 |accessdate=15 December 2018 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/nov/13/arsenal-player-profiles-football-carling-cup}}</ref> He started all 30 matches of the campaign, in which he conceded 17 goals.<ref name=whu8things>{{cite web |title=Eight things you probably didn’t know about Lukasz Fabianski |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |date=20 June 2018 |accessdate=15 December 2018 |url= https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2018/june/20-june/eight-things-you-probably-didnt-know-about-lukasz-fabianski}}</ref>
In the 2005–06 and 2006–07 seasons, his performances led to him being awarded the "Football Oscar" for the best goalkeeper in the [[Ekstraklasa]].<ref name="times"/>
===Arsenal=== On 8 May 2007, Fabiański underwent medical tests in London after [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] agreed a transfer fee with Legia Warsaw worth approximately £2.1 million.<ref name="transfer">{{cite news |url=http://home.skysports.com/list.aspx?hlid=465703&CPID=8&clid=3&lid=&title=Gunners+to+pick+up+Pole |title=Gunners to pick up Pole |first=Peter |last=O'Rourke |publisher=Sky Sports |date=9 May 2007 |accessdate=10 May 2007}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The move was confirmed on 11 May 2007 by Arsenal manager [[Arsène Wenger]].<ref name="transfer2">{{cite web |url=https://www.arsenal.com/article.asp?thisNav=News&article=466047&lid=NewsHeadline&Title=TV+Online+exclusive:+Wenger+-+Fabianski+is+set+to+sign |title=Wenger: Fabianski is set to sign |author=Richard Clarke |publisher=Arsenal F.C. |date=11 May 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513023735/https://www.arsenal.com/article.asp?thisNav=News&article=466047&lid=NewsHeadline&Title=TV+Online+exclusive:+Wenger+-+Fabianski+is+set+to+sign <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate=13 May 2007}}</ref> Fabiański formally signed for Arsenal on 26 May with a long-term contract.<ref name="arsenaloffrelease">{{cite web |url=https://www.arsenal.com/article.asp?article=468626&lid=NewsHeadline&sub=Polish+goalkeeper+Lukasz+Fabianski+joins+Arsenal&sublid=NewsHeadline&Title=Polish+goalkeeper+Lukasz+Fabianski+joins+Arsenal&f=rss |title=Polish goalkeeper Lukasz Fabianski joins Arsenal |publisher=Arsenal F.C. |date=26 May 2007 |accessdate=26 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930205406/https://www.arsenal.com/article.asp?article=468626&lid=NewsHeadline&sub=Polish+goalkeeper+Lukasz+Fabianski+joins+Arsenal&sublid=NewsHeadline&Title=Polish+goalkeeper+Lukasz+Fabianski+joins+Arsenal&f=rss <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate=30 September 2007}}</ref> He made his debut for the club in a 2–0 [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 25 September 2007.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Fabiański's fond farewell to Arsenal |first=Piotr |last=Kozmiński |publisher=UEFA |date=3 June 2014 |accessdate=15 December 2018 |url= https://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/association=eng/news/newsid=2113026.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Arsenal 2-0 Newcastle |first=Saj |last=Chowdhury |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 September 2007 |accessdate=15 December 2018 |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7008002.stm}}</ref>
In Fabiański's early Arsenal career, two of his most notable appearances came in the 5–1 defeat to rivals [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in the [[2007–08 Football League Cup|2007–08 League Cup]] semi-final and the first leg of the [[2009–10 UEFA Champions League]] second round match with [[FC Porto|Porto]]. Fabiański received criticism for conceding soft goals in the Porto match as he scored an own goal and was blamed for the second goal after picking up a backpass from [[Sol Campbell]], with Porto scoring from the resulting free-kick.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} In January 2010, Arsène Wenger stated that Łukasz Fabiański could become one of the best goalkeepers in the [[Premier League]].<ref>[http://www.tribalfootball.com/arsenal-boss-wenger-fabianski-can-be-among-best-594841 Arsenal boss Wenger: Fabianski can be among the best | Premiership News] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406230204/http://www.tribalfootball.com/arsenal-boss-wenger-fabianski-can-be-among-best-594841 |date=6 April 2012 }}. tribalfootball.com (24 January 2010).</ref>
Fabiański played the last four matches for Arsenal in the [[2009–10 Arsenal F.C. season|2009–10 season]] after top-choice goalkeeper [[Manuel Almunia]] suffered a wrist injury. He was criticised for conceding soft goals in the defeats to [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] and [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], but kept clean sheets in the matches at home to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2914/champions-league/2010/02/17/1795174/porto-2-1-arsenal-lukasz-fabianski-errors-hand-portuguese |title=Porto 2–1 Arsenal: Lukasz Fabiański errors hand Portuguese side the edge |author=Niall McGlone |publisher=Goal.com |date=17 February 2010 |accessdate=5 March 2010}}</ref>
====2010–11 season==== [[File:Lukasz Fabianski Arsenal vs Birmingham 2010-11.jpg|185px|right|thumb|Fabiański playing for [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in 2010]] Fabiański started the [[2010–11 Arsenal F.C. season|2010–11 season]] as Arsenal's second-choice goalkeeper. On 21 September 2010, he made his first start of the season in a [[2010–11 Football League Cup|League Cup]] match against [[North London Derby|neighbours]] Tottenham Hotspur at [[White Hart Lane]], which Arsenal won 4–1 after extra time. Fabiański almost cost the match for Arsenal as he failed to stop [[Robbie Keane]]'s long-range effort, despite getting a hand to the shot. After the match, he revealed he was disappointed. He had a solid match in his second match of the season replacing the injured Manuel Almunia one week later in a [[2010–11 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] 3–1 away win against [[FK Partizan|Partizan]]. He saved [[Cléo]]'s second penalty of the match in the second half to deny Partizan a lifeline. He later turned [[Ivica Iliev]]'s effort around the post from point-blank range just before the final whistle. Arsène Wenger later commented that Fabiański had a "faultless" match and they finally saw the player who they usually see in training. He kept his first clean sheet in a win over Manchester City, where he made many saves in a match that ended 3–0. He was later named man of the match on an Arsenal.com poll after a brilliant display to keep Arsenal in the match.<ref>[https://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/-we-saw-the-fabianski-we-see-in-training- 'We saw the Fabianski we see in training' | News] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101001095644/https://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/-we-saw-the-fabianski-we-see-in-training- |date=1 October 2010 }}. Arsenal F.C..com (28 September 2010).</ref> After the City match, Wenger admitted he could well become the club's number one goalkeeper after impressive displays in the matches since the Partizan match.<ref>[http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2896/premier-league/2010/10/24/2181614/arsene-wenger-admits-lukasz-fabianski-could-displace-manuel Arsene Wenger admits Lukasz Fabianski could displace Manuel Almunia as Arsenal’s first-choice goalkeeper]. Goal.com.</ref>
On 7 November 2010, Fabiański was widely criticised for an error that lead to the only goal as Arsenal lost at home to Newcastle United.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ministryofglove.wordpress.com/2010/11/08/lukasz-fabianski-mistake-v-newcastle/ |title=Fabianski Mistake Hands Newcastle Surprise Win |publisher=MinistryOf Glove.com |date=8 November 2010 |accessdate=9 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/08112010/58/premier-league-toon-shock-arsenal.html |title=Toon Shock Arsenal |website=Eurosport |date=7 November 2010 |accessdate=23 October 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814172159/http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/08112010/58/premier-league-toon-shock-arsenal.html |archivedate=14 August 2011}}(archived)</ref> However, he produced a strong display to keep a clean sheet in the next Premier League match, against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], in which he managed to prevent a draw with a last-minute save, and then initiating a counter-attack with a long throw of the ball that led to another Arsenal goal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0,19764,11065_3293518,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Chamakh brace sinks Wolves |date=10 November 2010}}</ref> After the Wolves match, Arsenal played [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], where Fabiański received the man of the match award from [[Sky Sports]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/221169/report |title=Everton v Arsenal match report |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
Fabiański was injured for Arsenal's crucial match with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] but returned for the equally important match with London rivals [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], making many crucial saves in helping Arsenal to win 3–1.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9309539.stm |title=Arsenal 3–1 Chelsea |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 December 2010 |accessdate=27 December 2010 |first=Phil |last=McNulty}}</ref> On 5 January 2011, he suffered a season-ending shoulder injury as he was warming up with the help of [[Wojciech Szczęsny]], which ruled him out for the remainder of the 2010–11 season.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/874906/op-to-sideline-lukas-fabianski-for-season?cc=5901 |title=Op to sideline Fabianski for season |website=ESPN Soccernet |date=3 January 2011 |accessdate=4 January 2011}}</ref> During this period, Szczęsny established himself as Arsenal's first choice goalkeeper ahead of his Polish compatriot.{{citation needed|date=December 2018}}
====2011–12 season==== [[File:Lukasz Fabianski 3.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Fabiański warming up before a match against [[Chelsea F.C|Chelsea]] on 21 April 2012]]
Fabiański spent the [[2011–12 Arsenal F.C. season|2011–12 season]] as backup to Wojciech Szczęsny, making his first appearance against [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] in the [[2011–12 Football League Cup|League Cup]].{{citation needed|date=December 2018}}
On 6 December 2011, Fabiański was selected to start in Arsenal's [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League group stage|group stage]] match against [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]], but was substituted out after 25 minutes following a knee injury.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/15933230 |title=Olympiakos 3 – 1 Arsenal |date=6 December 2011 |accessdate=13 April 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
====2012–13 season==== Injuries limited Fabiański's appearances during the [[2012–13 Arsenal F.C. season|2012–13 season]], where he made only five [[2012–13 Premier League|Premier League]] appearances as back-up to Wojciech Szczęsny. In March 2013, after Szczęsny was dropped, Fabiański started in goal in the second-leg of Arsenal's [[2012–13 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] tie against [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]. He kept a clean sheet as Arsenal won 2–0 and retained his place in the team to make his first Premier League start of the season away against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on 16 March 2013, again keeping a clean sheet in a 2–0 win. Fabiański started in Arsenal's next three league matches against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] and [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]]. However, an injury sustained in the match against Norwich by Fabiański allowed Szczęsny to return to the starting line-up and reclaim his position as first-choice goalkeeper.{{citation needed|date=December 2018}}
====2013–14 season==== During the [[2013–14 Arsenal F.C. season|2013–14 season]], Fabiański was used as Arsenal's starting goalkeeper in [[2013–14 FA Cup|FA Cup]] and [[2013–14 Football League Cup|League Cup]] matches, with Szczęsny remaining first-choice in [[2013–14 Premier League|Premier League]] and [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] matches.{{citation needed|date=December 2018}}
On 19 February 2014, Fabiański came on as a substitute in the 37th minute of a 2–0 Champions League home defeat against Bayern Munich, after Szczęsny was [[Ejection (sports)|sent off]] for a foul on [[Arjen Robben]]. With Szczęsny suspended, Fabiański was in the starting line-up for the second leg and saved a late penalty from Bayern's [[Thomas Müller]].{{citation needed|date=December 2018}}
On 12 April, Fabiański saved penalties from [[Gary Caldwell]] and [[Jack Collison]] in an [[2013–14 FA Cup|FA Cup]] semi-final [[Penalty shootout|shootout]] victory over Wigan Athletic.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/26897266 |title=Wigan 1–1 Arsenal |date=12 April 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He made his only Premier League appearance of the season in the last match on 11 May, keeping a clean sheet in a 2–0 away win that caused his opponents Norwich City to be relegated.<ref>{{cite news |last=Osborne |first=Chris |title=Norwich 0–2 Arsenal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27273461 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 May 2014}}</ref> Six days later, Fabiański started for Arsenal in the [[2014 FA Cup Final]] as they defeated [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] 3–2 after extra time at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27354148 |title=Aaron Ramsey's extra-time winner ensured Arsenal ended their nine-year wait for a trophy by coming from two goals behind to beat Hull City in a dramatic FA Cup final at Wembley |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=17 May 2014}}</ref>
===Swansea City=== On 29 May 2014, it was announced that Fabiański would join fellow Premier League side Swansea City on a free transfer when his Arsenal contract expired on 1 July. He said of the transfer, "The main reason I came to Swansea was because I want to be the number one goalkeeper."<ref name=Swansea>{{cite news |title=Lukasz Fabianski leaves Arsenal to join Swansea City on free transfer |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27616469 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 May 2014}}</ref> He made his competitive debut for the club on 16 August, a 2–1 win against Manchester United at [[Old Trafford]] in the first match of the [[2014–15 Premier League|Premier League season]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bevan |first1=Chris |title=Man Utd 1–2 Swansea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28718345 |accessdate=16 August 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2014}}</ref> On 7 December 2014, Fabiański was sent off in Swansea's 1–3 loss at [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] for a foul on [[Diafra Sakho]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rose |first1=Gary |title=West Ham 3–1 Swansea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30266472 |accessdate=7 December 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 December 2014}}</ref>
On 11 May 2015, Fabiański kept a clean sheet and was named [[man of the match]] in a 1–0 win against Arsenal on his return to the [[Emirates Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11670/9847357/lukasz-fabianski-says-swanseas-win-over-arsenal-was-not-personal |title=Lukasz Fabianski says Swansea's win over Arsenal was not personal |date=11 May 2015 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> On 6 July, Fabiański signed a new four-year contract with Swansea, which would keep him at the club until June 2019.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33807475 |title=Fabianski signs 4-year deal |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=6 July 2015}}</ref>
Fabiański played all 38 of Swansea's Premier League games of [[2017–18 Swansea City A.F.C. season|2017–18]] and was voted Player of the Season by the club's supporters. His performances did not prevent the club from ending the season 18th and they were relegated to the [[EFL Championship|Championship]].<ref name=sb1718/><ref>{{Cite web |title=Swansea City's Player of the Season Awards 2018 |last=Gwilym |first=Andrew |website=WalesOnline |date=19 April 2018 |accessdate=20 June 2018 |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/swansea-citys-player-season-awards-14607269}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44020155 |title=Swansea 1–2 Stoke |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Dafydd |last=Pritchard |date=14 May 2018 |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>
===West Ham United=== On 20 June 2018, Premier League club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] announced the transfer of Fabiański for £7 million. He signed a three-year contract with the club.<ref>{{cite news |title=Lukasz Fabianski: West Ham sign Swansea City's Polish goalkeeper |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 June 2018 |accessdate=20 June 2018 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44546138}}</ref> Fabiański, the first Pole to play first-team football for West Ham, was installed as first-choice 'keeper at the start of the [[2018–19 West Ham United F.C. season|2018–19 season]].<ref name=whu8things/><ref>{{cite web |title=Standout players of 2018/19: Lukasz Fabianski |first=Adrian |last=Clarke |publisher=Premier League |date=13 October 2018 |accessdate=15 December 2018 |url= https://www.premierleague.com/news/878144}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:1 lukasz fabianksi 2016.jpg|thumb|upright|Fabiański playing for Poland against Portugal at Euro 2016]]
Having represented Poland regularly at [[Poland national under-21 football team|under-21]] level, Fabiański's performances for Legia Warsaw saw him soon making his debut for the [[Poland national football team|senior international team]] in a friendly against [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]] on 29 March 2006.<ref name="arsenaloffrelease"/>
Fabiański was included in Poland's squad for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], serving as back-up to [[Artur Boruc]] and [[Tomasz Kuszczak]]. During the qualifying campaign for the [[UEFA Euro 2008]], he made one appearance, playing all 90 minutes in Poland's 2–2 away draw against [[Serbia national football team|Serbia]] on 21 November 2007.<ref name="pzpn3777">{{cite web |url=http://www.fussballdaten.de/em/2008/qualifikation/gruppea/serbien-polen/ |title=Serbien gegen Polen 2:2 |publisher=Fussballdaten |accessdate=21 April 2010 |language=German}}</ref> In September 2008, Fabiański replaced the suspended Boruc for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2010 World Cup qualifiers]] against [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] and [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]]. He also played in another qualifying match against San Marino in April 2009.
Despite going into [[UEFA Euro 2016]] as an understudy to [[Wojciech Szczesny]], an injury in the first game of the tournament led to Fabiański becoming first choice for the rest of the tournament. He went on to keep clean sheets in both of the remaining group games against World champions [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]]. He then kept his place as Poland defeated [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] in the Round of 16 before losing to eventual winners [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] on penalties.

|url=http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/squad-lists/squad-lists-February-2013.pdf |publisher=Premier League |format=PDF |date=1 February 2013 |page=39 |accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1988|7|3|df=y}} | birth_place = [[North Shore, New Zealand|North Shore]], [[Auckland]], New Zealand | height = 1.91 m<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.premierleague.com/page/PlayerProfile/0,,12306~44344,00.html |title=Premier League Player Profile |accessdate=30 March 2011 |publisher=Premier League |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128085351/http://www.premierleague.com/page/PlayerProfile/0,,12306~44344,00.html |archivedate=28 November 2010}}</ref> | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = SUB Sønderborg | youthyears2 = | youthclubs2 = [[FC Midtjylland|Midtjylland]] | currentclub = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | clubnumber = 2 | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] | years1 = 2005–2010 | clubs1 = [[FC Midtjylland|Midtjylland]] | caps1 = 84 | goals1 = 2 | years2 = 2010– | clubs2 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps2 = 194<!--LEAGUE ONLY --> | goals2 = 9<!--LEAGUE goals only not play-offs--> | nationalyears1 = 2007 | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalteam1 = [[Denmark national under-19 football team|Denmark U19]] | nationalyears2 = 2008 | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalteam2 = Denmark U20 | nationalyears3 = 2008–2010 | nationalcaps3 = 10 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalteam3 = [[Denmark national under-21 football team|Denmark U21]] | nationalyears4 = 2010– | nationalcaps4 = 24 | nationalgoals4 = 1 | nationalteam4 = [[New Zealand national football team|New Zealand]] | pcupdate = 15:34, 3 March 2018 (UTC) | ntupdate = 06:45, 16 November 2017 (UTC) }} '''Winston Wiremu Reid''' (born 3 July 1988) is a New Zealand professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] for English {{English football updater|WestHamU}} club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] and also [[Captain (association football)|captains]] the [[New Zealand national football team|New Zealand national team]].
== Early life == Both Reid's parents have [[Māori people|Māori]] ancestry. He affiliates to [[Tainui]] through his father and to [[Te Rarawa]] through his mother.<ref name=thanks>{{Cite news |title=Thanks for the goal, Winston! |first=Yvonne |last=Tahana |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/soccer-football/news/article.cfm?c_id=86&objectid=10652438 |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=17 June 2010 |accessdate=17 June 2010}}</ref> He was born in [[North Shore, New Zealand|North Shore]], [[Auckland]],<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/all-whites/player-profile-winston-reid-3546543 |title=All Whites player profile: Winston Reid |publisher=TVNZ |date=17 May 2010 |accessdate=16 June 2010}}</ref> but moved from [[New Zealand]] to [[Denmark]] at the age of 10 with his mother and [[Danes|Danish]] stepfather. He always maintained contact with his father and his family in New Zealand.<ref name=commits/>
== Club career ==
=== FC Midtjylland === Reid signed a youth contract with SUB Sønderborg, before moving on to play youth football with [[Danish Superliga]] club [[FC Midtjylland]]. He was one of the first players to graduate from [[FC Midtjylland|FCM's]] football academy, the first of its kind in Denmark, coming through the system alongside Midtjylland teammates [[Jesper Weinkouff]], [[Christian Sivebæk]] and former teammate, [[Simon Kjær]]. In November 2005, Reid signed a professional contract with FC Midtjylland.<ref>{{cite news |title=Et spirende talent |url=http://www.fcm.dk/index.php?ID=6&nyhedID=88&mode=laes_nyhed |language=Danish |publisher=FC Midtjlland Official Website |date=23 January 2006 |accessdate=13 February 2012}}</ref> Aged 17, Reid made his FC Midtjylland debut in the [[Royal League]] tournament against Norwegian side [[Vålerenga Fotball|Vålerenga]] in a 4–0 win. He made his league debut for FC Midtjylland coming on for [[David Nielsen]] as a substitute in the 78th minute.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kampfakta: FCM – Horsens |url=http://www.fcm.dk/index.php?ID=6&nyhedID=245&mode=laes_nyhed |language=Danish |publisher=FC Midtjlland Official Website |date=2 April 2006 |accessdate=13 February 2012}}</ref> Playing few games in seasons 2005–06, 2006–07 and 2007–08 it was not until season 2008–09 that Reid made 28 appearances and scored his first goal against [[AaB Fodbold]] in a 3–2 loss on 23 March 2009 and scored his second in the league in his next match against [[AC Horsens]] in a 3–1 win on 5 April 2009. Reid also established himself in the starting eleven throughout the season until Reid left the club.
=== West Ham United ===
==== 2010–11 season ==== Reid signed for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 5 August 2010, on a three-year contract for an undisclosed fee.<ref name="west ham">{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20100805/reid-signs_2236884_2112684 |title=Reid signs |publisher=West Ham United Official Website |date=5 August 2010 |accessdate=5 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921085430/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20100805/reid-signs_2236884_2112684 |archivedate=21 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=811998&sec=transfers&cc=5739 |title=Hammers sign All Whites international Reid |date=5 August 2010 |work=ESPN Soccernet |accessdate=5 August 2010}}</ref> His transfer fee was the subject of a dispute between West Ham United and FC Midtjylland as West Ham withheld the fee to bring to [[UEFA]]'s attention fees owing to them from the sale of [[Alessandro Diamanti]] to [[Brescia Calcio|Brescia]].<ref>{{cite news |title=West Ham refuse to pay Winston Reid transfer due to bitter dispute with Fifa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/west-ham/8823344/West-Ham-refuse-to-pay-Winston-Reid-transfer-due-to-bitter-dispute-with-Fifa.html |publisher=Telegraph |date=13 October 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2012}}</ref> He made his [[Premier League]] debut on 14 August, in a 3–0 loss to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]],<ref>{{cite news |last=Darling |first=Kevin |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8906162.stm |title=BBC Sport – Football – Aston Villa 3–0 West Ham |publisher=BBC News |date=14 August 2010 |accessdate=15 August 2010}}</ref> and scored his first goal for the club in a 5–1 win against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in the Fifth Round of the [[FA Cup]] on 21 February 2011.<ref name="WHUGoal">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/west_ham_utd/9404702.stm |title=Winston Reid sympathises with New Zealand quake victims |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 February 2011 |accessdate=2 June 2011 |author=Leon Mann}}</ref> In his first season for West Ham United Reid's first team opportunities were limited, making just 12 appearances in all competitions as the club was relegated.
==== 2011–12 season ==== For the 2011–2012 season Reid stayed at West Ham following relegation to the [[Football League Championship|Championship]], and scored his first league goal for West Ham United in a 4–1 away win over [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Nottingham Forest 1 – 4 West Ham United Match Report |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20110828/nottm-forest-1-west-ham-4_2234233_57971 |publisher=WHFC Official Website |date=28 August 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2012}}</ref> Reid also scored the winning goal against arch-rivals [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] in a 2–1 home win on 4 February 2012.<ref>{{cite news |title=West Ham United 2 – 1 Millwall Match Report |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20120204/west-ham-2-millwall-1_2234233_59529 |publisher=WHFC Official Website |date=4 February 2012 |accessdate=13 February 2012}}</ref> West Ham finished the season by winning the [[2012 Football League Championship play-off Final|Football League play-offs]] against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] at [[Wembley Stadium]], and gaining promotion back to the Premier League at the first attempt.
==== 2012–13 season ==== In summer 2012, Reid opted to stay and train with his West Ham teammates ahead of the new Premier League season rather than represent [[New Zealand at the 2012 Summer Olympics#Men's tournament 2|New Zealand]] at the London Olympics.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/west-ham-defender-winston-reid-chooses-club-over-country-as-he-turns-down-olympics-7869151.html |title=West Ham defender Winston Reid chooses club over country as he turns down Olympics – Football – Sport – London Evening Standard |publisher=Standard.co.uk |date=20 June 2012 |accessdate=2013-01-05}}</ref> He scored his first ever Premier League goal in West Ham's 3–0 victory against Fulham on 1 September 2012, and in May 2013 Reid signed a two-year extension to his contact until the end of the 2014–15 season.<ref>{{cite web |title=Winston Reid inks two-year deal at West Ham |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/football/8616509/Winston-Reid-inks-two-year-deal-at-West-Ham |publisher=www.stuff.co.nz |accessdate=1 May 2013}}</ref> Arguably his best season since joining the club, Reid was rewarded for his form on 8 May 2013 when he was named [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer of the Year|Hammer of the Year]], as West Ham went on to finish the season in 10th.<ref name=Hoty>{{cite web |title=Reid crowned Hammer of the Year |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20130508/reid-crowned-hammer-of-the-year_2236884_3172136 |publisher=Www.whufc.com |accessdate=9 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511115924/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20130508/reid-crowned-hammer-of-the-year_2236884_3172136 |archivedate=11 May 2013}}</ref>
==== 2013–14 season ==== Reid scored the opening goal in a 3–0 away win against rivals [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in October 2013. However, in November 2013 he suffered an ankle injury in training which required surgery. He made his return in February 2014 in a 2–0 home win against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref>{{Soccerbase season|49688|2013|access-date=2 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20131106/reid-injured_2236884_3526767 |title=Reid injured |publisher=www.whufc.com |accessdate=2 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203234221/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20131106/reid-injured_2236884_3526767 |archivedate=3 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20131122/winston-reid-update_2236884_3540685 |title=Winston Reid update |publisher=www.whufc.com |accessdate=2 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20140201/west-ham-united-2-0-swansea-city-ft_2236884_3648687 |title=West Ham 2–0 Swansea |publisher=www.whufc.com |accessdate=2 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202135628/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20140201/west-ham-united-2-0-swansea-city-ft_2236884_3648687 |archivedate=2 February 2014}}</ref> Reid made his 100th appearance for West Ham in all competitions on 15 April, in a 1–3 defeat away to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].
==== 2014–15 season ==== On 20 September, Reid scored the first goal after just two minutes in a 3–1 win against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at Upton Park.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29187275 |title=West Ham United 3–1 Liverpool |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> In March 2015, Reid signed a new six-and-a-half year contract with West Ham, after much speculation over his future at the club, after being linked with London rivals [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref name="sixandahalf">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31744884 |title=Winston Reid: West Ham defender signs six-and-a-half-year deal |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref>
==== 2015–16 season ==== [[File:West Ham United Vs Manchester City (24107027383).jpg|thumb|Reid before West Ham's 2–2 draw with [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], January 2016]]
On 10 May 2016, Reid wrote his name into West Ham United folklore, when he scored the last ever goal at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]] in a 3–2 win against [[Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/reid-thrills-boleyn-shred-man-utd-top-four-215126320--sow.html;_ylt=AwrEWDbLWzJXuDcARydXNyoA;_ylu=X3oDMTEybDZvZ21uBGNvbG8DYmYxBHBvcwMxBHZ0aWQDQjIwNDZfMQRzZWMDc2M- |title=Violence, drama as Man Utd's top-four hopes shredded |publisher= |accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref>
== International career == {{update|section|date=July 2016}} Reid received Danish [[citizenship]] in 2006<ref name="west ham"/> and was subsequently called up for the [[Denmark national under-19 football team|under-19 national team]]. He played for various Danish age-grade representative teams, in particular the under-19s and [[Denmark national under-21 football team|under-21s]], and played in the [[2009 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification play-offs|2009 European Under-21 Championship qualification]] tournament.
On 11 March 2010, Reid stated that he wanted to play for the senior [[New Zealand national football team|New Zealand team]],<ref name="3News_145900">{{cite news |url=http://www.3news.co.nz/All-Whites-bolster-ranks-with-Danish-star-Winston-Reid/tabid/415/articleID/145900/Default.aspx |title=All Whites bolster ranks with Danish star Winston Reid |author=Gourdie, Andrew |date=11 March 2010 |work=[[3 News]] |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> and on 13 March 2010 he made himself available for New Zealand's [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]] selection.<ref name=commits>{{cite web |author=Woodcock, Fred |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/football/3443252/Reid-changes-mind-commits-to-All-Whites |title=Reid changes mind, commits to All Whites |work=The Dominion Post |date=13 March 2010 |accessdate=16 June 2010}}</ref> On 10 May 2010, Reid was included in New Zealand's 2010 World Cup squad even though New Zealand national coach [[Ricki Herbert]] had never seen him play.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>{{cite web |last=Johnstone |first=Duncan |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/football/world-cup/3676399/All-Whites-World-Cup-squad-named |title=All Whites World Cup squad named |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date=10 May 2010 |accessdate=16 June 2010}}</ref> He made his international debut in a friendly against [[Australia national football team|Australia]] in [[Melbourne]] two weeks later. His second appearance came in the All Whites' shock 1–0 victory over [[Serbia national football team|Serbia]], leaving Ricki Herbert "suitably impressed" with Reid's performance,<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_3756323">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/fifa-world-cup/all-whites/3756323/A-real-downer-for-Serb-fans-in-dress-rehearsal |title=A real downer for Serb fans in dress rehearsal |author=Smith, Tony |date=31 May 2010 |work=[[The Press]] |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> supplanting [[Ben Sigmund]] on the right side of Herbert's three-man defence.
On 15 June 2010, Reid scored an equalising goal in stoppage time against [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]] in their opening game of the 2010 World Cup, thus securing a draw as well as his first ever international goal and New Zealand's first ever point in a World Cup finals match.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_12 New Zealand 1–1 Slovakia] ''BBC Sport'', 15 June 2010</ref>
On 12 October 2010, Winston picked up his first international red card against [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]] in [[Wellington]] for a "vicious"<ref>{{cite web |last=Worthington |first=Sam |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/football/4230397/No-serious-damage-for-Winston-Reids-victim |title=No serious damage for Winston Reid's victim |publisher=The Dominion Post |date=14 October 2010 |accessdate=17 October 2010}}</ref> studs-up tackle on striker [[Federico Santander]] in the 90th minute of the [[New Zealand national football team|All Whites']] 2–0 defeat.
Following the retirement of [[Ryan Nelsen]] from international football in 2013, Winston Reid was named captain of the All Whites.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/football/8450714/Winston-Reid-named-All-Whites-captain |title=Winston Reid named new All Whites captain |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date=20 March 2013 |accessdate=22 March 2013 |first=Tony |last=Smith}}</ref> On 7 November 2013, Reid was ruled out of the All Whites' FIFA World Cup playoff against Mexico, not only leaving a void on defense, but also with his successor as captain uncertain.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=11152966 |title=Key questions: What now for Reid-less All Whites? |date=7 November 2013 |publisher= |accessdate=15 January 2017 |via=New Zealand Herald}}</ref> As of December 2017, Reid has won 23 caps for his country.
=== International goals === :''Scores and results list New Zealand's goal tally first.''<ref>{{cite news |url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/winston-wiremu-reid/11749/ |title=W. Reid |publisher=Soccerway |accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref>

'''Pablo Javier Zabaleta Girod''' ({{IPA-es|ˈpaβlo saβaˈleta|am}}; born 16 January 1985<ref name=MCFC2014/>) is an Argentine professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right-back]] for English {{English football updater|WestHamU}} club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] and the [[Argentina national football team|Argentina national team]]. Zabaleta can operate on both sides of the pitch as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|full-back]] and is known for his tenacious style of play, and has [[Captain (association football)|captained]] his club on numerous occasions.
With [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], Zabaleta won all of English football's major honours: the [[FA Cup]] ([[2010–11 FA Cup|2011]]), the Premier League ([[2011–12 Premier League|2012]] and 2014), and the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] ([[2013–14 Football League Cup|2014]] and 2016). Before joining Manchester City, Zabaleta played for [[La Liga]] club [[RCD Espanyol]], where he won the [[2005–06 Copa del Rey]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/football/players/pablo-zabaleta/|title=Pablo Zabaleta|accessdate=22 April 2014|publisher=Eurosport}}</ref> He made 333 appearances over nine seasons for Manchester City before signing for London-based club West Ham United in the summer of 2017.
A full international since 2005, Zabaleta represented Argentina at the [[2011 Copa América|2011]] and [[2015 Copa América]], and was part of their team which finished as runners-up in the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]. He was also in their team which won gold at the [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2008 Olympics]].
==Club career== ===San Lorenzo=== Born in [[Buenos Aires]], Zabaleta was raised in [[Arrecifes]]. He began his career at [[Club Atlético San Lorenzo de Almagro]] in 2002 after progressing through their youth ranks, having been signed at the age of 12 from local club ''Obras Sanitarias''. He started playing as a [[defensive midfielder]] but eventually moved to the right side of midfield.
===Espanyol=== Zabaleta was transferred to [[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]] in 2005 for €3 million after being [[Argentina national under-20 football team|Argentina under-20]]s [[Captain (association football)|captain]] in the [[2005 FIFA World Youth Championship]], which Argentina won. During the [[2005–06 La Liga|2005–06 season]], Zabaleta helped Espanyol to win the [[2005–06 Copa del Rey|Copa del Rey]], playing the full 90 minutes in the 4–1 defeat of [[Real Zaragoza]] in [[2006 Copa del Rey Final|the final]].<ref name="paradise">{{Cite news |title=Zabaleta rejects Juventus in favour of move to 'paradise' |last=Taylor |first=Daniel |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/aug/29/manchestercity.espanyolzabaleta |newspaper=The Guardian |date=29 August 2008 |location=London}}</ref>
In January 2007, Zabaleta suffered a [[shoulder]] injury that kept him off the pitch for almost three months, already having established himself as an undisputed first team choice. Later in the season, he featured in the [[2006–07 UEFA Cup]] [[2007 UEFA Cup Final|final]], where Espanyol lost on penalties to fellow Spanish side [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]].
===Manchester City=== ====2008–2012==== [[File:Pablo Zabaleta ready to throw vs Bolton.jpg|thumb|180px|right|Zabaleta playing for [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in 2009]]
In the summer of 2008, Zabaleta transferred to [[Premier League]] club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] after rejecting an offer from [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]]. He stated upon joining that "the offer of Manchester City is impossible to reject."<ref>{{Cite news |title=Espanyol's Zabaleta turns down Juventus to join Man City for £6.5m |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1050567/Espanyols-Zabaleta-turns-Juventus-join-Man-City-6-5m.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=29 August 2008 |location=London |first=Ian |last=Ladyman}}</ref> Having passed a medical and agreed personal terms, Zabaleta completed a five-year deal with City on 31 August 2008 for an undisclosed fee, believed to be the buy-out clause Zabaleta had attached to his contract of around £6.45 million.<ref name=paradise/> Zabaleta joined a day before Manchester City was bought by the [[Abu Dhabi United Group]], led by [[Sheikh Mansour]], which enabled a wealth of investment in the club.
On 13 September 2008, Zabaleta made his debut for Manchester City in a 3–1 defeat to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]]. On 5 October, he received his first [[Penalty card#Red card|red card]] in English football when he was sent off in a 3–2 loss to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in his fourth Premier League appearance. He scored his first goal for City on 17 January 2009, the only goal of the game in a 1–0 league win over [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7815631.stm|title=Man City 1–0 Wigan|publisher=BBC|date=17 January 2009|accessdate=2 January 2010|first=Chris|last=Bevan}}</ref>
On 21 November 2010, Zabaleta scored his second Premier League goal in Manchester City's 4–1 win against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]. In the same match, he [[Assist (football)|assisted]] a [[Carlos Tevez]] goal, helping his compatriot to earn his ninth goal for the club during the [[2010–11 Manchester City F.C. season|2010–11]] season.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Fulham 1–4 Manchester City |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/293144?cc=5901 |publisher=ESPN Soccernet |date=21 November 2010}}</ref>
On 1 January 2011, Zabaleta played his 100th game for Manchester City in all competitions, coming off the bench against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] in a 1–0 win at Eastlands. Two weeks later, on 15 January, Zabaleta made his second assist of the season in a 4–3 win over [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].<ref>{{Cite news |title=Manchester 4–3 Wolves |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=293123&cc=5901 |publisher=ESPN Soccernet |date=15 January 2011}}</ref> This win meant that City went top of [[2010–11 Premier League|the league]] above [[Manchester derby|local rivals]] [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. However, City's title challenge faded with a loss of form in February and March 2011.
On 1 May 2011, Zabaleta scored his second goal of the season in a Premier League match against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. This secured a 2–1 win for the Citizens and put them seven points ahead of [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in the race for [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League|fourth place]].<ref>{{Cite news |title=Manchester City 2–1 West Ham |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/293139?cc=5739 |publisher=ESPN Soccernet |date=1 May 2011}}</ref>
On 14 May 2011, Zabaleta appeared as an 88th-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for Carlos Tevez in the [[2011 FA Cup Final]] as Manchester City beat [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] 1–0.<ref name=11cup>{{cite news|last=Gibbs|first=Thom|title=FA Cup final 2011: Manchester City v Stoke City live|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/fa-cup/8513729/FA-Cup-final-2011-Manchester-City-v-Stoke-City-live.html|accessdate=6 March 2014|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=14 May 2011|location=London}}</ref>
In the summer of 2011, it was reported that Italian club [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] were keen on signing Zabaleta, but Manchester City insisted the player was not for sale<ref>{{Cite news |title=Roma to launch £6m Zabaleta bid, but Manchester City unwilling to sell Argentina defender |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2014502/Roma-launch-6m-bid-Pablo-Zabaleta-Manchester-City-unwilling-sell-Argentina-defender.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=14 July 2011 |location=London}}</ref> and Zabaleta agreed a three-year contract in July 2011. On 1 October 2011, Zabaleta started and played the full 90 minutes at right-back in a 4–0 win over [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] at [[Ewood Park]] in the Premier League, as regular starter [[Micah Richards]] was not available. On 23 October, he was an unused substitute in the convincing 1–6 win over rivals Manchester United at [[Old Trafford]], with Richards starting at right-back.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Zabaleta agrees three-year deal |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/zabaleta-agrees-threeyear-deal-2318961.html |newspaper=The Independent |date=23 July 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
In November 2011, Zabaleta extended his contract with City until the summer of 2015. Zabaleta said, "I'm in a very good team, and I try to do my best for the club, the team and the fans. I didn't think twice, I gave a quick answer because I was so happy to sign."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2063216/Manchester-City-new-deals-Adam-Johnson-Pablo-Zabaleta.html | location=London | newspaper=Daily Mail | title=Going places! Johnson hails City ambition as he joins Zabaleta in agreeing new deal | date=18 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=City tie down Johnson and Zabaleta |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=1717452.html |date=18 November 2011 |publisher=[[UEFA]] |access-date=29 June 2016}}</ref> In his first three-and-a-half years at the club, Zabaleta emerged as a cult hero amongst the Manchester City fans who admire his never-say-die attitude and commitment to the club.
On 30 April 2012, he started and played the full 90 minutes in the right-back slot in a 1–0 victory over rivals Manchester United thanks to a first-half stoppage time header by [[Vincent Kompany]] from a corner at the City of Manchester Stadium. Zabaleta scored the first goal in City's dramatic 3–2 win over [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on the final day of the [[2011–12 Premier League|season]], a result which secured the first league title for the club since 1968.<ref>{{cite news|title=Man City 3 QPR 2|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/4313835/Man-City-3-2-QPR-Match-report-pictures-video-highlights.html|newspaper=The Sun|location=London|first=Shaun|last=Custis}}</ref> On 9 December 2012, Zabaleta scored a late equalising goal in a 3–2 defeat to Manchester United.
====2013–2017==== [[File:Zabaleta Negredo league cup.JPG|thumb|left|180px|Zabaleta and [[Álvaro Negredo]] with the trophy after the [[2014 Football League Cup Final|2014 League Cup Final]]]]
On 1 January 2013, he scored the opening goal in a 3–0 win at the City of Manchester Stadium over Stoke City, doubling his goal tally from the previous season. On 25 January 2013, Zabaleta scored his third goal of the season and the only goal of the match in a 1–0 win away against Stoke City in the [[2012–13 FA Cup|FA Cup]], fourth round. His goal took Manchester City through to the fifth round.
Zabaleta was voted Manchester City's Player of the Month for both December 2012<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/2013/January/Zaba-wins-Etihad-prize|title=Zabaleta is Etihad Player of the Month|date=7 January 2013|publisher=Manchester City F.C.}}</ref> and January 2013,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/2013/February/Zabaleta-wins-January-Etihad-Player-of-the-Month|title=Zabaleta voted Etihad Player of the Month|date=11 February 2013|publisher=Manchester City F.C.}}</ref> and was stand-in captain for the club during [[Vincent Kompany]]'s injury absence between January and March 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/manchester-city-missing-uniteds-winning-1786570|title=Mind games: Manchester City are missing United's winning mentality, admits Pablo Zabaleta|date=26 March 2013|access-date=22 February 2015|newspaper=Daily Mirror}}</ref> He was the only City player to be named in the 2012–13 Premier League [[PFA Team of the Year]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Gareth Bale wins PFA Player of Year and Young Player awards|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/22331030|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 April 2013|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref> After a superb season, Zabaleta was voted 2012–13 Manchester City Player of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/news/team-news/2013/june/zabaleta-named-player-of-the-year|title=Pablo Zabaleta is Manchester City Player of the Year|date=4 June 2013|publisher=Manchester City F.C.|accessdate=21 June 2013}}</ref>
Zabaleta was sent off in the [[2013 FA Cup Final]] against Wigan Athletic for a second [[Penalty card#Yellow card|yellow card]] after a clear foul on [[Callum McManaman]] 84 minutes into the match. Wigan went on to win 1–0 through a [[Ben Watson (footballer, born July 1985)|Ben Watson]] goal in stoppage time. He was the third player to be sent off in an FA Cup final and first for the losing side.
On 2 March 2014, Zabaleta played the full 90 minutes as Manchester City beat [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 3–1 in the [[2014 Football League Cup Final|2014 League Cup Final]] to complete a full set of major honours in English football.<ref name=14cup>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/26311649|title=Man City 3–1 Sunderland|date=2 March 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 21 April, he scored his first goal of the season in a 3–1 defeat of West Bromwich Albion at the City of Manchester Stadium.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/27017161|title=Man City 3–1 West Brom|date=21 April 2014|accessdate=22 April 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 11 May, Zabaleta was part of the victory against West Ham that won Manchester City the Premier League, his second in three seasons.
On 21 September 2014, Zabaleta was sent off for a second [[Penalty card#Yellow card|yellow card]] due to a challenge on Chelsea's [[Diego Costa]]. Both players received a yellow card, Zabaleta for the initial challenge and Costa for his reaction.
On 21 August 2015, it was announced that Zabaleta was out for a month with knee injury.<ref>{{cite web|title=Manchester City's Pablo Zabaleta out for month with knee injury|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/34018567|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 August 2015|accessdate=21 August 2015}}</ref> On 17 January 2016, Zabaleta reached 200 appearances for Manchester City in the club's 4–0 victory over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Zabaleta proud to be 'half Mancunian' after 200th City appearance |url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/85/england/2016/01/17/19416502/zabaleta-proud-to-be-half-mancunian-after-300th-city |date=17 January 2016 |website=Goal.com |accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref>
Zabaleta made 32 appearances in all competitions in the 2016–17 season scoring two goals; against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] in the Premier League and against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] in the FA Cup. His final appearance for Manchester City came on 16 May 2017, a 3–1 home win against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39853090|title=Manchester City 3–1 West Bromwich Albion|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Chris|last=Bevan|date=16 May 2017|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref> After the game he was praised by the City manager, [[Pep Guardiola]], as a "legend".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2017/may/17/manchester-city-guardiola-praises-legend-zabaleta-after-west-brom-win-video|title=Manchester City’s Guardiola praises ‘legend’ Zabaleta after West Brom win – video|newspaper=The Guardian|date=17 May 2017}}</ref> Zabaleta was given a lifetime season ticket for Manchester City and a shirt that read “Zabaleta 333”, to mark the number of City appearances he made.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/may/16/manchester-city-west-bromwich-albion-premier-league-match-report|title=Manchester City bid farewell to Pablo Zabaleta after crucial West Brom win|first=Jamie|last=Jackson|date=16 May 2017|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
===West Ham United=== On 26 May 2017, Zabaleta signed for [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on a free transfer, agreeing to a two-year contract. He was given number five as his squad number.<ref>{{cite web|title=Joint-Chairman hails ‘supreme professional’ Zabaleta|url=http://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2017/may/26-may/joint-chairman-hails-supreme-professional-zabaleta|publisher=West Ham United F.C.|date=26 May 2017|accessdate=26 May 2017}}</ref>
On 22 May 2018, [[Manuel Pellegrini]] was confirmed as manager of [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]],<ref name=WestHamIn>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44163423 |title=West Ham: Manuel Pellegrini named new manager at London Stadium |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 May 2018 |accessdate=22 May 2018}}</ref> reuniting him with his former manager at [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].
==International career== [[File:MessiZabaletaBanega.jpg|thumb|190px|Zabaleta (middle) before a game against Croatia, 2014]]
At the age of 14, Zabaleta was called up by [[Hugo Tocalli]] to the Argentina under-15 squad. He took part in many youth tournaments, including the [[FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in [[2003 FIFA World Youth Championship|2003]] and [[2005 FIFA World Youth Championship|2005]], winning the latter in the [[Netherlands]]. He received over 75 caps to national youth sides, and started representing [[Argentina national football team|the senior side]] in 2005. He was also a member of the gold medal-winning team at the [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2008 Summer Olympics]], starting at right-back and playing all six matches.
After the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]], for which Zabaleta was not selected by head coach [[Diego Maradona]], under the new Argentina manager he has established himself as first-choice right-back. On 1 June 2011, Zabaleta captained Argentina for the first time in a friendly against [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]].
In June 2014, Zabaleta was named in Argentina's squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2014/m=6/news=demichelis-in-argentina-squad-as-trio-miss-out-2353431.html|title=Demichelis in Argentina squad as trio miss out|date=2 June 2014|accessdate=21 June 2014|publisher=FIFA}}</ref> He made his [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] debut in Argentina's 2–1 win over [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] at the [[Estádio do Maracanã]], playing the full match in defence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/25285099|title=Argentina 2–1 Bos-Herce|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=21 June 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
At the [[2015 Copa América]] in Chile, Zabaleta sent in the cross from which his Manchester City teammate [[Sergio Agüero]] headed the only goal of the game as Argentina defeated holders [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] in their second [[2015 Copa América Group B|group]] match.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/33085567|title=Argentina 1–0 Uruguay|date=17 June 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
==Personal life== Zabaleta was born in [[Buenos Aires]], to a family of Basque descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euskalkultura.com/espanol/noticias/el-delantero-uruguayo-diego-forlan-su-abuela-vasca-y-sus-deseos-de-fichar-por-el-athletic-club-de-bilbao|title=El delantero uruguayo Diego Forlán, su abuela vasca, y sus deseos de fichar por el Athlétic Club de Bilbao|publisher=EuskalKultura.com}}</ref> Zabaleta has a tattoo on his chest which bears the name of his mother.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pablo Zabaleta espera duro partido para Argentina contra Holanda|url=https://ecodiario.eleconomista.es/global/noticias/702153/08/08/Pablo-Zabaleta-espera-duro-partido-para-Argentina-contra-Holanda.html|newspaper=El Economista|date=13 August 2008|accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> In June 2018, he worked as a pundit for the BBC's [[Match of the Day]] [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]] coverage from Russia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44568837|title=World Cup 2018: 'Everyone is so angry' – Pablo Zabaleta reacts to Argentina defeat|date=21 June 2018|accessdate=22 June 2018|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
