At the end of the match, Hernández claimed the [[hat-trick]], but replays showed that his shot for United's second goal was hit wide until turned into his own net by Villa defender [[Ron Vlaar]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://metro.co.uk/2012/11/10/aston-villa-v-manchester-united-javier-hernandez-hits-double-to-give-manchester-united-victory-at-villa-park-617033/ |title=Javier Hernández hits double to give Manchester United victory at Villa Park |publisher=Metro.uk |date=10 November 2012}}</ref> On 24 November, he scored his fifth league goal of the season in a 3–1 home win over [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Jonathan |last=Jurejko |title=Man Utd 3–1 QPR |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20374677 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 November 2012 |accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> On 26 December, Hernández scored United's fourth goal in the final minutes in a 4–3 win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] at Old Trafford.<ref>{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Bartram |title=Report: United 4 Newcastle 3 |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/Fixtures-And-Results/Match-Reports/2012/Dec/manchester-united-v-newcastle-united-premier-league-report.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=26 December 2012 |accessdate=14 February 2015}}</ref> He then began 2013 by scoring a brace against Wigan on 1 January, helping United to a 4–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news |title=Wigan 0–4 Manchester United |url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/345667/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901 |website=ESPN FC |date=1 January 2013 |accessdate=23 March 2013}}</ref> On 26 January, Hernández would go on to score another brace, this time during an FA Cup match against Fulham which United won 4–1.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester United 4–1 Fulham |url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/359761/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901 |website=ESPN FC |date=26 January 2013 |accessdate=23 March 2013}}</ref>
In another FA Cup match against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on 18 February, Hernández scored in the 72nd minute, giving United a 2–0 lead. His goal would end up being a deciding factor as United went on to win the game 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester United 2–1 Reading |url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/360563/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901 |website=ESPN FC |date=18 February 2013 |accessdate=23 March 2013}}</ref> Although he started in United's 2–0 Premier League victory against QPR on 23 February 2013, he did not score in the match and he didn't score again until 10 March in another FA Cup match against Chelsea which ended in a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester United 2–2 Chelsea |url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/363236/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901 |website=ESPN FC |date=10 March 2013 |accessdate=23 March 2013}}</ref> Hernández opened the scoring in manager [[Alex Ferguson|Sir Alex Ferguson]]'s final home game at [[Old Trafford]] against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]]. After a free kick was not cleared, he slotted in from six yards in the first half to put United 1–0 up, in a game they went on to win 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Manchester United 2–1 Swansea |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/22417737 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=12 May 2013}}</ref> Hernández scored United's last goal of the season and the final goal of the Ferguson era, when he tapped in a cross from close range in a 5–5 draw away at [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on the final day.<ref>{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Johnston |title=West Brom 5–5 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/22499117 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref>
====2013–14 season==== Hernández scored his first goal of [[2013–14 Manchester United F.C. season|the season]] under new manager [[David Moyes]] on 25 September 2013, netting the only goal of a home win over rivals Liverpool in the third round of the League Cup.<ref>{{cite news |title=Capital One Cup third round: Javier Hernandez goal sees Man Utd beat Liverpool |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11669/8941797/capital-one-cup-third-round-javier-hernandez-goal-sees-man-utd-beat-liverpool |accessdate=31 August 2015 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=25 September 2013}}</ref> On 26 October, with his first league goal of the campaign, he headed the winner as they came from behind to defeat Stoke 3–2 at Old Trafford.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wright |first1=David |title=Manchester United 3 – Stoke City 2: David Moyes' men fight back in scrappy win |url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/439372/Manchester-United-3-Stoke-City-2-David-Moyes-men-fight-back-in-scrappy-win |accessdate=31 August 2015 |newspaper=Daily Express |date=26 October 2013}}</ref> Three days later, he recorded a brace – starting with a penalty – in a 4–0 win against [[Norwich City]] in the next round of the League Cup.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd 4–0 Norwich |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24619369 |accessdate=31 August 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 October 2013}}</ref> In the tournament's semi-finals, his goal from [[Adnan Januzaj]]'s cross in the last minute of extra time forced a [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]], which United lost to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Daniel |title=Sunderland beat Manchester United in dramatic shootout to reach final |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jan/22/manchester-united-sunderland-capital-one-cup-match-report |accessdate=31 August 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=22 January 2014}}</ref>
====Real Madrid (loan)==== On 1 September 2014, Hernández signed for [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] on a season-long loan deal, with an option of a purchase at the end of the loan.<ref>{{cite web |date=1 September 2014 |title=Real Madrid sign Javier Hernández on loan from Manchester United |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/sep/01/javier-hernandez-real-madrid-manchester-united-loan |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=2 September 2014}}</ref> He underwent a medical and signed the contract that same day.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chicharito Hernández signs his contract with Real Madrid |url=http://www.realmadrid.com/en/news/2014/09/chicharito-hernandez-signs-his-contract-with-real-madrid |publisher=Real Madrid C.F. |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref>
He made his debut in the [[Madrid derby]] on 13 September, replacing [[Karim Benzema]] for the final 27 minutes as the team lost 2–1 at home to [[Atlético Madrid]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Real Madrid 1–2 Atl Madrid |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29176277 |accessdate=20 September 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2014}}</ref> On 19 September, Hernández came on as a 77th-minute substitute for [[Gareth Bale]] and scored his first two goals in an 8–2 away win against [[Deportivo de La Coruña]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29275785 |title=Deportivo de La Coruña 2–8 Real Madrid |date=19 September 2014 |accessdate=19 September 2014 |publisher=BBC}}</ref>
He scored the winning goal on 22 April 2015 in the 1–0 win over [[Atlético Madrid]], which sent Real Madrid into the semi-finals of the [[2014–15 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espnfc.com/uefa-champions-league/match/418408/real-madrid-atletico-madrid/report |title=Javier Hernandez scores as Real Madrid beat Atletico Madrid |publisher=ESPN FC |date=22 April 2015 |accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> Four days later, Hernández scored a brace in Madrid's 2–4 away win over [[Celta de Vigo]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Begley |first=Emlyn |date=26 April 2015 |title=Celta de Vigo 2–4 Real Madrid |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32436173 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref>
On 26 May, it was announced that Hernández would return to Manchester United following the end of his loan spell after Real Madrid decided not to make the loan move a permanent deal.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32882997 |title=Javier Hernandez back at Man Utd as Real Madrid decide against deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 May 2015 |accessdate=26 May 2015}}</ref>
====Permanent exit from Manchester United==== On 29 August 2015, it was reported that Manchester United manager [[Louis Van Gaal]] had told Hernández he could leave the club before the closure of the transfer window. Although with one year of his contract still remaining, it was unclear with scale of transfer fee United would demand for him.<ref>{{cite news |last=Burt |first=Jason |title=Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal tells Javier Hernandez he is free to leave |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-united/11832741/Manchester-United-manager-Louis-van-Gaal-tells-Javier-Hernandez-he-is-free-to-leave.html |accessdate=18 September 2018 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=29 August 2015}}</ref>
Hernández played in what proved to be his final match for Manchester United on 22 August in a scoreless draw against Newcastle United at Old Trafford. He came on as a substitute in the 67th minute, replacing Adnan Januzaj.<ref>{{cite web |last=Johnston |first=Neil |date=23 August 2015 |title=Man Utd 0–0 Newcastle |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/33945081 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=23 August 2015}}</ref> As he often came on as a substitute during his time with Manchester United, Hernández's minutes per goal ratio is among the most prolific in the history of the [[Premier League]].<ref name="goal ratio" /><ref>{{cite news |title=Revealed! The most lethal Premier League goal scorers of all-time |url=http://talksport.com/football/revealed-most-lethal-premier-league-goal-scorers-all-time-141007117545?p=6 |publisher=talkSport |date=7 October 2014 |accessdate=23 October 2015}}</ref>
===Bayer Leverkusen=== On 31 August 2015, it was announced Hernández signed a three-year contract with [[Bundesliga]] club [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen|Bayer Leverkusen]] for an undisclosed fee,<ref>{{cite web |title=Chicarito completes transfer from United to Bayer Leverkusen |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2015/Aug/javier-chicharito-hernandez-completes-transfer-from-manchester-united-to-bayer-leverkusen.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref> reportedly £7.3 million.<ref>{{cite news |title=Javier Hernandez: Man Utd striker joins Bayer Leverkusen for £7.3m |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34108233 |accessdate=31 August 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 August 2015}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== Hernández made his Bundesliga debut as a 58th-minute substitute in the 1–0 defeat to [[Darmstadt 98]] on 12 September.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chicharito makes Bayer Leverkusen debut |url=http://www.goal.com/s/en-us/news/114/mexico/2015/09/12/15285212/chicharito-makes-bayer-leverkusen-debut |website=Goal |accessdate=12 September 2015}}</ref> Four days later he scored his first goal in the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] group-stage match against [[FC BATE Borisov|BATE Borisov]], scoring the third goal in the 4–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bayer Leverkusen 4 BATE 1: Hernandez nets in comfortable win |url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/news/bayer-leverkusen-4-bate-1-hernandez-nets-comfortable-win |website=FourFourTwo |accessdate=16 September 2015}}</ref> On 23 September, Hernández scored his first Bundesliga goal in Bayer's 1–0 victory over [[FSV Mainz 05|FSV Mainz]], being also named Man of the Match.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hernandez strike downs Mainz |url=http://www.bundesliga.com/en/news/Bundesliga/blmd6-hernandez-strike-downs-mainz.jsp |publisher=Bundesliga |accessdate=23 September 2015}}</ref> On 20 October, Hernández scored his first brace for Leverkusen in their 4–4 draw against [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] in the Champions League.<ref>{{cite web |last=Howarth |first=Matthew |date=20 October 2015 |title=Leverkusen leave it late in eight-goal thriller |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000634/match=2015698/postmatch/report/index.html#leverkusen+leave+late |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref> He ended the Champions League group stage with five goals from six matches but Bayer failed to qualify for the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League knockout phase|knockout phase]], finishing third in Group E and dropping into the [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.goal.com/en/people/mexico/35050/javier-chicharito-hernandez |title=Javier 'Chicharito' Hernandez |access-date=10 December 2015 |website=Goal.com}}</ref>
Hernández was named Bundesliga Player of the Month for November; a month in which he scored in a 2–1 loss at home to [[1. FC Köln]] and twice in 3–1 win at [[Eintracht Frankfurt]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Chicharito-Named-Bundesliga-Player-of-the-Month-in-November-20151206-0014.html |title=Chicharito Named Bundesliga Player of the Month in November |date=6 December 2015 |website=teleSUR}}</ref> On 12 December, Hernández scored his first [[hat-trick]] in Leverkusen's 5–0 win over [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]], thus scoring 15 goals in his last 12 matches, and taking his tally to 17 goals in 20 matches.<ref>{{cite web |last=Dunbar |first=Ross |title=Chicharito hat trick lifts Leverkusen to big win over Gladbach |url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/javier-hernandez-hat-trick-lifts-bayer-leverkusen-to-big-win-over-gladbach-121215 |publisher=Fox Sports |accessdate=12 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Javier Hernandez hat trick carries Leverkusen, Bayern cruise to win |url=http://www.espnfc.com/german-bundesliga/story/2752730/javier-hernandez-hat-trick;-bayern-munich-defeat-ingolstadt |website=ESPN FC |accessdate=12 December 2015}}</ref> He would again be named Bundesliga Player of the Month for December.<ref>{{cite web |title=Javier Hernandez again named Bundesliga player of the month |url=http://www.espnfc.com/german-bundesliga/story/2775453/javier-hernandez-again-named-bundesliga-player-of-the-month |website=ESPN FC |date=30 December 2015 |accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref>
On 30 January 2016, in Bayer's second match after the winter break, Hernández scored twice in a 3–0 defeat of [[Hannover 96]] to register his 20th and 21st goals of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vavel.com/en/international-football/germany-bundesliga/597793-bayer-leverkusen-hannover-96.html |title=Bayer Leverkusen 3–0 Hannover 96: Hernandez double downs Hannover |date=30 January 2016 |website=Vavel}}</ref> Two days later, he was named for the third time Bundesliga Player of the Month.<ref>{{cite news |title=JANUARY PLAYER OF THE MONTH: JAVIER 'CHICHARITO' HERNANDEZ |url=http://www.bundesliga.com/en/news/Bundesliga/blmd19n-january-player-of-the-month-candidates-chicharito-aubameyang-lewandowski-pizarro.jsp |publisher=Bundesliga |date=1 February 2016 |accessdate=6 February 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== Hernández scored and provided an assist in Leverkusen's 2–1 win over [[SC Hauenstein]] in the first round of the [[2016–17 DFB-Pokal|DFB-Pokal]] on 21 August 2016.<ref>{{cite news |title=SC Hauenstein 1–2 Bayer Leverkusen |url=http://www.espnfc.com/match?gameId=452454 |website=ESPN FC |publisher=ESPN |date=21 August 2016 |accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref> Two days later, it was reported that Hernández would miss Bayer's opening match of the [[2016–17 Bundesliga|season]] against [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]] after sustaining a broken hand.<ref>{{cite news |title=Javier Hernandez to miss Bayer Leverkusen's Bundesliga opener after falling down stairs |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11891/10548702/javier-hernandez-to-miss-bayer-leverkusen-bundesliga-opener-after-falling-down-stairs |publisher=Sky Sports |date=23 August 2016 |accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref> On 17 September, Hernández scored his first goal of the Bundesliga season at [[Eintracht Frankfurt]], however he missed a chance to equalize late from the penalty spot in the 2–1 loss.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/chicharito-goes-from-bayer-leverkusen-hero-to-goat-as-bayer-leverkusen-lose-091716 |title=Chicharito goes from Bayer Leverkusen hero to goat as Bayer Leverkusen lose |publisher=FOX Sports |first=Ryan |last=Rosenblatt |accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> The following week at [[FSV Mainz 05]], Hernández collected a [[Hat-trick#perfect hat-trick|perfect hat-trick]] that included a stoppage time winner, the third hat trick of the [[2016–17 Bundesliga|Bundesliga season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2016/9/24/13041434/chicharito-hat-trick-bayer-leverkusen-mainz |title='Chicharito' Javier Hernandez completes hat trick with stoppage time winner for Bayer Leverkusen |website=SB Nation |first=Kevin |last=McCauley |accessdate=24 September 2016}}</ref> He was later named Bundesliga Player of the Month for September.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chicharito voted September Player of the Month! |url=http://www.bundesliga.com/en/news/Bundesliga/blmd6v-september-player-of-the-month-vote.jsp |publisher=Bundesliga |accessdate=30 September 2016}}</ref>
On 28 January 2017, Hernández scored Bayer Leverkusen's second goal in the 2–3 loss to Borussia Mönchengladbach, ending his eleven-match scoreless streak.<ref>{{cite web |last=Sayer |first=Brandon |title=Bayer 04 Leverkusen 2–3 Borussia Monchengladbach: Foals produce stunning second half comeback to give Hecking perfect start |url=https://www.vavel.com/en/international-football/germany-bundesliga/748266-bayer-04-leverkusen-2-3-borussia-monchengladbach.html |website=Vavel |accessdate=28 January 2016}}</ref> On 21 February, following the match against [[Atlético Madrid]], Hernández became the Mexican player with the most appearances in the Champions League with 47, surpassing [[Rafael Márquez]]'s previous record of 46 appearances.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chicharito, el mexicano con más partidos en Champions League |url=https://www.goal.com/s/es-co/news/4573/internacional/2017/02/21/32929942/chicharito-el-mexicano-con-más-partidos-en-champions-league |website=Goal.com |language=Spanish |accessdate=21 February 2017}}</ref>
===West Ham United=== ====2017–18 season==== On 24 July 2017, Hernández joined English club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] for an undisclosed fee, reported to be around £16 million, signing a three-year contract.<ref>{{cite news |title=Javier Hernandez: West Ham sign striker from Bayer Leverkusen for £16m |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40669333 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 July 2017 |accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Javier Hernandez completes transfer to West Ham United |url=https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2017/july/24-july/javier-hernandez-completes-transfer-west-ham-united |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref> He made his debut for the West Ham on 13 August, playing all 90 minutes in the 4–0 defeat against his former club Manchester United at Old Trafford.<ref>{{cite news |last=Jurejko |first=Jonathan |title=Manchester United 4–0 West Ham |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40841358 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=13 August 2017}}</ref> The following week, Hernández scored his first two goals for West Ham in the 3–2 loss to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Chapman |first=Caroline |title=Southampton 3–2 West Ham |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40908330 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 August 2017}}</ref>
In November, Hernández sustained a hamstring injury while on international duty with Mexico, and it was reported that he would be ruled out from activity for up to two weeks.<ref>{{cite web |title=Report: Chicharito Could Miss Two West Ham Games With Hamstring Injury |url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2017/11/15/javier-hernandez-could-miss-west-hams-next-two-matches-following-hamstring-injury |website=Sports Illustrated |accessdate=15 November 2017}}</ref> Following the sacking of [[Slaven Bilić]] and the appointment of David Moyes as manager, there were fears Hernández would be excluded at West Ham as he was at Manchester United. In response, Moyes referred to him as a "top goalscorer," and "a brilliant finisher."<ref>{{cite news |last=Burnton |first=Simon |date=11 November 2017 |title=David Moyes assures Javier Hernández he has a future at West Ham |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/nov/11/david-moyes-javier-hernandez-future-west-ham |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> During the winter transfer window there were reports Hernández would exit the club after only six months, being linked with a move to Turkish club [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]] as well as a possible return to Manchster United.<ref>{{cite web |title=Transfer report: West Ham striker Javier Hernandez in talks with Turkish champions Besiktas |url=https://talksport.com/football/transfer-report-west-ham-striker-javier-hernandez-talks-turkish-champions-besiktas |publisher=talkSport |accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref> On 20 January 2018, he came off the bench to score the equalizing goal for West Ham in their 1–1 league draw against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]], scoring his first goal since October.<ref>{{cite news |title=West Ham 1–1 Bournemouth: Hernandez scores first time since October to cancel out Fraser strike |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/west-ham-bournemouth-live-stream-11882059 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> Following the match Moyes praised Hernández's performance, saying "we needed him today."<ref>{{cite web |title='We needed him today' – Moyes tackles Chicharito transfer talk after goal against Bourenmouth |url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/we-needed-him-today-moyes-tackles-chicharito-transfer-talk-after-/bvfotve81i2119iy0k06dphno |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> On 8 April, in a league match against Chelsea, he scored a 73rd-minute goal to make the score 1–1, marking the ninth time he has scored against the club.<ref>{{cite web |title=Javier Hernandez can't explain fine goal scoring record against Chelsea |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/west-ham-united/story/3449175/javier-hernandez-cant-explain-fine-goal-scoring-record-against-chelsea |publisher=ESPN |date=8 April 2018 |accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref>
====2018–19 season==== On 28 August 2018, Hernández scored West Ham's third goal in injury time of a 3–1 victory over [[AFC Wimbledon]] in the second round of the [[2018–19 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |title=AFC Wimbledon 1–3 West Ham: Hammers turn it on in second half against 10-man Dons |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/afc-wdon-vs-west-ham/401643 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=28 August 2018 |accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref> In September, West Ham manager [[Manuel Pellegrini]] declared that Hernández was suffering from [[glandular fever]], causing him to miss out various matches.<ref>{{cite web |title=Pellegrini: "Chicharito está enfermo" |url=https://www.whufc.com/es/noticias/2018/september/14-september/pellegrini-chicharito-esta-enfermo |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |language=Spanish |date=14 September 2018 |accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> He would recover and return to training in October.<ref>{{cite web |title=Javier 'Chicharito' Hernandez back training with West Ham after fever |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/west-ham-united/story/3657268/javier-chicharito-hernandez-back-training-with-west-ham-after-fever |first=Tom |last=Marshall |publisher=ESPN |date=4 October 2018 |accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> On 3 November, he scored his first Premier League goal of the [[2018–19 Premier League|season]] in West Ham's 4–2 victory over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Bullin |first=Matt |date=3 November 2018 |title=West Ham 4–2 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/46000541 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref>
On 22 February 2019, Hernández scored the equalizing goal in West Ham’s eventual 3–1 win over Fulham; on initial viewing, it looked like he had headed the ball in from a yard to score, however replays of the goal appeared to show the ball rebound off of Hernández’s arm to put the ball into the net.<ref>{{cite news |last=Hafez |first=Shamoon |date=22 February 2019 |title=West Ham 3–1 Fulham |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/47248479 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 February 2019}}</ref> It was also his 50th career Premier League goal, becoming the first Mexican to reach the milestone.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chicharito reaches 50th career Premier League goals with strike against Fulham |url=https://www.goal.com/en-us/news/chicharito-reaches-50-premier-league-goals-with-strike/118bbcc9a0p4h10op262diqhci |website=Goal.com |accessdate=22 February 2019}}</ref> He would get on the scoresheet again on 16 March, coming on as a second-half substitute and scoring twice—including the stoppage-time winner—to secure a 4–3 league victory over [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Javier Hernández the hero as West Ham beat Huddersfield in seven-goal thriller |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2019/mar/16/west-ham-huddersfield-town-premier-league-match-report |work=The Guardian |accessdate=16 March 2019}}</ref>
==International career== ===Mexico under-20=== Hernández was one of the 21 players called up to the [[Mexico national under-20 football team|Mexican under-20 national team]] for the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in Canada; he came in as a late substitute in the opening game against Gambia and scored Mexico's 3–0 goal.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u20worldcup/canada2007/matches/round=249401/match=58859/index.html |title=FIFA U-20 World Cup archive – FIFA |last=FIFA.com}}</ref>
===Mexico national team=== [[Image:Chicharito.JPG|thumb|upright|Hernández playing for [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] in 2010]]
On 30 September 2009, Hernández made his debut for [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] against [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]], where he made an assist in a 2–1 loss.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mexico 1–2 Colombia |url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/seleccion-mexicana/ficha.php?id_partido=26917 |website=Medio Tiempo |accessdate=30 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210171917/http://www.mediotiempo.com/seleccion-mexicana/ficha.php?id_partido=26917 |archivedate=10 February 2012}}</ref> On 24 February 2010, Hernández scored two goals against [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia]] and had an assist for [[Braulio Luna]]'s goal. On 3 March, Hernández scored a header against [[New Zealand national football team|New Zealand]], giving Mexico the lead in a 2–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news |title=Soccer: Gutsy All Whites fall to fiery Mexico |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/all-whites/news/article.cfm?c_id=117&objectid=10629874&pnum=2 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120525034356/http://www.nzherald.co.nz/all-whites/news/article.cfm?c_id=117&objectid=10629874&pnum=2 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 May 2012 |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |publisher=APN Holdings NZ |date=4 March 2010 |accessdate=6 March 2010}}</ref> On 17 March, Hernández scored his fourth international goal to give Mexico a 2–1 victory over [[North Korea national football team|North Korea]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico 2–1 North Korea: Hernandez Strikes Again |url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/468/internationals/2010/03/18/1838270/mexico-2-1-north-korea-hernandez-strikes-again |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=18 March 2010}}</ref> On 26 May, he scored a consolation header against the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] in a 2–1 loss.<ref>{{cite news |title=Netherlands 2–1 Mexico |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=289197&cc=5739 |website=ESPN Soccernet |date=26 May 2010 |accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref> On 30 May, Hernández scored yet again, netting twice in a 5–1 victory over [[Gambia national football team|Gambia]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico 5–1 Gambia |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?cc=5739&id=292626 |website=ESPN Soccernet |date=30 May 2010 |accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref>
====2010 FIFA World Cup==== On 11 June, Hernández made his [[FIFA World Cup]] debut during the opening game of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 tournament]] against [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]] in a 1–1 draw, coming on in the 73rd minute to replace [[Guillermo Franco]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Jonathan |last=Stevenson |title=South Africa 1–1 Mexico |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_01 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 June 2010 |accessdate=11 June 2010}}</ref> On 17 June, Hernández again came off the bench and this time scored his first ever World Cup goal, netting the first in a 2–0 victory over [[France national football team|France]] by springing the offside trap, latching onto a through ball from [[Rafael Márquez]], sidestepping [[Hugo Lloris]] and sidefooting into the net.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico subs shoot down France |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round=249722/match=300061451/summary.html |publisher=FIFA |date=17 June 2010 |accessdate=3 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902040900/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round%3D249722/match%3D300061451/summary.html |archivedate=2 September 2011 |df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=Dawkes |title=France 0–2 Mexico |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_20 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 June 2010 |accessdate=17 June 2010}}</ref> By scoring he emulated his grandfather, [[Tomás Balcázar]], who scored against France in the 1954 World Cup.<ref>{{cite web |first=Steve |last=Bartram |title=Chicharito steals the show |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2010/Jun/Chicharito-steals-the-show.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=17 June 2010 |accessdate=3 July 2010}}</ref> He was elected as [[man of the match]].<ref>{{cite web |title=France-Mexico |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round=249722/match=300061451/index.html |publisher=FIFA |date=17 June 2010 |accessdate=3 July 2010}}</ref> On 27 June, Hernández made his first start at a World Cup and netted his second goal of the World Cup, by turning [[Martín Demichelis]] on the edge of the box before sending a left-foot shot into the roof of the net,<ref>{{cite web |title=Tevez shines as Argentina oust Mexico |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round=249717/match=300061502/summary.html |publisher=FIFA |date=27 June 2010 |accessdate=3 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101211170356/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/matches/round%3D249717/match%3D300061502/summary.html |archivedate=11 December 2010 |df=}}</ref> in Mexico's 3–1 loss against [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] in the round of 16.<ref>{{cite news |first=Paul |last=Fletcher |title=Argentina 3–1 Mexico |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_52 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 June 2010 |accessdate=27 June 2010}}</ref> FIFA's statistical analysis showed that Hernández was the quickest player in World Cup 2010, reaching a top speed of 32.15 km/h.<ref>{{cite web |title=Statistical stars from the group stage |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/statistics/news/newsid=1259849/ |publisher=FIFA |date=26 June 2010 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402072829/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/southafrica2010/statistics/news/newsid%3D1259849/ |archivedate=2 April 2011 |df=}}</ref>
====Post World Cup friendlies==== Hernández scored another goal in his first match for Mexico since the World Cup, in a friendly against world champions [[Spain national football team|Spain]] on 11 August 2010. He scored after just 12 minutes of the match, but [[David Silva]] equalised for Spain in the last minute of play to claim a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite news |title=Silva salvages draw for Spain |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=290887&cc=5739&league=FIFA.FRIENDLY |website=ESPN Soccernet |date=11 August 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2010}}</ref> Hernández scored his and Mexico's first international goal of 2011 as he opened the scoring in a 2–0 win over [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] on 9 February.<ref>{{cite news |language=Spanish |first=Sergio |last=Guzmán |title=México 2–0 Bosnia-Herzegovina... Debut esperanzador |url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/ficha.php?id_partido=34079 |website=Medio Tiempo |date=9 February 2011 |accessdate=9 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714065245/http://www.mediotiempo.com/ficha.php?id_partido=34079 |archivedate=14 July 2011}}</ref> On 26 March, Hernández scored two goals in an international friendly against [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]]. He first connected with a pass from [[Pablo Barrera]] in the sixth minute of the match, before scoring off a low cross in the 29th minute, three minutes after teammate [[Andrés Guardado]] had made the score 2–0. He exited to a standing ovation in the 65th minute.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hernandez stars for Mexico |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/news/newsid=1406971.html |publisher=FIFA |date=27 March 2011 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref>
====2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup==== On 5 June 2011, he scored a hat-trick, the first in his career, in a 5–0 win against [[El Salvador national football team|El Salvador]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Hernandez stars for Mexico |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/jun/06/javier-hernandez-hat-trick-mexico |location=UK |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 June 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> On 9 June 2011, he scored two goals, in the 36th and 76th minutes against [[Cuba national football team|Cuba]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Hernandez strikes Gold |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2011/Jun/Hernandez-strikes-again.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=10 June 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref> On 18 June 2011, Hernández scored the winner in a 2–1 win over [[Guatemala national football team|Guatemala]] to send Mexico to the semi-finals.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hernandez fires Mexico through |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2011/Jun/hernandez-puts-mexico-in-gold-cup-semifinals.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=19 June 2011 |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref> On 22 June 2011, he helped Mexico reach the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup Final|Gold Cup Final]] after a 2–0 win over [[Honduras national football team|Honduras]] in [[Overtime (sports)|extra-time]], where he scored Mexico's second goal in the 99th minute. Hernández was the Gold Cup's top scorer with seven goals and was named the most valuable player of the tournament, in addition to helping his team to a 4–2 victory in the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup Final|Final]] against the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]].<ref name="manutd1">{{cite news |title=Chicharito lifts Gold Cup |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2011/Jun/Chicha-and-Mexico-lift-Gold-Cup.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=26 June 2011 |accessdate=26 June 2011}}</ref>
====2013 FIFA Confederations Cup==== Hernández was selected in Mexico's squad for the [[2013 FIFA Confederations Cup]]. On 16 June, he scored from a penalty kick in the team's opening match, a 2–1 defeat to [[Italy national football team|Italy]] at the [[Estádio do Maracanã]]. In the final group match, Hernández scored both goals as ''El Tri'' defeated Asian champions [[Japan national football team|Japan]] 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22916862 |title=Japan 1–2 Mexico |date=22 June 2013 |publisher=BBC}}</ref>
====2014 FIFA World Cup==== Hernández scored five times for Mexico during [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)|qualification]] for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]. On 23 June, Hernández scored Mexico's third goal against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] in their 3–1 victory at [[Arena Pernambuco]] to qualify the team for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Round of 16|round of 16]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Mexico beat Croatia to spark Recife fiesta |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/round=255931/match=300186452/match-report.html?preferredPlatform=desktop |publisher=FIFA |access-date=23 June 2014}}</ref>
====2015 CONCACAF Gold Cup==== On 1 July 2015, Hernández sustained a broken collar bone during a friendly match against Honduras, ruling him out of the [[2015 CONCACAF Gold Cup]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Javier Hernandez injury a cruel setback to the striker and Mexico |url=http://www.espnfc.us/team/mexico/203/blog/post/2510656/javier-hernandez-injury-a-cruel-setback-mexico-gold-cup |website=ESPN FC |date=2 July 2015}}</ref> which Mexico went on to win.{{citation needed|date=December 2018}}
====2016–2017: Copa América Centenario and all-time Mexico top scorer==== [[File:2017 Confederation Cup - MEXNZL - Ochoa and Chicharito.jpg|thumb|Hernández on the bench with teammate [[Guillermo Ochoa]] at the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]]|alt=|left|192x192px]] Hernández was included in Mexico's 23-man squad that would participate in the [[Copa América Centenario]] tournament. On 5 June 2016, he played 83 minutes in the 3–1 victory over [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]],<ref>{{cite news |last=Baxter |first=Kevin |title=Mexico scores twice late to turn back Uruguay, 3–1, in Copa America group game |url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/soccer/la-sp-mexico-uruguay-20160605-snap-story.html |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |access-date=5 June 2016}}</ref> and scored the first goal in Mexico's 2–0 win over [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]]. The goal took Hernández's tally to 45, one goal shy of tying [[Jared Borgetti]]'s national team record.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico through to Copa América quarters after seeing off Jamaica |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/10/mexico-beats-jamaica-chicharito-quarter-finals |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=9 June 2016}}</ref>
On 27 May 2017, Hernández became Mexico's all-time top goalscorer with 47 goals when he scored in a friendly against Croatia.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gonzalez |first1=Roger |title=Chicharito becomes all time leading goalscorer for mexico |url=http://www.cbssports.com/soccer/news/watch-chicharito-becomes-all-time-leading-goal-scorer-in-mexico-soccer-team-history/ |website=CBS Sports |accessdate=31 May 2017}}</ref>
Hernández was included in the national squad that would play in the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup|FIFA Confederations Cup]] in Russia. He scored Mexico's first goal in an eventual 2–2 draw against [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] on 18 June, scoring a low header from a [[Carlos Vela]] cross.<ref>{{cite news |title=Portugal 2–2 Mexico |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40265185 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=18 June 2017}}</ref>
====2018 FIFA World Cup==== Hernández scored three times for Mexico during [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)|qualification]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]. He was in the starting lineup in Mexico's first World Cup game against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] at the [[Luzhniki Stadium]] in Moscow and made an assist to [[Hirving Lozano]] to go on to win the match 1–0.<ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2018: Javier Hernandez breaks down in tears at full-time of win for Mexico against Germany |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/world-cup-2018/6556292/world-cup-2018-javier-hernandez-tears-mexico-1-0-germany/ |newspaper=The Sun |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> In the second group game Hernández scored Mexico's second goal, his 50th international goal, in their 2–1 win over [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico in dominant win over South Korea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44439169 |publisher=BBC |date=23 June 2018}}</ref> He also became the joint-highest scoring Mexican player at the World Cup with four goals, along with [[Luis Hernández (footballer)|Luis Hernández]],<ref>{{cite news |last=Bagchi |first=Rob |title=Mexico edge towards knockout round at World Cup after Carlos Vela and Javier Hernandez all but end South Korea hopes |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/world-cup/2018/06/23/world-cup-2018-south-korea-vs-mexico-live-score-latest-updates/ |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> as well as the third Mexican player to score in three World Cups.<ref>{{cite web |title=ESPN Stats & Info on Twitter |url=https://mobile.twitter.com/ESPNStatsInfo/status/1010560967799816192?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet |accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> He would go on to start in all group stage matches, including the [[2018 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Brazil vs Mexico|round-of-16 loss]] against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Javier HERNANDEZ |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/players/player/228599/ |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=22 October 2018}}</ref>
==Style of play== A clinical goalscorer, Hernández has been described as a "goal-poacher", due to a number of his goals being scored from close-range.<ref>{{cite news |title=Javier Hernández and the best tap-in merchants |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-united/8385881/Javier-Hernandez-and-the-best-ever-tap-in-merchants.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref><ref name="tf9">{{cite web |title=The False 9: Javier Hernandez – Rebirth of the Poacher? |url=http://www.thefalse9.com/2011/06/javier-hernandez-modern-day-poacher-in.html |website=The False 9 |access-date=4 June 2011}}</ref> His movement off the ball, pace, and ability to find space inside the box has also been praised.<ref name="tf9" /><ref>{{cite news |last=Taylor |first=Daniel |date=16 March 2011 |title=Sir Alex Ferguson hails form of Javier Hernández for Manchester United |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/mar/16/alex-ferguson-javier-hernandez-manchester-united |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=30 January 2016}}</ref> He has been described as one of the few players who seem capable of appearing behind a defender's back to knock in the ball from two yards, with his playing style being compared to that of German striker [[Miroslav Klose]].<ref name="Christenson">{{cite news |last=Christenson |first=Marcus |title=Javier Hernández and the underrated art of the clinical goalscorer |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/nov/02/javier-hernandez-goalscorer-bayer-leverkusen-tottenham-champions-league-miroslav-klose |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=2 November 2016}}</ref>
[[Rudi Völler]], sporting director of Bayer Leverkusen, has praised Hernández for his keen positioning in front of goal, saying: "he certainly doesn't win every tackle but he has an incredible sense of where the ball will end up".<ref name="Christenson" /> Former Manchester United manager [[Alex Ferguson|Sir Alex Ferguson]] described Hernández as two-footed, very quick, in possession of a good spring, and a natural goalscorer. Ferguson also said Hernández's style reminds him of former United striker [[Ole Gunnar Solskjær]] – the so-called "baby-faced assassin" who scored the injury time winner against Bayern Munich in United's 1999 Champions League triumph.<ref>[http://www.tipsbladet.dk/nyhed/premier-league/javier-hernandez-bliver-den-nye-solskjaer Javier Hernandez bliver den nye Solskjær] {{dk icon}} Tipsbladet, 1 August 2010</ref> Hernández's former teammate [[Jesús Padilla]] described him as "amazing in the air" despite his height.<ref name="nyt" /> Due to his small stature, he is extremely quick and agile, also possessing good technique.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.us/story/2590455/javier-hernandez-signs-for-bayer-leverkusen-from-man-united |title=Javier Hernandez signs for Bayer Leverkusen from Manchester United |publisher=ESPN FC |author1=Richard Jolly |date=31 August 2015|access-date=29 January 2016}}</ref>
In a May 2016 interview with ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', Hernández commented on his abilities inside the penalty area, describing the intuition he has in knowing where an impending cross will fall from a teammate and outsmarting opposing defenders.<ref>{{cite web |title=Inside the churning mind of Mexico's Javier 'Chicharito' Hernandez |url=https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2016/05/31/chicharito-mexico-javier-hernandez-bayer-leverkusen |website=Sports Illustrated |access-date=31 May 2016}}</ref>
Former Mexico national team coach [[Juan Carlos Osorio]] described Hernández as having "a knack for the goal. Sometimes it seems like every rebound or every deflection goes into his path. Another thing is he doesn't dwell on a missed opportunity. He always looks forward to the next one. He has good ability in the air. He has good pace, and he makes those diagonal runs starting from the first defender in behind the second one. He also has the willingness to work defensively."<ref>{{cite web |title=Masters of Modern Soccer: Chicharito and the Art of Mexico's Synchronization |url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2018/05/03/chicharito-javier-hernandez-mexico-juan-carlos-osorio-masters-modern-soccer |website=Sports Illustrated |first=Grant |last=Wahl |date=3 May 2018 |accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== [[File:Javier Hernandez praying.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Hernández conducting his pre-match prayer before a match against [[Cardiff City]] in November 2013]] Hernández is the son of [[Javier Hernández Gutiérrez]], who played for three clubs in Mexico and was a member of the [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] squad at the [[1986 FIFA World Cup]].<ref name="gtnh">{{cite web |first1=James |last1=Tuck |first2=Geoff |last2=Berkeley |title=Get to know... Hernandez |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Features/2010/Apr/Get-to-know-Hernandez.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=8 April 2010 |accessdate=15 June 2010}}</ref> Hernández Gutiérrez quit his job as manager of Guadalajara's reserve side in order to watch Hernández play in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/world-cup/story/_/id/792607/ce/uk/?cc=4716&ver=global |title=Hernandez's father quits to see him play |date=4 June 2010 |website=ESPN Soccernet |accessdate=30 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607062908/http://soccernet.espn.go.com/world-cup/story/_/id/792607/ce/uk/?cc=4716&ver=global |archivedate=7 June 2010 |df=}}</ref> Hernández is also the grandson of [[Tomás Balcázar]], who also played for Guadalajara and played for the national side in the [[1954 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Billy |last=Witz |title=For World Cup, Javier Hernández Could Be Mexico's Next Big Thing |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/02/sports/soccer/02soccer.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=1 April 2010}}</ref>
On 26 May 2012, Hernández became the Mexican ambassador for [[UNICEF]], making him the third Mexican to serve this position, following [[César Costa]] and [[Julieta Venegas]] in 2004 and 2009 respectively.<ref name=embajador>{{cite news |title=Chicharito es embajador de UNICEF |url=http://eleconomista.com.mx/deportes/2012/05/26/chicharito-embajador-unicef |accessdate=27 May 2012 |newspaper=El Economista |date=26 May 2012 |language=Spanish}}</ref> As ambassador, he will participate in a number of activities to encourage children and teenagers to not abandon their education.<ref name=embajador/> He was commemorated in a news conference, where he said he felt "proud and committed".<ref name=espnunicef>{{cite news |last=Lecanda |first=León |title=Chicharito es embajador de Unicef |url=http://espndeportes.espn.go.com/news/story?id=1532364&s=mundial&type=story |accessdate=27 May 2012 |publisher=ESPN |date=26 May 2012 |language=Spanish}}</ref>
Hernández is a devout [[Roman Catholic]]. He is well known for his pre-game ritual where he gets on his knees and prays which he performs before most games.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://theredevilspot.blogspot.com/2010/11/chicharito-to-ditch-his-pre-match.html |title=Chicharito to ditch his pre-match Catholic prayer at Ibrox |publisher=theredevilspot.blogspot |date=24 November 2010 |accessdate=13 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.catholicvote.org/professional-soccer-player-facing-persecution-for-pre-game-catholic-prayer/comment-page-1/ |title=Professional Soccer Player Facing Persicution For Pre-Game Catholic Prayer |publisher=CV (Catholic Voice) |accessdate=13 June 2014 |author=Thomas Peters |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141111230345/https://www.catholicvote.org/professional-soccer-player-facing-persecution-for-pre-game-catholic-prayer/comment-page-1/ |archivedate=11 November 2014 |df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2011/5/26/2191435/champions-league-2011-barcelona-manchester-united-javier-hernandez-chicharito-manchester-united |title=UEFA Champions League Final 2011: Manchester United's Chicharito Is The Story in North America – FMF State of Mind |publisher=SB Nation |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=14 June 2014 |author=Kevin McCauley}}</ref> On 27 June 2013, [[EA Sports]] announced that they had featured Hernández on the North American cover of ''[[FIFA 14]]'', alongside global cover star [[Lionel Messi]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.easports.com/fifa/news-updates-gameplay/article/fifa-14-north-america-box-art |title=FIFA 14 – North America Cover Reveal |publisher=EA Sports |date=27 June 2013 |accessdate=28 June 2013}}</ref>
In January 2019, Hernández and his girlfriend Sarah Kohan, an Australian model and travel blogger, announced on Instagram that they were expecting their first child.<ref>{{cite news|title=Javier 'Chicharito' Hernández anuncia que será padre|url=http://www.milenio.com/deportes/extra-cancha/javier-chicharito-hernandez-anuncia-que-sera-padre|accessdate=14 January 2019 |newspaper=Milenio|date=14 January 2019|language=Spanish}}</ref>
===Nickname=== Hernández is commonly known as ''Chicharito'', meaning ''little [[pea]]'' in Spanish, and wears the name on his shirt.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bundesliga.com/en/news/Bundesliga/ten-things-about-javier-hernandez.jsp |title=Ten things about Mexico's most famous export Javier 'Chicharito' Hernandez |publisher=Bundesliga |accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref> This is due to his father, Javier Hernández Gutiérrez, being nicknamed ''Chícharo'' (''pea'') because of his [[Eye color#Green|green eyes]].<ref>[http://bleacherreport.com/articles/375453-javier-chicharito-hernandez-manchester-united-new-prodigy Javier "Chicharito" Hernandez: Manchester United New Prodigy] Bleacher Report, 8 April 2010</ref>

'''Samir Nasri''' (born 26 June 1987) is a French professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2018/december/31-december/hammers-sign-premier-league-title-winner-samir-nasri#PZ9BP8w8UUAbE9Xb.99 |title=Hammers sign Premier League title winner Samir Nasri|author=<!--Not stated--> |date=31 December 2018 |website=whufc.com |publisher=West Ham United |access-date=31 December 2018 |quote=}}</ref> He primarily plays as an [[attacking midfielder]] and a [[Winger (association football)|winger]], although he has also been deployed in [[Centre midfielder|central midfield]]. He was suspended from football for eighteen months until January 2019 following a [[doping (sport)|doping]] violation.
Nasri is known for his dribbling, ball control and passing ability.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/aug/17/arsenalnasriwestbrom|title=Nasri makes an instant impact |work=The Guardian |date=17 August 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | location=London| first=Amy| last=Lawrence}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2010/mar/13/samir-nasri-dribbling-stanley-matthews|title=Samir Nasri's dribbling makes him a throwback to days of Matthews|work=The Guardian |date=13 March 2010 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | location=London| first=David| last=Lacey}}</ref> He is described as a player whose "vision and imagination make him an unpredictable opponent".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/player/_/id/43531/Samir-Nasri?cc=5901|title=Samir Nasri ESPN Bio |publisher=[[ESPN]]|date= |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref> His playing style, ability and cultural background have drawn comparisons to French legend [[Zinedine Zidane]].<ref name="nasri_zidane">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/mar/23/europeanfootball.marseille|title=Samir Nasri: the new Zidane?|work=The Guardian |date=23 March 2007 |accessdate=3 June 2010 | location=London| first=Paul| last=Doyle}}</ref><ref name="nasri_interview">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1362722/Samir-Nasri-Arsenal-star-argument-Thierry-Henry-problems-William-Gallas.html|title=Nasri: We had an argument but Thierry was cool – then I had a problem with Gallas |date=4 March 2011 |work=Daily Mail |location=UK|accessdate=19 March 2011 |first=Matt |last=Lawton}}</ref>
Nasri began his football career playing for local youth clubs in his hometown [[Marseille]]. At age nine, he joined professional club [[Olympique de Marseille]] and spent the next seven years developing in the club's youth academy at [[Centre d'entraînement Robert Louis-Dreyfus|La Commanderie]], the club's training centre. In the [[2004–05 Ligue 1|2004–05 season]], he made his professional debut in September 2004 at age 17 against [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]]. In the [[2005–06 Ligue 1|following season]], he became a regular starter in the team and also participated in [[UEFA|European competition]] for the first time after playing in the [[2005–06 UEFA Cup|2005–06 edition]] of the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]]. In the [[2006–07 Ligue 1|2006–07 campaign]], Nasri won the [[National Union of Professional Footballers]] (UNFP) [[Trophées UNFP du football#Young Player of the Year|Young Player of the Year]] award and was also named to the [[Trophées UNFP du football#Team of the Year|Team of the Year]]. He finished his career with Marseille amassing over 160 appearances. He played in the teams that reached back-to-back [[Coupe de France]] finals in [[2006 Coupe de France Final|2006]] and [[2007 Coupe de France Final|2007]].
In June 2008, Nasri joined [[Premier League]] club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on a four-year contract. He reached prominence with the team in his third season winning the [[Professional Footballers' Association]] (PFA) Fans' Player of the Month award on three occasions and being named to the association's [[PFA Team of the Year|Team of the Year]]. In December 2010, he was named the [[France Football#French Player of the Year|French Player of the Year]] for his performances during the calendar year.<ref name="nasri_player">{{cite web |url=http://www.francefootball.fr/FF/breves2010/20101213_144746_nasri-numero-1-a-23-ans.html |title=Nasri, numéro 1 à 23 ans |work=[[France Football]] |date=13 December 2010 |accessdate=13 December 2010 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214104656/http://www.francefootball.fr/FF/breves2010/20101213_144746_nasri-numero-1-a-23-ans.html |archivedate=14 December 2010 }}</ref> In August 2011, after three seasons with Arsenal, Nasri joined [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on a four-year contract. In his first season with the club, he won his first major honour as a player as the club won the [[2011–12 Premier League]].
Nasri is a former [[France national youth football team|France youth international]] and has represented his nation at every level for which he was eligible. Prior to playing for the [[France national football team|senior team]], he played on the [[France national under-17 football team|under-17 team]] that won the [[2004 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]]. Nasri made his senior international debut in March 2007 in a friendly match against [[Austria national football team|Austria]]. Two months later, he scored his first senior international goal in a 1–0 [[UEFA Euro 2008 qualifying]] win over [[Georgia national football team|Georgia]]. Nasri has represented France at two major international tournaments: [[UEFA Euro 2008]] and [[UEFA Euro 2012|Euro 2012]].
== Personal life == Samir Nasri ({{lang-ar|سمير نصري}}) was born in [[Septèmes-les-Vallons]], a northern suburb of [[Marseille]], to French nationals of [[Algeria]]n descent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://septemesmonvillage.free.fr/septemois/samir-nasri%20.html|title=Le minot Prodige de Septèmes |publisher=[[Septèmes-les-Vallons]]|date= |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref><ref name="nasri_parents">{{cite news |url=http://www.liberation.fr/portrait/0101101885-petit-om-deviendra-grand|title=Petit OM deviendra grand |publisher=[[Septèmes-les-Vallons]]|date=11 May 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> His mother, Ouassila Ben Saïd, and father, Abdelhafid Nasri, were both born in France; his father being born and raised in Marseille, while his mother being from nearby [[Salon-de-Provence]].<ref name="nasri_parents"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rmcsport.fr/editorial/262422/nasri-un-bleu-made-in-om/|title=Nasri, un Bleu "made in OM" |publisher=[[Radio Monte Carlo|RMC Sport]]|date=2 June 2012 |accessdate=2 June 2012 | language = French }}</ref> Nasri's grandparents emigrated to France from Algeria.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.purepeople.com/article/samir-nasri-et-tatiana-golovin-si-demain-tatiana-m-apprenait-qu-elle-attend-un-enfant_a50649/1|title=Samir Nasri et Tatiana Golovin: "Si demain Tatiana m'apprenait qu'elle attend un enfant ..." |work=Pure People|date=24 February 2010 |accessdate=19 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> His mother is a [[housewife]] and his father previously worked as a [[bus driver]] before becoming his son's personal manager. At the start of his football career, Nasri initially played under his mother's surname, Ben Saïd, before switching to Nasri, his father's surname, following his selection to the [[France national under-16 football team|France under-16 team]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/bleus/actu/384113.shtml |title=Samir Nasri fête ses 20 ans |publisher=[[French Football Federation]] |date=26 June 2007 |accessdate=8 February 2012 | language = French }}</ref> He is the eldest of four children and is a non-practising Muslim.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lebuteur.com/international/actualites/samir-nasri-je-suis-musulman-non-pratiquant|title=Samir Nasri: "Je suis musulman, non pratiquant"|work=Le Buteur|date=5 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110308230635/http://www.lebuteur.com/international/actualites/samir-nasri-je-suis-musulman-non-pratiquant|archivedate=8 March 2011}}</ref> Nasri has a younger sister named Sonia and twin brothers named Walid and Malik.<ref name="nasri_parents"/> All four were raised in La Gavotte Peyret. After joining [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in England, Nasri settled in [[Hampstead]], a district of North London.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/samir-nasri-gunners-midfielder-is-streets-ahead-1625716.html|title=Samir Nasri: Gunners midfielder is streets ahead |work=The Independent |location=UK|date=19 February 2009 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref>
== Club career ==
=== Early career === While growing up in La Gavotte Peyret, Nasri grew an attraction to the sport of [[association football|football]] at a young age.<ref name="nasri_interview"/> He regularly played the sport on the [[street football|streets]] where he learned many of his skills. Upon noticing his prodigious talent, his parents signed him up to play with the local club in his hometown. Nasri spent one year playing with the club in La Gavotte Peyret before moving to Pennes Mirabeau in nearby [[Les Pennes-Mirabeau|Mirabeau]] at age seven. While playing with Pennes, Nasri was discovered by [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] scout Freddy Assolen, who had been informed of the player's talent through local [[word of mouth]].<ref name="nasri_parents"/><ref name="nasri_assolen">{{cite news|url=http://www.om.net/en/Saison/101002/Actualites/32981/Samir_Nasri_to_play_his_100th|title=Samir Nasri to play his 100th!|publisher=[[Olympique de Marseille]]|date=10 November 2007|accessdate=18 March 2011|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405021025/http://www.om.net/en/Saison/101002/Actualites/32981/Samir_Nasri_to_play_his_100th|archivedate=5 April 2012}}</ref> After noticing Nasri's skill in person, Assolen recruited the player to travel with a group of other young players to Italy to participate in a youth tournament where they would play against the youth academies of [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] and [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]]. Nasri impressed at the tournament and Assolen was jokingly told by a Milan scout that "he [Nasri] stays here, you leave him".<ref name="nasri_parents"/> After returning to France, Marseille officials organized a meeting with the player's father and the group agreed to allow Nasri insertion into the club's academy at the age of nine.
=== Olympique de Marseille ===
{{Quote box | width=30% | align=right | quote= "He could do everything with the ball: stepovers, dribbling, shooting with the right or the left. In fact, I wasn't even sure whether he was left or right-footed." |source= <small>Freddy Assolen, upon noticing Nasri's skill at the age of nine.<ref name="nasri_assolen"/> </small> }}
Upon entering the Marseille youth academy, Nasri quickly impressed. Upon moving to [[Bastide]], where the club's youth players reside, his style of play began to take shape. In 2007, Nasri admitted that the move to Bastide really helped his game, stating, "That's where I really started to progress. Training was different and the facilities are beautiful, all of which helps you work well."<ref name="nasri_assolen"/> As a result of his quick progression, Nasri was an integral part of every youth team he was a part of winning several trophies, such as the Championnat de Provence, Coupe de Provence, and the Ligue de la Méditerranée. After spending most of the 2003–04 season playing with the club's under-18 team, for the latter part of the season, the now 16-year-old Nasri was promoted to the club's reserve team in the [[Championnat de France amateur]], the fourth division of [[Football in France|French football]]. He appeared primarily as a substitute in a few matches during the campaign as the reserve team failed to rebound from its bad start to the season, which resulted in a 16th-place finish and relegation to the [[Championnat de France amateur 2]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stat2foot.com/mclubs/om20304.htm|title=Olympique Marseille Reserve Pro: Saison Football 2003/2004|work=Stat2Foot|date=|accessdate=18 March 2011|language=French|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617131754/http://www.stat2foot.com/mclubs/om20304.htm#|archive-date=17 June 2012|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
==== Debut season ==== Ahead of the [[2004–05 Ligue 1|2004–05 season]], several clubs were reported to be interested in signing Nasri, most notably English clubs [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11670_2337629,00.html|title=Gunners join Nasri hunt |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=31 May 2005 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref> In an effort to decrease the speculation, Nasri was offered a three-year professional contract by Marseille officials led by president [[Pape Diouf]] and manager [[José Anigo]]. On 13 August 2004, Nasri agreed to the contract. Marseille officials had been eager to sign Nasri to a contract in an attempt to not undergo a situation similar to the departure of [[Mathieu Flamini]], in which the player departed the club without Marseille receiving any compensation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11669_2323845,00.html|title=L'OM starlet in demand |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=14 January 2005 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref> As a result of his professional contract, Nasri was promoted to the senior team by Anigo and assigned the number 22 shirt. He began the season playing on the club's reserve team and appeared in four matches before earning a call up to the senior team in September 2004.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stat2foot.com/mclubs/om20405.htm|title=Olympique Marseille Reserve Pro: Saison Football 2004/2005|work=Stat2Foot|date=|accessdate=22 March 2011|language=French|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402031819/http://www.stat2foot.com/mclubs/om20405.htm#|archive-date=2 April 2012|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
Nasri made his professional debut on 12 September in a 2–0 league defeat to [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]], appearing as a substitute for [[Bruno Cheyrou]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/49233|title=Sochaux v. Marseille Match Report|publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=12 September 2004 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> On 17 October, he made his first professional start playing the entire match in a 1–1 draw with [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/48917|title=Marseille v. Saint-Étienne Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=17 October 2004 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> Nasri featured heavily within the team under Anigo and later [[Philippe Troussier]]. In the team's first match following the winter break, he scored his first professional goal in a 2–1 away victory over [[Lille OSC|Lille]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/49211|title=Lille v. Marseille Match Report|publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=11 January 2005 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> Nasri finished his rookie campaign with 25 total appearances, one goal and two assists.
==== 2005–06 season ====
[[File:Samir Nasri in Moscow.jpg|200px|upright|thumb|left|Nasri taking a corner during his time with Marseille.]]
The [[2005–06 Ligue 1|2005–06 season]] saw Marseille boosted by the arrival of attackers [[Franck Ribéry]] and [[Djibril Cissé]], the latter arriving after having a successful loan stint with the club the previous season. Nasri, who was now given a more prominent role within the team by new manager [[Jean Fernandez]], formed impressive partnerships with the two along with lead [[Striker (association football)|striker]] [[Mamadou Niang]].<ref name="nasri_assolen"/> He appeared in 49 total matches, which included appearances in both the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]] and the [[UEFA Intertoto Cup]]. Nasri made his European debut on 16 July 2005 in the first round of the [[2005 UEFA Intertoto Cup]] against Swiss club [[BSC Young Boys|Young Boys]]. Marseille won the first leg 3–2. In the second leg, Nasri scored his first European goal in a 2–1 win. Marseille ultimately won the competition after beating Spanish outfit [[Deportivo de La Coruña]] 5–3 on aggregate. In the league, Nasri appeared in 30 matches, 25 as a starter. He scored his only league goal of the season on 29 April 2007 in a 4–2 win over Sochaux.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/50817|title=Marseille v. Sochaux Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=11 January 2005 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> In the [[Coupe de France]], Nasri appeared in five matches as Marseille reached the final of the competition where the club faced ''[[Le Classique]]'' rivals [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]]. Nasri appeared as a substitute in the match as Marseille were defeated 2–1. Following the season, Nasri signed a two-year contract extension with the club until 2009.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11668_2343857,00.html|title=l'OM starlets sign on |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=2 August 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref>
==== 2006–07 season ==== Nasri began the [[2006–07 Ligue 1|2006–07 season]] playing under [[Albert Emon]], his fourth different manager in three years. Despite this, Marseille's now heightened popularity saw increased speculation from writers and supporters that the club would finally win its first league title since the [[1991–92 French Division 1|1991–92 season]]. Nasri began the season on a quick note scoring the second goal in the team's 3–1 win over Paris Saint-Germain in September 2006.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/50565|title=Paris Saint-Germain v. Marseille Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=10 September 2006 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> On 29 April 2007, Nasri scored a goal in Marseille's 4–2 hammering of Sochaux.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/50817|title=Marseille v. Sochaux Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=29 April 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> Marseille were due to face the same club in the [[2007 Coupe de France Final]] just days later and were, subsequently, heavy favorites as a result of the team's two-goal victory in the previous match. However, Sochaux recorded an upset victory defeating Marseille 5–4 on [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalties]] after the match ended 2–2 following extra time. On the final match day of the season, Nasri converted the only goal in a 1–0 win over [[CS Sedan Ardennes|Sedan]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/50846|title=Marseille v. Sedan Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=26 May 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> The victory secured 2nd place for Marseille and was the club's best finish since finishing runner-up to Bordeaux in the [[1998–99 French Division 1|1998–99 season]]. Nasri finished the season with a career-high 50 appearances, 37 of them in the league. For his efforts, he was awarded the [[National Union of Professional Footballers|UNFP]] [[Trophées UNFP du football#Young Player of the Year|Young Player of the Year]] award and named to the [[Trophées UNFP du football#Team of the Year|Team of the Year]].<ref name="nasri_honours">{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/samir-nasri-my-reasons-for-joining-arsenal|title=Samir Nasri – My reasons for joining Arsenal |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=11 July 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> Nasri was also voted the Club Player of the Year by supporters, receiving 62% of the votes ahead of the likes of Ribéry and Niang.<ref name="nasri_honours"/>
==== 2007–08 season ====
[[File:SamirNasri.jpg|175px|upright|thumb|right|Nasri with Marseille in 2008.]]
Similar to his previous three years at Marseille, Nasri began the new season under new management as the club was now being led by the Belgian [[Eric Gerets]]. Due to the departure of Ribéry to [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]], Gerets installed Nasri as the focal point of the attack and he responding by having his best season at the club. He appeared in 42 total matches scoring a career-high six goals and also assisting on a career-high 15 goals. Nasri formed partnerships in the midfield with winger [[Mathieu Valbuena]] and [[midfielders]] [[Lorik Cana]] and [[Benoît Cheyrou]] as Marseille boasted the third-best attack in the league behind champions [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] and [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]], who finished first and second in the league respectively. Initially, Nasri struggled during the infancy of the campaign due to dealing with the effects of a severely sprained ankle suffered in the pre-season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11810_2595419,00.html|title=L'OM relief at Nasri news |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=10 July 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref> He failed to score a goal or provide an assist in the team's first eight league matches. On 24 November 2007, he assisted on two goals in a 2–0 victory over [[FC Metz|Metz]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51412|title=Marseille v. Metz Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=24 November 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> Nasri closed out the fall season by assisting on the equalizing goal in a 2–2 draw with Bordeaux and making the final pass on the match-winning goal against [[Le Mans FC|Le Mans]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51671|title=Bordeaux v. Marseille Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=16 December 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51412|title=Marseille v. Le Mans Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=22 December 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref>
Following the winter break, Nasri's goal-scoring began to take form. In late January, he scored goals in back-to-back matches against [[AS Nancy|Nancy]] and [[Stade Malherbe Caen|Caen]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51469|title=Nancy v. Marseille Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=23 January 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51478|title=Marseille v. Caen Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=26 January 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> In European competition, Nasri participated in the [[UEFA Champions League]] for the first time in his career, however he failed to make an impact in the four group stage matches he appeared in. He missed the club's upset victory over Liverpool at [[Anfield]] due to dealing with a bout of [[meningitis]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11800_2754445,00.html|title=Nasri setback for Marseille |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=25 September 2007|accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11800_2845112,00.html|title=Nasri set for Marseille return |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=29 September 2007|accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season=2008/round=15105/match=301175/report=rp.html |title=Gerets enjoys dream start at Anfield |date=3 October 2007 |accessdate=16 February 2011 |publisher=[[UEFA]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116140030/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season=2008/round=15105/match=301175/report=rp.html |archivedate=16 January 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/search_index.php?page=detail_news&news_id=13356|title=Liverpool on the ropes as Marseille storm fortress Anfield |date=4 October 2007 |accessdate=16 February 2011 |work=The Financial Express}}</ref> Marseille ultimately finished the group in third place, which resulted in the team qualifying for the round of 32 of the UEFA Cup. The club was defeated in the round of 16 by [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]] despite being up 3–1 heading into the second leg. Of those three goals Marseille scored in the first leg, Nasri assisted on two of them. On 16 March 2008, Nasri scored a goal in a 3–3 draw with [[RC Lens|Lens]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51529|title=Lens v. Marseille Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=16 March 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> A month later, he scored the game-winning goal in a 2–1 victory over Metz.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51572|title=Metz v. Marseille Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=12 April 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> In his final match with Marseille, against [[RC Strasbourg Alsace|Strasbourg]], Nasri scored a goal and assisted on another in a 4–3 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51620 |title=Marseille v. Strasbourg Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=17 May 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318045451/http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51620 |archivedate=18 March 2012 }}</ref> Marseille finished the league campaign in third place, which resulted in the club qualifying for the UEFA Champions League for the second consecutive season. On 8 May 2008, with all the transfer speculation surrounding the player, Nasri surprised many by signing a three-year contract extension with the club until 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11800_3537838,00.html|title=Nasri pens l'OM extension |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=8 May 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref>
=== Arsenal ===
==== 2008–09 season ====
{{Quote box | width=30% | align=left | quote= "Samir is a student of football – he lives for the game. He loves training and watches game after game on TV. He uses things he has seen to help correct mistakes in his own game. When you genuinely love football this is what makes the difference." |source= <small>[[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] scout [[Gilles Grimandi]] on Nasri.<ref name="nasri_scout">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/9411158.stm |title=Gilles Grimandi profiles Manchester City's Samir Nasri |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref> </small> }}
One week later, despite signing a contract extension with Marseille, Nasri was linked with a move to [[Premier League]] club Arsenal. Arsenal manager [[Arsène Wenger]] had been tracking Nasri since watching him play at the [[2004 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]].<ref name="nasri_scout"/> It was later revealed that the contract extension Nasri signed with Marseille was simply protocol to allow Marseille to receive a higher transfer fee for the player.
