goals9 = 16 | years10 = 2015– | clubs10 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps10 = 104 | goals10 = 24 | club-update = 03:19, 17 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Michail Gregory Antonio''' (born 28 March 1990) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Left winger|winger]] for [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].
Antonio began his career at [[non-League football|non-League]] club [[Tooting & Mitcham United F.C.|Tooting & Mitcham United]] before going on to represent a number of [[English Football League|Football League]] clubs, including [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], [[Cheltenham Town F.C.|Cheltenham Town]], [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]], [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] and [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].
==Club career== ===Early career=== Antonio was born in [[Wandsworth]], London.<ref name=Hugman1011/> He started his career at Tooting & Mitcham United Juniors at the age of 12 and remained there for six seasons. The Juniors' team was independent from [[Tooting & Mitcham United F.C.|Tooting & Mitcham United]], whom he signed for at the age of 17 years. He made his debut for the club in an away match with [[Hendon F.C.|Hendon]] at the age of 17, scoring to level scores at 1–1.<ref name=FL>{{cite web |title=Career ladder: Michail Antonio |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/features/20130325/career-ladder-michail-antonio_2293307_3108828 |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref>
===Reading=== Antonio signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on 28 October 2008 for an undisclosed fee, signing a deal until 2010.<ref>{{cite news| title = Reading complete deal for Antonio| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/reading/7695368.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 28 October 2008| accessdate = 24 February 2009}}</ref><ref name="Bignall treble sinks Seagulls">{{cite web|title=Bignall treble sinks Seagulls |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1421751,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724083409/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~1421751%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archivedate=24 July 2011 |publisher=Reading F.C. |date=27 October 2008 |accessdate=24 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> He rejoined Tooting on a month-long loan spell on 9 January 2009,<ref name="Youngster loan move confirmed">{{cite web|title=Youngster loan move confirmed |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1514989,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090111150353/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~1514989%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archivedate=11 January 2009 |publisher=Reading F.C. |date=9 January 2009 |accessdate=24 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> with the loan extended for a further month on 11 February<ref>{{cite web|title=Winger loan deal extended |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1551180,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090213141627/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~1551180%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archivedate=13 February 2009 |publisher=Reading F.C. |date=11 February 2009 |accessdate=24 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> but he returned to Reading less than a week later on 17 February after being recalled by the club.<ref>{{cite web | title = Winger recalled from loan| url = http://www.readingfcco.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1560105,00.html| publisher = Reading F.C. | date = 17 February 2009| accessdate = 24 February 2009}}</ref>
Following his loan spell with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in the summer of 2010, Antonio signed a fresh deal to keep him at Reading until 2013.<ref name="Reading contract 2010">{{cite news |title=Jem Karacan and Michail Antonio sign new Reading deals |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/reading/9031012.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref> He featured more regularly in the squad during the [[2010–11 Reading F.C. season|2010–11 season]], scoring one goal, against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Burnley 0–4 Reading|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9103743.stm|accessdate=27 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 October 2010}}</ref> in 24 appearances in all competitions.<ref name=sb1011/>
====Cheltenham Town (loan)==== After being recalled from Tooting, Antonio was subsequently loaned out to [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Cheltenham Town F.C.|Cheltenham Town]] on a month's loan, commencing on 19 February.<ref name="Cheltenham capture Reading winger">{{cite news| title = Cheltenham capture Reading winger| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cheltenham_town/7901056.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 20 February 2009| accessdate = 24 February 2009}}</ref>
He made his [[English Football League|Football League]] debut in a 2–0 defeat to [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] on 21 February,<ref>{{cite news| title = Leeds 2–0 Cheltenham| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7886236.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date = 21 February 2009| accessdate = 24 February 2009}}</ref> being substituted on 28 minutes after suffering from an ankle injury.<ref name="Robson-Kanu scores; Antonio injured">{{cite web|title=Robson-Kanu scores; Antonio injured |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1567555,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226000835/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~1567555%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archivedate=26 February 2009 |publisher=Reading F.C. |date=24 February 2009 |accessdate=24 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> After spending some time out injured, Antonio would go on to make eight further appearances until the end of the season with Cheltenham.<ref name=sb0809/>
====Southampton (loan)==== Southampton signed Antonio on loan for one month on 5 October 2009,<ref>{{cite news| title = Southampton sign Reading winger| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/southampton/8291419.stm| publisher = BBC Sport| date =5 October 2009 | accessdate =5 October 2009 }}</ref> making his debut on 9 October in a 3–1 away win at [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]].<ref>{{cite news| title = Southend 1–3 Southampton| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8290585.stm | publisher = BBC Sport| date =9 October 2009 | accessdate =9 October 2009}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Southampton in the [[FA Cup]] victory over [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] on 6 November.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/8341048.stm|title=Bristol Rovers 2–3 Southampton|publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 November 2009 |accessdate=6 November 2009}}</ref> The loan was subsequently extended until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/southampton/8441350.stm |publisher=BBC Sport | title=Southampton extend Antonio stay | date=6 January 2010 | accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref>
He scored in the first leg of the [[EFL Trophy|Football League Trophy]] area final against [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]], with the match finishing 1–0.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} He also scored in his next appearance, a 2–1 victory over [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in the [[FA Cup]].{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} He scored again in the 4–1 [[2010 Football League Trophy Final]] win over [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] on 28 March 2010, which was his 20th birthday, bringing Antonio his first silverware.<ref name=2010FLT>{{cite news |first=Stephan |last=Shemilt |title=Carlisle 1–4 Southampton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8583783.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 March 2010 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref>
Antonio's loan deal finished at the end of the [[2009–10 Southampton F.C. season|2009–10 season]], but both manager [[Alan Pardew]] and Antonio himself expressed a desire for the winger to remain at Southampton.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10280~2034801,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100428225341/http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10280~2034801%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archivedate=28 April 2010 |title=Michail Happy at Saints |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=25 April 2010 |accessdate=3 May 2010 |df= }}</ref>
====Colchester United (loan)==== [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]] was the next destination for Antonio, where he signed on a one-month loan on 15 August 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14536618.stm? |title=Colchester United sign Reading winger Michail Antonio |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 August 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011 }}</ref> He made his debut for the club the following day in a 2–0 home defeat to [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Colchester United – Match details – Colchester Utd 0–2 Charlton Athletic |url=http://coludata.co.uk/item.php?pg=matchesplayed&fplyShowAll=true&fdfaShowAll=true&frt=rescomp&pd=1025&fsea=all&fply=794&it=3561 |publisher=Coludata.co.uk |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club to put the U's 2–1 ahead as they eventually lost in a 3–2 defeat to [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on 20 August.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14514585 |title=Huddersfield 3–2 Colchester |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 August 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref> His loan spell with the club was extended for another month in September<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14894309 |title=Colchester's Carl Pentney in Chelmsford City loan deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref> and then for a further month in October.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14945389 |title=Colchester United extend Michail Antonio spell |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 October 2011 |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref> In total, Antonio scored four goals in 15 league outings for Colchester.<ref name=sb1112/>
===Sheffield Wednesday=== On 21 February 2012, [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] signed Antonio on an emergency loan deal until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~2618686,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222154445/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~2618686%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archivedate=22 February 2012 |title=Williams makes loan move |publisher=Reading F.C. |date=21 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> His debut for the Owls came in a 1–0 victory over local rivals, [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] on 26 February.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sheffield Wednesday 1 Sheffield United 0 | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17093412|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 February 2012|date=26 February 2012}}</ref> In his next appearance, a 4–1 win against [[Bury F.C.|Bury]], he scored two and set up another for [[forward (association football)|forward]] [[Ryan Lowe]].{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} In the following match, against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]], Antonio set up the opener and scored Wednesday's third in the opening ten minutes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sheffield Wednesday 3 Bournemouth 0 | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17243531|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=13 March 2012|date=10 March 2012}}</ref> Against [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] at [[Hillsborough Stadium|Hillsborough]], he scored a 95th-minute winner to beat them and put Sheffield Wednesday only one point behind local rivals United, who were in second place.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} He helped the Owls to promotion on the final day of the season by scoring the first in a 2–0 victory over already relegated [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], which led Wednesday to finish above Steel city rivals Sheffield United.<ref name=BBC050512 >{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17878339 | title=Sheffield Wed 2–0 Wycombe | publisher=BBC Sport | date=5 May 2012| accessdate=23 February 2019}}</ref>
Antonio signed on a permanent basis for Sheffield Wednesday on 6 August 2012 on a four-year deal after a third and final bid for the player was accepted by Reading.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swfc.co.uk/news/article/antonio-signs-295396.aspx|title=Antonio Signs|publisher=Sheffield Wednesday F.C. |date=6 August 2012}}</ref> In his first season with the club, Antonio had been leading the scoring charts with nine goals, but an injury suffered in a 2–0 defeat by [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on 16 March 2013 ruled him out for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21843797 |title=Sheffield Wednesday's Michail Antonio to miss rest of season |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 March 2013 |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref>
===Nottingham Forest=== On 6 August 2014, Antonio signed a three-year contract with [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] for a transfer fee in the region of £1.5 million.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Richardson|first1=Nick|title=Forest sign Wednesday winger|url=http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/news/article/forest-sign-wednesday-winger-1805204.aspx|publisher=Nottingham Forest F.C.|accessdate=6 August 2014|date=6 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Michail Antonio: Nottingham Forest sign Sheffield Wednesday winger|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28679833|accessdate=6 August 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 August 2014}}</ref>
Antonio's strong form in Forest's first five league matches of the season, in which he contributed three goals and three assists, led to him being named as a candidate for the [[2014–15 Football League Championship|Championship's]] Player of the Month award for August.<ref>{{cite web |title=Red recognition |url=http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/news/article/manager-of-the-month-august-1896555.aspx |publisher=Nottingham Forest F.C. |date=4 September 2014 |accessdate=6 September 2014}}</ref> Antonio lost out on the award to [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton's]] [[Igor Vetokele]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Sky Bet Player of the Month 2014/15 |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/PlayeroftheMonth |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110316222734/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/PlayeroftheMonth |dead-url=yes |archivedate=16 March 2011 |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=21 September 2014 |df= }}</ref> Antonio started every league match for Forest during his first season with the club, scoring 14 goals, and was named Forest's Player of the Season on 4 May 2015.<ref name=potynffc>{{cite web |url=http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/news/article/antonio-scoops-top-prize-2439208.aspx|title=Antonio scoops top prize|publisher=Nottingham Forest F.C. |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref>
On 11 August 2015, Antonio scored a brace in a 3–4 loss to League One club [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] in the first round of the [[2015–16 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Nottm Forest 3–4 Walsall|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33768691 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=12 August 2015|date=11 August 2015}}</ref> On 15 August, the winger scored the winner in a 2–1 victory at home to Rotherham to open his tally for the new season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Match report: Forest 2–1 Rotherham|url=http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/fixtures-results/match-report/index.aspx?MatchId=3832767&tcmid=2514613 |publisher=Nottingham Forest F.C. |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref>
Having already rejected a bid of £4 million from [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] for the transfer of Antonio earlier that summer, Forest received a second bid of £4 million from arch-rivals [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]].{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} Consequently, Antonio was left out of Forest's Championship match against [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] on 19 August 2015, with his manager [[Dougie Freedman]] citing that the winger was not "in the right frame of mind" to play.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} However, Antonio returned for the next league match at [[Bolton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Michael Antonio left out following bid from Derby, as Nottingham Forest pull out of Frey deal |url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/Michail-Antonio-left-following-bid-Derby/story-27633804-detail/story.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150820062131/http://www.nottinghampost.com/Michail-Antonio-left-following-bid-Derby/story-27633804-detail/story.html |dead-url=yes |archivedate=20 August 2015 |newspaper=Nottingham Post |date=18 August 2015 |accessdate=20 August 2015 |df= }}</ref> On 26 August, [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] joined the bidding for Antonio, offering Forest £4 million and winger [[Matt Jarvis]] on a season-long loan.<ref>{{cite web |title=Michail Antonio: West Ham bid for winger set to be rejected |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34066785 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 August 2015 |accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref>
===West Ham United=== On 1 September 2015, Antonio signed for [[Premier League]] club West Ham United for around £7 million on a four-year contract with an option for a further two years.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34110297 | title=Antonio, Song, Moses and Jelavic join West Ham on deadline day | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref> He made his debut on 19 September, replacing [[Victor Moses]] in the 60th minute of West Ham's 2–1 Premier League win at Manchester City.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34191909 | title=Manchester City 1–2 West Ham | publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 September 2015| accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> In a [[Man of the match]] performance on 28 December 2015 in a 2–1 win, Antonio scored his first goal for West Ham. With the team losing 1–0 to Southampton, Antonio equalised when a clearance hit him and looped over Southampton goalkeeper, [[Maarten Stekelenburg]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35148239 | title=West Ham 2–1 Southampton | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=29 December 2015}}</ref>
On 27 February, Antonio scored the only goal in a home win over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]]. He celebrated by lying on his side and spinning in a circle, imitating a celebration by ''[[The Simpsons]]'' character [[Homer Simpson]] in the episode "[[Last Exit to Springfield]]".<ref>{{cite news|last=Dutton|first=Tom|title=Michail Antonio celebration: Watch West Ham star perform Homer Simpson dance move after scoring|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/michail-antonio-celebration-watch-west-ham-star-perform-bizarre-dance-move-after-scoring-a3190711.html|accessdate=28 February 2016|newspaper=London Evening Standard|date=27 February 2016}}</ref> In his next appearance, Antonio turned-in a [[Man of the match]] performance, scoring the only goal in a home win against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35647651 | title=West Ham United 1–0 Tottenham Hotspur | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=8 March 2016}}</ref> He followed this with another goal in a 3–2 away win at [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] three days later as West Ham came from two goals down.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-cant-deal-crosses-west-10997391 | title='Everton can't deal with crosses' – West Ham scorer Antonio admits targeting Blues after watching videos of their defensive weakness |newspaper=Liverpool Echo | date=6 March 2016 | accessdate=8 March 2016 | author=O'Keefe, Greg}}</ref> In July 2016, Antonio signed a new, four-year contract with West Ham.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36709044|title=Michail Antonio: West Ham winger signs new four-year deal |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref>
Antonio started West Ham's first match of the [[2016–17 West Ham United F.C. season|2016–17 season]] in the [[right-back]] position, subsequently giving away a penalty in the early stages of the second half, which was converted by [[Eden Hazard]], to give [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] a 1–0 lead. He was substituted not long after for [[Sam Byram]]. Chelsea went on to win 2–1.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.espnfc.com/club/west-ham-united/371/blog/post/2930767/michail-antonio-and-enner-valencia-flop-as-west-ham-lose-opener-to-chelsea | title=Michail Antonio and Enner Valencia flop as West Ham lose to Chelsea | publisher=ESPN FC | date=15 August 2016 | accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> In the second match of the season, on 21 August 2016, Antonio returned to his favourite position of [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]]. He scored the only goal of the match, from a cross by [[Gökhan Töre]], in a 1–0 win against Bournemouth; West Ham's first Premier League match and goal at their new ground, the [[London Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/aug/21/west-ham-united-bournemouth-premier-league-match-report | title=West Ham's Michail Antonio is the history boy in defeat of Bournemouth |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London | date=21 August 2016 | accessdate=23 August 2016 | author=Steinberg, Jacob}}</ref> In April 2017, having scored nine goals for West Ham, Antonio was ruled out for the remainder of the season with what was described by manager, [[Slaven Bilic]], as a "significant injury".<ref>{{cite web|title=West Ham's Michail Antonio out for season with 'significant injury'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39586811|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=10 May 2017|date=13 April 2017}}</ref> For his performances during the 2016–17 season, Antonio was named [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer of the Year|Hammer of the Year]].<ref name = HOTY>{{cite web|title=Antonio crowned Betway Hammer of the Year | url=http://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2017/may/09-may/antonio-crowned-betway-hammer-year|publisher=West Ham United F.C.|accessdate=10 May 2017|date=9 May 2017}}</ref> On 11 May 2017, West Ham announced that Antonio had signed a new, four-year contract.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39887055|title=Michail Antonio: West Ham winger signs new four-year contract|date=11 May 2017|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=18 May 2017}}</ref>
==International career== In March 2016, Antonio revealed that he had rejected the opportunity to play for [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica internationally]] and that he harboured an ambition of playing for England.<ref>{{cite web|title=West Ham's Michail Antonio turned down Jamaica for England|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35835036|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 March 2016|date=17 March 2016}}</ref>
On 28 August 2016, in new [[England national football team|England]] manager [[Sam Allardyce]]'s first squad, Antonio was called up for the first time, for a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification|2018 World Cup qualification]] match against [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]] in Slovakia on 4 September 2016 where he was an unused substitute.<ref>{{cite web|title=England squad named for opening 2018 FIFA World Cup qualifier against Slovakia as Michail Antonio wins first call-up|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/2016/aug/england-squad-slovakia-2018-fifa-world-cup-qualifier|publisher=The Football Association}}</ref> On 16 March 2017, Antonio was called up by new England manager [[Gareth Southgate]]'s squad for the friendly match against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] on 22 March and the 2018 World Cup qualifier against [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]] on 26 March, however, on 20 March, Antonio withdrew from the squad after picking up a hamstring injury.<ref>{{cite web|title=Michail Antonio out of England games with Germany and Lithuania|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/10808380/michail-antonio-out-of-england-games-with-germany-and-lithuania|publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
==Personal life== In February 2019, Antonio suggested that clubs whose fans engage in [[Racism in association football|racial abuse]] should be deducted points.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47208847|title=Michail Antonio: Clubs should be docked points for fans' racial abuse|date=12 February 2019|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 27 February 2019}}

revision.text:
'''Ben''', '''Benjamin''' or '''Benny Johnson''' may refer to:
*[[Ben Jonson]] (1572–1637), English poet and dramatist *[[Ben Johnson (actor)]] (1918–1996), American actor *[[Ben Johnson (offensive tackle)]] (born 1980), former American football offensive tackle of the National Football League *[[Ben Johnson (tight end)]] (born 1994), American football tight end *[[Ben Johnson (artist)]] (born 1946), British painter *[[Ben Johnson (chairman)]] (1939–2014), American Makah politician *[[Ben Johnson (cricketer)]] (born 1973), Australian cricketer *[[Ben Johnson (Australian footballer)]] (born 1981), Australian rules footballer *[[Ben Johnson (footballer, born 2000)]], English footballer *[[Ben Johnson (ice hockey)]] (born 1994), American professional ice hockey player *[[Ben Johnson (musician)]] (born 1984), American musician, member of the band 100 Monkeys *[[Ben Johnson (outfielder)]] (born 1981), American Major League Baseball outfielder *[[Ben Johnson (pitcher)]] (born 1931), American former Major League Baseball pitcher *[[Ben Johnson (politician)]] (1858–1950), American lawyer *[[Ben Johnson (soccer)]] (born 1977), American soccer player *[[Ben Johnson (sprinter)]] (born 1961), Canadian sprinter *[[Ben Johnson (American sprinter)]] (1914–1992), American sprinter *[[Ben F. Johnson]] (1914–2006), American politician in Georgia and academic administrator *[[Ben Patrick Johnson]] (born 1969), American voice-over actor, author, and commentator/activist *[[Ben Campbell Johnson]] (1932–2016), American minister and professor *[[Benita Johnson]] (born 1979), Australian distance runner *[[Benjamin Johnson (judge)]] (1784–1849), United States federal judge *[[Benjamin Johnson (rugby league)]], rugby league footballer of the 1910s *[[Benjamin Johnson (actor)]] (1665–1742), English actor *[[Benjamin Johnson (cyclist)]] (born 1983), Australian cyclist *[[Benjamin F. Johnson]] (1818–1905), American Mormon pioneer *[[Benjamin Newhall Johnson]] (1856–1923), American attorney and historian *[[Benton Johnson]] (born 1928), American sociologist *[[Benny Johnson (American football)]] (1948–1988), American football defensive back * [[Benny Johnson (journalist)]], American political columnist and reporter ==Other uses== *[[Ben Johnson (film)|''Ben Johnson'' (film)]], a 2005 Malayalam-language film
==See also== *[[Ben Johnson House (Bardstown, Kentucky)]], listed on the NRHP in Kentucky *[[Ben Johnson House (Flemingsburg Junction, Kentucky)]], [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Fleming County, Kentucky|listed on the NRHP in Fleming County, Kentucky]] *[[Ben Johnston (disambiguation)]]
{{hndis|Johnson, Ben}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Jordan Hugill | image = Jordan Hugill.jpg | caption = Hugill with Preston North End in 2016 | fullname = Jordan Thomas Hugill{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=18 February 2018}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1992|06|04}} | birth_place = [[Middlesbrough]], England | height = {{height|ft=6|in=0}}{{cite web |title=Player Profile |url=http://mobile.pnefc.net/team/player-profile/jordan-hugill/25 |website=mobile.pnefc.net |accessdate=2 October 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011081207/http://mobile.pnefc.net/team/player-profile/jordan-hugill/25|archive-date=11 October 2016|dead-url=yes}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]]
(on loan from [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]) | clubnumber = 11 | youthyears1 = 2007–2008| youthclubs1 = [[Marske United F.C.|Marske United]] | years1 = 2008–2009| clubs1 = [[Seaham Red Star F.C.|Seaham Red Star]] | caps1 = | goals1 = | years2 = 2009–2010| clubs2 = [[Consett A.F.C.|Consett]] | caps2 = | goals2 = | years3 = 2011 | clubs3 = [[Jerez Industrial CF|Jerez Industrial]] | caps3 = | goals3 = | years4 = 2011–2012| clubs4 = [[Whitby Town F.C.|Whitby Town]] | caps4 = | goals4 = | years5 = 2012 | clubs5 = → [[Marske United F.C.|Marske United]] (loan) | caps5 = | goals5 = | years6 = 2013–2014| clubs6 = [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] | caps6 = 20 | goals6 = 4 | years7 = 2013 | clubs7 = → [[Gateshead F.C.|Gateshead]] (loan) | caps7 = 7 | goals7 = 5 | years8 = 2014–2018| clubs8 = [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] | caps8 = 103 | goals8 = 23 | years9 = 2015 | clubs9 = → [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] (loan) | caps9 = 6 | goals9 = 1 | years10 = 2015 | clubs10= → [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] (loan)| caps10= 8 | goals10= 4 | years11 = 2018– | clubs11= [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps11= 3 | goals11= 0 | years12 = 2018– | clubs12= → [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] (loan) | caps12= 28 | goals12= 6 | club-update = 17:00, 2 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Jordan Thomas Hugill''' (born 4 June 1992) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[EFL Championship]] club [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. A relative late comer to the professional game, he had spells with non-league sides [[Seaham Red Star F.C.|Seaham Red Star]], [[Consett A.F.C.|Consett]], [[Whitby Town F.C.|Whitby Town]] and [[Marske United F.C.|Marske United]], and also spent time at the then [[Glenn Hoddle Academy]] club [[Jerez Industrial CF|Jerez Industrial]] in Spain. He was signed by [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] in June 2013, and made his debut for the club four months later following a productive loan spell at [[Gateshead F.C.|Gateshead]]. He signed with [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] in June 2014. He was loaned out to [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] in February 2015 and then [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] the following month. He was signed by Premier League side West Ham United in January 2018 for an undisclosed fee. He returned to the Championship the following transfer window in a season-long loan to Middlesbrough. ==Playing career== ===Early career=== Hugill, who was a pupil at [[Nunthorpe Academy|Nunthorpe School]],{{Cite web |title=From pulling pints at the Dickens Inn to scoring at the Riverside |last=Shaw |first=Dominic |work=Gazette Live |date=27 August 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2018 |url=https://www.gazettelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/dickens-inn-scoring-riverside-ex-7677911}} attended [[George Smith (footballer born 1945)|George Smith]]'s academy in [[Hemlington]] from the age of nine. He began his career with [[Northern Football League|Northern League]] club [[Seaham Red Star F.C.|Seaham Red Star]] at the age of 16, and was due to go on trial at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] before he was struck down with an ankle injury in September 2009.{{cite news |title=Hugill injury blow for Red Star |url=http://www.sunderlandecho.com/sport/local-football-hugill-injury-blow-for-red-star-1-1070606 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |newspaper=Sunderland Echo |date=18 September 2009}} He later moved on to [[Consett A.F.C.|Consett]], but left his contract in August 2010 to spend two years at the [[Glenn Hoddle Academy]] in Spain.{{cite news |last=Woodcock |first=Laura |title=Jordan's off to train in Spain; ...with Glenn Hoddle! |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Jordan%27s+off+to+train+in+Spain%3B+...with+Glenn+Hoddle!-a0234920253 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |newspaper=Evening Gazette |date=19 August 2010}}{{cite web |title=Marske United Make 2 New Signings |url=http://www.marskeunitedfc.com/news.htm |work=marskeunitedfc.com |accessdate=23 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009024831/http://marskeunitedfc.com/news.htm |archivedate=9 October 2013 |df=}} He signed with [[Whitby Town F.C.|Whitby Town]] in December 2011 and scored in his debut game against [[Nantwich Town F.C.|Nantwich Town]], only to damage his anterior cruciate ligament later in the match and spend the next ten months out injured. He joined [[Marske United F.C.|Marske United]] in October 2012 initially on loan so as to regain match fitness. His last appearance for Marske came in the final of the [[North Riding Senior Cup]], where they were beaten 3–0 by [[Pickering Town F.C.|Pickering Town]].{{cite news |last=Steel |first=Adam |title=Cup final loss is story of Marske United's season |url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/sport/other-sport/amateur-sport/cup-final-loss-story-marske-3664998 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |newspaper=gazettelive.co.uk |date=1 May 2013}} During his time at the club he worked as a barman at the ''Dickens Inn'' in [[Middlesbrough]].{{cite news |title=Jordan Hugill determined to be a star |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Port-Vale-Hugill-determined-Vale-star/story-20097666-detail/story.html |accessdate=19 November 2013 |newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]] |date=19 November 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131121032546/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Port-Vale-Hugill-determined-Vale-star/story-20097666-detail/story.html|archive-date=21 November 2013|dead-url=yes}} ===Port Vale=== Hugill signed with [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] in June 2013.{{cite news |title=Port Vale complete Chris Robertson and Gavin Tomlin deals |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23082437 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |newspaper=[[BBC Sport]] |date=27 June 2013}} He was loaned out to [[Gateshead F.C.|Gateshead]] of the [[Conference Premier]] on 20 September 2013.{{cite news |last=Baggaley |first=Mike |title=Vale striker joins Gateshead |url=http://www.thisisstaffordshire.co.uk/Vale-striker-joins-Gateshead/story-19825034-detail/story.html#axzz2fNPmF6cX |accessdate=20 September 2013 |newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]] |date=20 September 2013}} "Tynesiders" boss [[Gary Mills (footballer born 1961)|Gary Mills]] stated that Hugill was a "talented... goalscorer" and put him in the starting line-up for the next match.{{cite web |last=Bowron |first=Jeff |title=Gateshead Bring in Rams And Vale Pair |url=http://www.gateshead-fc.com/4606/gateshead-bring-in-rams-and-vale-pair |work=gateshead-fc.com |accessdate=23 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925093727/http://www.gateshead-fc.com/4606/gateshead-bring-in-rams-and-vale-pair |archivedate=25 September 2013 |df=}} He scored his first goal for the club on 24 September in a 3–2 win over [[Chester F.C.|Chester]] at the [[Gateshead International Stadium]].{{cite news |title=Gateshead 3 – 2 Chester |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24122084 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |newspaper=[[BBC Sport]] |date=24 September 2013}} He finished his loan spell with five goals in four starts and three substitute appearances. He made his debut for the "Valiants" on 22 October, and played the first 75 minutes of a 3–0 victory over [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]].{{cite news |title=Crawley 0 – 3 Port Vale |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24529456 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |newspaper=[[BBC Sport]] |date=22 October 2013}} He performed well on his debut, justifying his manager's surprise decision to play him alongside fellow Glenn Hoddle Academy graduate [[Ben Williamson (footballer)|Ben Williamson]] in place of established strikers [[Tom Pope]] and [[Lee Hughes]].{{cite news |last=Baggaley |first=Michael |title=Match report: Crawley Town 0, Port Vale 3 |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Match-report-Crawley-Town-0-Port-Vale-3/story-19970607-detail/story.html |accessdate=23 October 2013 |newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]] |date=23 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029213432/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Match-report-Crawley-Town-0-Port-Vale-3/story-19970607-detail/story.html|archive-date=29 October 2013|dead-url=yes}} {{Quote|First of all you have to say well done to our chief scout, [[George Foster (footballer)|George Foster]], who spotted his potential playing in non-league. We had him with us last season and the one thing he struggled with was his fitness. Pre-season was a struggle for him as well. He is a big old boy, not used to a professional pre-season, but is one of those lads who never gives up. You ask him to pull out of things and he doesn't want to do that.|Port Vale manager [[Micky Adams]] describing Hugill in October 2013.{{cite news |title=Micky Adams salutes Port Vale heroes after Crawley win |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Micky-Adams-salutes-Port-Vale-heroes-Crawley-win/story-19970609-detail/story.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20131024020241/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Micky-Adams-salutes-Port-Vale-heroes-Crawley-win/story-19970609-detail/story.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 October 2013 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]] |date=22 October 2013}}}} He scored his first Football League goal on 16 November, scoring the final goal of a 3–1 victory over [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] at [[Vale Park]]; after the match Adams said that the club had "unearthed a gem" in Hugill.{{cite news |last=Baggaley |first=Mike |title=Adams says Hugill is the real deal |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Adams-says-Hugill-real-deal/story-20090264-detail/story.html |accessdate=16 November 2013 |newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]] |date=16 November 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131118214828/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Adams-says-Hugill-real-deal/story-20090264-detail/story.html|archive-date=18 November 2013|dead-url=yes}} Hugill continued to turn out for the first team, but admitted that he needed to work on his fitness to play a full 90 minutes of professional football.{{cite news |title=Jordan Hugill determined to become Micky Adams' 90-minute man |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Jordan-Hugill-determined-Port-Vale-s-90-minute/story-20632004-detail/story.html |accessdate=15 February 2014 |newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]] |date=15 February 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303175246/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Jordan-Hugill-determined-Port-Vale-s-90-minute/story-20632004-detail/story.html|archive-date=3 March 2014|dead-url=yes}} At the end of the [[2013–14 Port Vale F.C. season|2013–14]] campaign he was named as the club's Young Player of the Year, and also featured in Vale's [[Staffordshire Senior Cup]] final defeat to [[Rushall Olympic F.C.|Rushall Olympic]].{{cite news |last=Baggaley |first=Michael |title=Port Vale lose Staffs Senior Cup final to Rushall |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Port-Vale-lose-Staffs-Senior-Cup-final-Rushall/story-21036812-detail/story.html |accessdate=11 May 2014 |newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]] |date=30 April 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512221209/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Port-Vale-lose-Staffs-Senior-Cup-final-Rushall/story-21036812-detail/story.html|archive-date=12 May 2014|dead-url=yes}}{{cite news |last=Baggaley |first=Mike |title=Tom Pope named Port Vale player of the year |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Tom-Pope-named-Port-Vale-player-year/story-21056123-detail/story.html |accessdate=5 May 2014 |newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]] |date=5 May 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505201838/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Tom-Pope-named-Port-Vale-player-year/story-21056123-detail/story.html|archive-date=5 May 2014|dead-url=yes}} However, in the summer Micky Adams confirmed that Hugill had rejected the club's offer of a new contract, and stated: "It is disappointing ... we spent a lot of time and effort with Jordan last season, but we will have to accept it."{{cite news |title=Port Vale set to lose Jordan Hugill |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Port-Vale-set-lose-Jordan-Hugill/story-21229649-detail/story.html |accessdate=13 June 2014 |work=t |date=13 June 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140616000211/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Port-Vale-set-lose-Jordan-Hugill/story-21229649-detail/story.html|archive-date=16 June 2014|dead-url=yes}} ===Preston North End=== Hugill signed a two-year contract with League One club [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] in June 2014, who paid Port Vale an undisclosed fee; manager [[Simon Grayson]] stated that "he's young, he's raring to go, hungry, he's a strong, powerful player, and he's got many attributes that will help us along the way this season and complement the squad well".{{cite web |title=Jordan Hugill: Preston North End sign Port Vale striker |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27930265 |accessdate=20 June 2014 |newspaper=[[BBC Sport]] |date=19 June 2014}} He had an eventful match after coming on for [[Andrew Little (footballer)|Andrew Little]] as a 20th-minute substitute at [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] on 13 September; he provided an assist for [[Joe Garner]] before being sent off for clashing with opposition defender [[Andy Butler]], he also picked up an injury in the game that required surgery and a lengthy spell on the sidelines.{{cite news |title=PNE striker undergoes knee surgery |url=http://www.lep.co.uk/sport/preston-north-end-news/pne-striker-undergoes-knee-surgery-1-6848320 |accessdate=7 October 2014 |work=Lancashire Evening Post |date=18 September 2014}} He returned to fitness in February 2015, at which point he joined his former Vale manager [[Micky Adams]] at [[EFL League Two|League Two]] side [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] for a one-month loan spell.{{cite news |title=Jordan Hugill: Preston North End striker loaned to Tranmere |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31658059 |accessdate=26 March 2015 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=27 February 2015}} On 26 March 2015, loan deadline day, Hugill signed for bottom-placed League Two club [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] on loan until the end of [[2014–15 Hartlepool United F.C. season|the season]]; "Pools" boss [[Ronnie Moore]] said that "It just didn't work at Tranmere. But we've seen a lot of him and he'll go straight in and get goals for us, no doubt about it".{{cite news |title=Hartlepool United: Preston striker Jordan Hugill signs on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32064983 |accessdate=27 March 2015 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=26 March 2015}} He scored four goals in eight games for the club, including the winning goal against [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] at [[Victoria Park (Hartlepool)|Victoria Park]] that secured Pools' place in the [[English Football League]].{{cite news |last1=Mennear |first1=Richard |title=Hartlepool hero Jordan Hugill eyes Preston success but hasn’t ruled out a return to The Vic |url=http://www.hartlepoolmail.co.uk/sport/football/hartlepool-utd/hartlepool-hero-jordan-hugill-eyes-preston-success-but-hasn-t-ruled-out-a-return-to-the-vic-1-7234194 |accessdate=8 May 2015 |work=Hartlepool Mail |date=29 April 2015}} He was an unused substitute at [[Wembley Stadium|Wembley]] in the [[2015 Football League One play-off Final|play-off final]] as Preston won promotion into the [[EFL Championship|Championship]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32770740 |title=Preston North End 4–0 Swindon Town |first=Nathan |last=Middleton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 May 2015 |accessdate=26 December 2018}} He signed a new two-and-a-half-year contract in October 2015.{{cite news |title=Jordan Hugill: Preston North End striker signs new deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34541222 |accessdate=17 October 2015 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=15 October 2015}} He ended the [[2015–16 Preston North End F.C. season|2015–16]] campaign with five goals in 32 games. He continued to impress in the [[2016–17 Preston North End F.C. season|2016–17]] season, and was given another new two-and-a-half-year contract in September 2016.{{cite news |title=Jordan Hugill Signs New Contract |url=http://www.pnefc.net/news/article/2016-17/jordan-hugill-signs-new-contract-3308037.aspx |accessdate=12 January 2017 |work=pnefc.net |date=14 September 2016}} The club rejected an offer of £1.5 million from [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in January 2017.{{cite news |title=Jordan Hugill: Preston North End turn down Ipswich Town approach |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38594277 |accessdate=12 January 2017 |work=BBC Sport |date=12 January 2017}} He ended the [[2016–17 Preston North End F.C. season|2016–17]] season with 13 goals in 47 appearances to end up as Preston's top-scorer.{{cite news |last1=Seddon |first1=Dave |title=PNE striker on the radar of Championship rivals |url=http://www.lep.co.uk/sport/football/preston-north-end/pne-striker-on-the-radar-of-championship-rivals-1-8536589 |accessdate=12 May 2017 |work=Lancashire Post |date=11 May 2017 |language=en}} He started the [[2017–18 Preston North End F.C. season|2017–18]] season in good form and was linked with a number of clubs in the [[List of English football transfers summer 2017|summer transfer window]], and handed in a transfer request on 29 August.{{cite news |title=Preston striker Jordan Hugill hands in transfer request |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11697/11011344/preston-striker-jordan-hugill-hands-in-transfer-request |accessdate=29 August 2017 |work=Sky Sports |date=29 August 2017 |language=en}} ===West Ham United=== On 31 January 2018, Hugill completed a deadline day signing for [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in a reported £10 million transfer deal, becoming manager [[David Moyes]]' second signing at the [[London Stadium]].{{cite news |title=Jordan Hugill: West Ham sign Preston striker in reported £10m deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42895867 |accessdate=1 February 2018 |work=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2018}} However he was restricted to a handful of brief cameos in the second half of the [[2017–18 West Ham United F.C. season|2017–18]] season, playing just 22 minutes in total.{{cite news |last1=Inkersole |first1=Sam |title=Jordan Hugill – Why his West Ham career is yet to take off |url=https://www.football.london/west-ham-united-fc/players/jordan-hugill-west-ham-future-14484202 |accessdate=11 May 2018 |work=footballlondon |date=6 April 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Inkersole |first1=Sam |title=Why Jordan Hugill was not named in the West Ham squad to face Everton |url=https://www.football.london/west-ham-united-fc/players/jordan-hugill-west-ham-everton-14651777 |accessdate=14 May 2018 |work=footballlondon |date=13 May 2018}} ====Middlesbrough loan==== On 8 August 2018, Hugill returned to the Championship on a season-long loan to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].{{cite news |title=Jordan Hugill joins Middlesbrough on loan from West Ham |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11680/11465611/jordan-hugill-closing-in-on-middlesbrough-loan-move-as-west-ham-enter-talks |accessdate=8 August 2018 |work=Sky Sports |date=8 August 2018 |language=en}} ==Style of play== Hugill is a target man [[Forward (association football)|forward]], has great strength and is able to out-muscle opposition defenders.{{cite news |last1=Baggaley |first1=Mike |title=Tom Pope: Why former Port Vale striker Jordan Hugill is in demand |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/tom-pope-why-former-port-vale-striker-jordan-hugill-is-in-demand/story-30054123-detail/story.html |accessdate=13 January 2017 |work=Stoke Sentinel |date=13 January 2017}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news |title=Ice-cool striker Jordan Hugill gives manager Micky Adams food for thought |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Port-Vale-Ice-cool-striker-Jordan-Hugill-gives/story-19985687-detail/story.html |accessdate=25 October 2013 |newspaper=[[The Sentinel (Staffordshire)|The Sentinel]] |date=25 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029210253/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Port-Vale-Ice-cool-striker-Jordan-Hugill-gives/story-19985687-detail/story.html|archive-date=29 October 2013|dead-url=yes}} Former Port Vale teammate [[Tom Pope]] stated that Hugill had an excellent attitude and "was desperate to learn and improve".{{cite news |last1=Pope |first1=Tom |title=Deadline day paid off for Jordan Hugill and Louis Dodds, by Port Vale's Tom Pope |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/sport/football/deadline-day-paid-jordan-hugill-1154256 |accessdate=2 February 2018 |work=Stoke {{Use British English|date=January 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Sam Byram | image = sambyram.png | image_size = 200 | caption = Byram during [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]]'s 2014 pre-season | fullname = Samuel Mark Byram{{Hugman|22461|accessdate=20 January 2016}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1993|9|16|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Thurrock]], England | height = {{height|ft=6|in=0}}{{cite book|editor1-first=Glenda|editor1-last=Rollin|editor2-first=Jack|editor2-last=Rollin|title=Sky Sports Football Yearbook 2012–2013|year=2012|publisher=[[Headline Publishing Group|Headline]]|location=London|isbn=978-0-7553-6356-8|page=482|edition=43rd}} | position = [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Right back]] | currentclub = [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]]
(on loan from [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]) | clubnumber = 25 | youthyears1 = 2005–2012 | youthclubs1 = [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] | years1 = 2012–2016 | clubs1 = [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] | caps1 = 130 | goals1 = 9 | years2 = 2016– | clubs2 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps2 = 27 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2018– | clubs3 = → [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] (loan) | caps3 = 1 | goals3 = 0 | club-update = 04:18, 26 August 2018 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Samuel Mark Byram''' (born 16 September 1993) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]], on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. He primarily plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]], but can also play as a [[Midfielder#Winger|right midfielder or right winger]].{{cite web|title=Luke showed what we've been miss-ing!|url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/leeds-united/latest-whites-news/luke-showed-what-we-ve-been-miss-ing-1-5082500|work=Yorkshire Evening Post|accessdate=2 November 2012|date=2 November 2012}} Byram was called up to the [[England national under-20 football team|England Under 20 team]] for the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] but withdrew from the squad through injury and remains uncapped at international level. ==Club career== Byram was born in [[Thurrock]], [[Essex]], before moving north, where he attended Ralph Butterfield Primary School, [[Haxby]], and then [[Joseph Rowntree School]] in [[York]]. He played for the City Schools team as a boy before joining [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]].{{Cite news | url = http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/archive/2003/10/15/York+Archive/7898168.print/ | title = Five-star York are in fine Nick | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | publisher = York Press. | date = 15 October 2003}} After completing his secondary education at school, he signed scholar forms with the West Yorkshire club in 2010. During his first year as scholar, he played 'down' a year in the under-16 team to help his development as a footballer.{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120820/sam-signs-up-for-the-future_2247585_2895119 | title = SAM SIGNS UP FOR THE FUTURE | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C. | date = 20 August 2012}} He later progressed to his age group in the under-18s where he would become a regular in the team during his second year in 2011–12. As an integral part of the team, he scored several goals over the course of the season as the under-18s finished as runners-up to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in their divisional academy league.{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120425/united-pride-in-runners-up-spot_2247585_2748334 | title = UNITED PRIDE IN RUNNERS-UP SPOT | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C. | date = 25 April 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120531132718/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120425/united-pride-in-runners-up-spot_2247585_2748334# | archive-date = 31 May 2012 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} Following the end of the season in May 2012, he was one of five young players rewarded with their first professional contracts for their performances in the campaign.{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120502/the-magnificent-seven_2247585_2757299 | title = THE MAGNIFICENT SEVEN | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C. | date = 2 May 2012}} ===Leeds United=== ====2012–13 season==== [[File:Sam Byram.jpg|thumb|175px|Byram playing for [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in 2012]] In the first friendly match of Leeds United's 2012–13 pre-season against [[Farsley Celtic F.C.|Farsley Celtic]], Byram was one of a number of youngsters given an opportunity to impress manager [[Neil Warnock]] when he lined up for the second half at [[Throstle Nest]].{{Cite news | url = http://www.leeds.vitalfootball.co.uk/article.asp?a=287701 | title = LUFC Five star Leeds see off Farsley Celtic | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | publisher = Vital Football | date = 20 July 2012}} United recorded a convincing 5–2 victory over their city rivals. Nevertheless, he would travel with the first-team on their summer tour of the South West of England the following week, featuring in the games against [[Tavistock A.F.C.|Tavistock]], [[Bodmin Town F.C.|Bodmin Town]] and [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]].{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120723/united-hit-tavistock-for-six_2247585_2857883 | title = UNITED HIT TAVISTOCK FOR SIX | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C. | date = 23 July 2012}}{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120725/four-star-united-win-at-bodmin_2247585_2860492 | title = FOUR-STAR UNITED WIN AT BODMIN | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C. | date = 25 July 2012}}{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120727/south-west-tour-ends-on-a-high_2247585_2863115 | title = SOUTH WEST TOUR ENDS ON A HIGH | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C. | date = 27 July 2012}} Byram remained as part of the first-team in pre-season after returning to the North; playing for an hour and scoring in the game away to [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]].{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120804/three-of-the-best-see-off-preston_2247585_2870743 | title = THREE OF THE BEST SEE OFF PRESTON | accessdate = 4 August 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C. | date = 4 August 2012}} After impressing in pre-season, Byram was handed the number 25 shirt for the season ahead and he made his first team debut at [[Elland Road]] in a 4–0 victory over [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] on 11 August in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]].{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120811/shrewsbury-live_2247585_2878205 | title = SHREWSBURY LIVE | accessdate = 11 August 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C. | date = 11 August 2012}} Byram retained his place in the first-team the following week in United's first league game of the campaign against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. He was part of a defence that kept a clean-sheet in a 1–0 victory over one of the early favourites for promotion and his performance out-wide against the [[England national football team|England]] international [[Matt Jarvis]] won praise from several observers.{{Cite news| url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120818/united-open-up-with-a-winner_2247585_2889721 | title = Becchio goal secures win against Wolves... | accessdate = 18 August 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C. | date = 18 August 2012}} He signed a new three-year contract with the West Yorkshire club two days after his league debut and only three months after signing his first professional contract with the club.{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120820/sam-signs-up-for-the-future_2247585_2895119 | title = Sam Signs Up for the Future | accessdate = 20 August 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C. | date = 20 August 2012}} Byram scored his first professional goal on 28 August in the 3–0 League Cup second-round victory over [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]]. Picking up the ball just outside the penalty area, he beat two Oxford defenders with his first and second touches before chipping the goalkeeper from inside the box in the 34th minute to give his team a 2–0 lead.{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120828/oxford-live_2247585_2902951 | title = OXFORD LIVE | accessdate = 28 August 2012 | publisher = Leeds United F.C.| date = 28 August 2012}} An impressed Neil Warnock told reporters after the game that "Sam will probably never score another goal like that in his career".{{Cite news | url = http://www.sportinglife.com/football/live/match-reaction/273452/warnock-pleased-with-cup-win | title = Warnock Pleased with Cup Win | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | work = Sporting Life| date = 28 August 2012}} Byram remained a permanent feature in the first-team squad during the early months of the season with United legend [[Eddie Gray (footballer, born 1948)|Eddie Gray]] tipping him to win a call-up to [[England national under-21 football team|England Under-21]] squad in the near future if he maintained his form.{{Cite news | url = http://www.lufcchat.com/legends-on-leeds/gray-on-leeds | title = Gray on Leeds – Byram's got the goods to follow Lees' international call | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | publisher = LUFC Chat| date = 10 September 2012}} His former manager in the under-18s, [[Neil Redfearn]], stated that Byram's rise through the ranks at the club served as a good example for other promising youngsters including his former teammates in the academy side, Ross Killock, [[Dominic Poleon]] and Simon Lenighan.{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120905/sams-a-shining-light-for-youngsters_2247585_2909567 | title = SAM'S A SHINING LIGHT FOR YOUNGSTERS | accessdate = 23 September 2012 | work = Sporting Life| date = 5 September 2012}} On 2 October, he scored his first league goal for Leeds in a 2–2 draw away to [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], heading in a cross from [[El Hadji Diouf]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19709796 "Bolton 2–2 Leeds"] BBC Sport. 2 October 2012. Retrieved 2 October 2012.{{cite web|title=DAVIES DOUBLE DENIES UNITED VICTORY|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20121002/davies-double-denies-united-victory_2247585_2936572|work=Leeds United A.F.C|accessdate=2 October 2012}} An away match at Leicester City on 5 March saw young Byram score his third goal for Leeds in a 1–1 draw. After his impressive form for Leeds linked him with [[Premier League]] interest,{{cite web|title=Sam Byram agrees new deal with Leeds United|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11715/8441406|work=Sky Sports News|accessdate=26 January 2013}} Byram signed a new contract with Leeds on 26 January 2013, to extend his stay at the club until 2016.{{cite web|title=SAM'S SET TO SIGN FOR THE FUTURE|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20130126/sams-set-to-sign-for-the-future_2247585_3054085|work=Leeds United A.F.C|accessdate=26 January 2013}} He scored his second league goal for the club on 6 March, in a 1–1 draw away at [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]],[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21583959 "Leicester 1–1 Leeds"] BBC Sport. 6 March 2013. Retrieved 9 March 2013. and followed this up with the equaliser in another 1–1 draw, at home to [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]]. On 26 April 2013, Byram won the ''[[Yorkshire Evening Post]]'' Player of the Season award with 99% of the vote.{{Cite news | url = http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/leeds-united/latest-whites-news/leeds-united-byram-so-proud-to-be-youngest-winner-1-5623885 | title = Leeds United: Byram so proud to be youngest winner | accessdate = 27 April 2013 | work = Yorkshire Evening Post | date = 27 April 2013}} After being linked with an £8 million pound move to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in the summer, Byram proclaimed that he wanted to stay at Leeds to try earn promotion.{{Cite news | url = http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/leeds-united/latest-whites-news/leeds-united-i-m-not-going-anywhere-byram-1-5623891 | title = I'm not going anywhere – Byram | accessdate = 27 April 2013 | work = Yorkshire Evening Post | date = 27 April 2013}} At the club's annual end of season awards on 27 April, Byram won the Player of the Year Award, Young Player of the Year Award, Players Player of the Year Award and also the Supporters Club Player of the Year Award.{{Cite news | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20130427/sam-wins-the-big-prizes_2247585_3159534 | title = SAM WINS THE BIG PRIZES | accessdate = 28 April 2013 | publisher = Leeds United Official Website | date = 28 April 2013}} On 30 July 2013, Bryam was named in [[Sky Sports]] Football League Players to watch out for in the Football League.{{Cite news | url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11689/8841517/fl-125-championship | title = FL 125 Championship | accessdate = 30 July 2013 | publisher = Sky Sports | date = 30 July 2013}} ====2013–14 season==== The hip injury sustained at the end of the 2012–13 season ruled Byram out of the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20]]'s World Cup. Bryam's injury caused him to miss the entire 2013–14 pre-season friendlies for Leeds. After missing the start of the 2013–14 season, on 6 August Leeds manager [[Brian McDermott (footballer)|Brian McDermott]] announced that Byram had an injection in his hip and the injury may require surgery which could potentially rule him out for several months.{{Cite news | url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11688/8857913/championship-leeds-defender-sam-byram-may-be-sidelined-for-several-more-months | title = Leeds defender Sam Byram may be sidelined for several more months | accessdate = 6 August 2013 | publisher = Sky Sports | date = 6 August 2013}} Byram made his first-team return on 21 September 2013, playing 57 minutes in Leeds' 2–1 defeat against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]]. He also played Leeds' next game, a League Cup defeat to Newcastle United, playing the full 90 minutes.{{Cite news | title = CUP EXIT AT NEWCASTLE | url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/1oda3gwpk9f661mehsrci0fk83/title/cup-exit-at-newcastle | publisher = Leeds United A.F.C | date = 28 September 2013 | accessdate = 28 September 2013}} Byram played just 27 games during an injury hit season. ====2014–15 season==== On 1 August, Byram was assigned the Leeds number 2 shirt for the 2014–15 season.{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/1wncxa2kw0zr11fmlyjr0m3t53/title/squad-numbers-released|title=SQUAD NUMBERS RELEASED|publisher=Leeds United F.C.|date=1 August 2014 |accessdate=1 August 2014}} On 9 August, [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] manager [[Ronald Koeman]] confirmed that Leeds had rejected a bid of £4.5 million to sign Byram.{{Cite news | title = Southampton's £4.5m bid for young defender Sam Byram rejected by Leeds | url = http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/497450/Southampton-s-4-5m-bid-for-young-defender-Sam-Byram-rejected-by-Leeds | publisher = Express | date = 9 August 2014 | accessdate = 9 August 2014}} Byram was given a straight red card on 23 August against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] for an off the ball incident with Watford defender [[Daniel Pudil]].{{cite news|title=TWO OFF IN WATFORD DEFEAT|date=23 August 2014|accessdate=23 August 2014|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/sojpa30okel317a4kki4xhnbg/title/two-off-in-watford-defeat|publisher=Leeds United Official Site}} Byram scored his fourth goal for Leeds in a 2–1 win against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Hudderfield Town]] on 31 January. In 2015, head coach Neil Redfearn changed Leeds' formation to a 4–2–3–1 with Byram moved forward into an attacking right wing position, with [[Scott Wootton]] played as the regular right back. Byram scored the second goal in a 2–0 away win over [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on 10 February.{{Cite web | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2948295/Reading-0-2-Leeds-United-Luke-Murphy-Sam-Byram-strike-seal-valuable-three-points-Neil-Redfearn-s-side.html | title = Reading 0 Leeds 2 | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 10 February 2015 | accessdate = 10 February 2015 }} On 18 March 2015, Byram scored for Leeds United against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in a 3–0 away victory.{{cite news |title=Fulham 0 Leeds 3|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31827949|date=10 March 2015 |accessdate=10 March 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}} On 9 April, after rumoured Premier League interest in Byram and teammates [[Lewis Cook (footballer, born 1997)|Lewis Cook]], [[Charlie Taylor (footballer, born 1993)|Charlie Taylor]] and [[Alex Mowatt]], head coach Neil Redfearn challenged Leeds United's owners to keep a hold of their homegrown talents.{{cite news |title=Keep young stars, Redfearn challenges Leeds|url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/leeds-united/latest-whites-news/leeds-united-keep-young-stars-redfearn-challenges-leeds-1-7202015 |date=9 April 2015 |accessdate=9 April 2015 |work=Yorkshire Evening Post}} On 2 May 2015, Byram was one of five players nominated for the Fans Player of the Year Award at Leeds United's official end of 2014–15 season awards ceremony, but lost out to eventual winner Alex Mowatt. Byram was also nominated for Young Player of the Year Award, but missed out on the Young Player of the Year award to Lewis Cook.{{cite news|title= MOWATT SCOOPS AWARDS NIGHT DOUBLE |date=2 May 2015|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/slzwndu1a9wb1kdweft4sskxz/title/mowatt-scoops-awards-night-double|publisher=Leeds United F.C.}} ====2015–16 season==== [[File:Sam Byram of West Ham United.jpg|right|140px|thumb|Byram with [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], January 2016]] Byram started the pre-season for Leeds playing as a [[Forward (association football)|right forward]] in new manager [[Uwe Rösler]]'s 4–3–3 formation.{{cite news|title= Leeds United 2–0 Everton: Alex Mowatt and Chris Wood strikes condemn Toffees to comfortable defeat at Elland Road |date=1 August 2015|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3182261/Leeds-United-2-0-Everton-Alex-Mowatt-Chris-Wood-strikes-condemn-Toffees-comfortable-defeat-Elland-Road.html}} On 31 July 2015, Rösler revealed that despite speculation linking Byram to Premier League clubs,{{cite news|title= Everton eye £8million-rated Leeds right back Sam Byram as Manchester United weigh up bid for Seamus Coleman |date=30 June 2015|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3144001/Everton-eye-Leeds-right-Sam-Byram-replacement-Manchester-United-target-Seamus-Coleman.html}} that he was not looking to sell the player and that he was an important player for the club.{{cite news|title= Leeds United: Rosler fights to quell Byram speculation |date=31 July 2015|url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/leeds-united/latest-whites-news/leeds-united-rosler-fights-to-quell-byram-speculation-1-7387748}}{{cite news|title= Rosler insists Leeds will not sell their best talent such as Sam Byram|date=2 August 2015|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3182630/Leeds-manager-Uwe-Rosler-determined-bring-glory-days-club-avoid-Massimo-Cellino-casualty.html}} On 12 August 2015, Byram missed a penalty in a penalty shootout against [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] in the League Cup, with Leeds losing 4–2 on penalties after a 1–1 draw.{{cite news|publisher= Leeds United Official site | date= 12 August 2015 | accessdate= 12 August 2015 | title= DONCASTER: UNITED EXIT CUP ON PENALTIES | url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/tq9ka0mhwvog1wx1szbqrvwzk/title/doncaster-united-exit-cup-on-penalties}} On 22 September 2015, Byram was criticized by Leeds owner [[Massimo Cellino]] who revealed he was "deeply offended" and "hurt" that Byram had not signed a new contract with the club.{{cite news|publisher= Sky Sports | date= 22 September 2015 | accessdate= 22 September 2015 | title= Sam Byram 'refused' new deal, says 'hurt' Cellino | url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11715/10001590/sam-bryam-thinks-he-is-too-big-for-leeds-and-will-not-sign-new-contract-says-massimo-cellino}} The ''Yorkshire Evening Post'' reported that the contract offer from Cellino to Byram was actually a reduction on his existing wage on a long term deal.{{cite news|work= Yorkshire Evening Post | date= 22 September 2015 | accessdate= 22 September 2015 | title= Byram too big for his boots, blasts Leeds United chief Cellino| url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/football/leeds-utd/byram-too-big-for-his-boots-blasts-leeds-united-chief-cellino-1-7475166}} On 5 December 2015, Bryam turned down a further contract offer, with the offer being just a one-year extension, however parity of his current wage.{{cite news|work= Yorkshire Evening Post | date= 5 December 2015 | accessdate= 5 December 2015 | title= Leeds United: Sam Byram rejects contract offer | url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/leeds-united/latest-lufc-news/leeds-united-sam-byram-rejects-contract-offer-1-7608795}} On 17 December 2015, Byram scored a brace in the match against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] to seal Leeds' 3–2 win.{{cite news|publisher= Leeds United F.C. | date= 17 December 2015 | accessdate= 17 December 2015 | title= REPORT: UNITED CLINCH THRILLER AT WOLVES | url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/6y2i8r7ed2df1112136hiey5c}} On 27 December, Byram scored in the match against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] to end the match at 1–1.{{cite news|publisher= Leeds United F.C. | date= 27 December 2015 | accessdate= 27 December 2015 | title= REPORT: BYRAM CLINCHES POINT AT FOREST | url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/19gaju3utrin11szuyl2bd1fwo}} On 5 January 2016, Byram was named Championship Player of the Month for December 2015 after scoring three goals and making assists throughout the month.{{cite news|publisher= Sky Sports News | date= 5 January 2016 | accessdate= 5 January 2016 | title= Mesut Ozil, Sam Byram lead PFA Fans' Player of the Month awards for December| url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/10119042/mesut-ozil-lucas-joao-lead-pfa-fans-player-of-the-month-awards-for-november}} After being subject to enquiries from Premier League clubs, on 7 January 2016 Leeds manager [[Steve Evans (footballer, born 1962)|Steve Evans]] revealed that he wanted to keep Byram at the club but that club owner Massimo Cellino had advised the enquiries had not been concrete enough for a move to happen.{{cite news|title= EVANS PROVIDES LATEST TRANSFER NEWS |date=7 January 2016|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/1rdran2rlfwce1vd0xm4tsu3kt/title/evans-provides-latest-transfer-news|publisher=Leeds United F.C.}} Byram left Leeds in January 2016. He had played 143 games in all competitions for them, scoring 10 goals.{{cite web | url=http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/January/20-January/Hammers-sign-Sam-Byram | title=Hammers sign Sam Byram | publisher=West Ham United F.C. | date=20 January 2016 | accessdate=20 January 2016}} ===West Ham United=== ====2015–16 season==== Byram signed for Premier League club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on a four-and-a-half year contract for an undisclosed fee on 20 January 2016.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35364368|title=Sam Byram joins West Ham from Leeds United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 January 2016|accessdate=20 January 2016}} He made his West Ham debut as a 13th-minute substitute for the injured [[Carl Jenkinson]] on 23 January in a 2–2 draw against Manchester City. In his post-match interview, manager [[Slaven Bilić]] revealed that Byram had not been in the matchday squad but was a late inclusion following an injury to [[James Tomkins (footballer)|James Tomkins]].{{cite web | url=http://www.skysports.com/watch/video/sports/football/competitions/premier-league/10141816/bilic-proud-of-performance | title=Bilic proud of performance | publisher=Sky Sports | date=24 January 2016 | accessdate=24 January 2016}} ====2016–17 season==== On 29 July 2016, Byram made his first start and appearance of the season in a 2–1 defeat against Slovenian [[NK Domžale|Domžale]] in the first leg of the [[2016–17 UEFA Europa League|UEFA Europa League]] third qualifying round tie.{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/nk-domzale-vs-west-ham/362689 |title=NK Domzale 2–1 West Ham: Matic Crnic scores twice to stun Hammers in Europa League first leg |date=29 July 2016 |publisher=SkySports}} ===Notingham Forest loan=== On 10 August 2018, Byram joined [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on loan for the remainder of the 2018–19 season.{{cite web|url=https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2018/august/10-august/sam-byram-joins-nottingham-forest-loan|title=Sam Byram joins Nottingham Forest on loan|publisher=West Ham United F.C.|accessdate=15 August 2018}} He made his debut for Forest on 14 August in the first round of the [[2018–19 EFL Cup]] against [[Bury F.C.|Bury]]. The game finished 1–1 after 90 minutes with Forest going through to the second round 10–9 on penalties, one of which Byram scored for Forest.{{cite web|url=https://uk.soccerway.com/matches/2018/08/14/england/league-cup/nottingham-forest-fc/bury-fc/2796928/?ICID=PL_MS_01|title=Nottingham Forest vs. Bury – 14 August 2018|publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=15 August 2018}} ==International career== On 17 May 2013, Byram was called up to the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20]] team by [[Peter Taylor (footballer, born 1953)|Peter Taylor]] for the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in Turkey.{{Cite news |url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20130517/sams-confirmed-on-world-cup-short-list_2247585_3182143 |title = SAM'S CONFIRMED ON WORLD CUP SHORT-LIST |accessdate = 17 May 2013 |publisher = Leeds United official website |date = 17 May 2013 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130607115953/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20130517/sams-confirmed-on-world-cup-short-list_2247585_3182143 |archivedate = 7 June 2013 |df = dmy-all }} On 11 June, however, he withdrew as a precaution due to a hip injury sustained towards the end of the 2012–13 season.{{Cite news |url = http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20130612/u20-world-cup-injury-rules-sam-out_2247585_3207919 |title = World cup injury rules Sam out |accessdate = 16 June 2013 |publisher = Leeds United Official Website |date = 12 June 2013 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130615011353/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20130612/u20-world-cup-injury-rules-sam-out_2247585_3207919# |archive-date = 15
