{{Spanish name|Martínez|López}} {{BLP sources|date=May 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Toni Martínez | image = Toni Martinez 2015 SBS Cup (cropped).jpg | image_size = | caption = Martínez at the 2015 SBS Cup | fullname = Antonio Martínez López{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=18 February 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|6|30|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Barrio del Progreso]], Spain | height = 1.80 m{{Cite web | title=Antonio Martínez| publisher=Premier League| accessdate=17 January 2018| url = https://www.premierleague.com/players/19681/Antonio-Martínez/overview}} | position = [[Forward (association football)#Striker|Forward]] | currentclub = [[CD Lugo|Lugo]]
(on loan from [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]) | clubnumber = 9 | youthyears1 = 2013 | youthclubs1 = [[Real Murcia]] | youthyears2 = 2013–2016 | youthclubs2 = [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] | years1 = 2013–2016 | clubs1 = [[Valencia CF Mestalla|Valencia B]] | caps1 = 16 | goals1 = 2 | years2 = 2016– | clubs2 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps2 = 0 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2017 | clubs3 = → [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] (loan) | caps3 = 15 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2018 | clubs4 = → [[Real Valladolid|Valladolid]] (loan) | caps4 = 10 | goals4 = 1 | years5 = 2018–2019 | clubs5 = → [[CF Rayo Majadahonda|Rayo Majadahonda]] (loan) | caps5 = 13 | goals5 = 2 | years6 = 2019– | clubs6 = → [[CD Lugo|Lugo]] (loan) | caps6 = 4 | goals6 = 1 | nationalyears1 =2014 | nationalteam1 = [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 =2015 | nationalteam2 = [[Spain national under-18 football team|Spain U18]] | nationalcaps2 = 2 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 =2016 | nationalteam3 = [[Spain national under-19 football team|Spain U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 2 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 16 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Antonio Martínez López''' ({{IPA-es|anˈtonjo maɾˈtineθ ˈlopeθ}}; born 30 June 1997), known as '''Toni Martínez''' {{IPA-es|ˈtoni-|}}; , is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|forward]] for [[CD Lugo]], on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. He has represented Spain at [[Spain national under-17 football team|under-17]] and [[Spain national under-19 football team|under-19]] level. Prior to joining West Ham, Martínez played for [[Real Murcia]] and [[Valencia CF]] at youth level, and [[Valencia CF Mestalla|the latter's B-team]] at semi-professional level. ==Club career== ===Valencia Mestalla=== Born in [[Barrio del Progreso]], [[Region of Murcia|Murcia]],{{cite web|url=http://www.whufc.com/Teams/Development-Squad/Squad/Antonio-Martinez |title=Antonio Martinez|publisher=West Ham United F.C. |accessdate=14 February 2019}} Martínez began his footballing career with local side C.F.S. El Progreso and later joined [[Real Murcia]].{{Cite web |title=El 'doctorado' de Toni Martínez en Oxford |trans-title= |first=Alberto |last=Rubio |work=Marca |date=18 February 2017 |accessdate=14 February 2019 |url= https://www.marca.com/futbol/premier-league/2017/02/18/58a78499e2704e75518b45c7.html |language=es}} In 2013, he signed for [[Valencia CF|Valencia]]. Initially a member of the club's academy ''Cadete A'' team (for players aged 14–15 years), Martínez was soon admitted to their reserve side, [[Valencia CF Mestalla|Valencia Mestalla]] (Valencia B). He made his senior debut in the ''[[2013–14 Segunda División B#Group 3|Segunda División B]]'' (third tier) at the age of 16, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] and scoring in a match against [[AE Prat]] on 8 December 2013.{{cite web | url=http://www.diariodemestalla.com/s/escuela/a/838-el-ano-de-toni-martinez- | title=El año de Toni Martínez | publisher=Diario de Mestalla {{es icon}} | date=14 June 2014 | accessdate=24 April 2016}} In three seasons at Valencia Mestalla he played 16 games and scored two goals, and made a further eight appearances, a goal and three assists for the club's [[Valencia CF (youth)|under-19 squad]] in the [[2015–16 UEFA Youth League|UEFA Youth League]].{{cite web | url=http://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/season=2016/clubs/player=250068973/index.html | title=Antonio Martínez | publisher=UEFA | date=1 April 2016 | accessdate=12 May 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170821144714/https://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/season=2016/clubs/player=250068973/index.html |archivedate=21 August 2017 |deadurl=no}} ===West Ham United=== In April 2016, Martínez agreed a three-year deal to join English club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 1 July 2016 for a fee of around £2.4 million.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36113462 |title=Toni Martinez: West Ham sign teenage Valencia striker |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 April 2016 |accessdate=24 April 2016}} He was given permission to train with his new teammates by Valencia to help him settle in England and would initially link up with West Ham United's [[West Ham United F.C. Under-23s#Development squad|development squad]]. Martínez was given the number 29 shirt for the [[2016–17 Premier League|2016–17 season]].{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/August/3-August/2016-17-squad-numbers-confirmed |title=2016/17 squad numbers confirmed |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |date=3 August 2016 |accessdate=6 August 2016}} He marked his [[Professional Development League|Premier League 2]] debut with a goal against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]], in a 3–0 home win. After scoring seven goals in as many games for [[West Ham United F.C. Under-23s and Academy|West Ham United U23]] during the first half of the season, he suffered two injury set-backs; the first left him sidelined for six weeks with the player due to return to action on 21 November, but then suffered another injury. His prolific goal-scoring feats continued into January and before long he had racked up a total of 12 goals from 11 games.{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/west-ham-youngster-toni-martinez-is-in-frightening-form-with-12-goals-in-11-appearances-for-under23s-a3425006.html|title=12 goals in 11 appearances: West Ham's Martinez in 'frightening form'|last=Long|first=Sam|date=20 December 2016|work=London Evening Standard|access-date=9 April 2017|dead-url=}} ====Oxford United (loan)==== On 23 January 2017, he was sent out on loan for the first time in his career, to [[EFL League One|League One]] side [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] until the end of the 2016–17 season.{{cite news|url=http://www.oufc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/oxford-united-west-ham-martinez-3534302.aspx |title=Oxford Sign West Ham Striker Martinez |publisher=Oxford United F.C. |date=23 January 2017 |accessdate=23 January 2017}} The player was handed the number 7 shirt by the club. On 28 January, Martínez came on as a substitute to score his first goal for the League One side in a 3–0 home win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in the fourth round of the [[FA Cup]].{{cite news |url=http://www.thefa.com/competitions/thefacup/match-stats?season=2016&competition=1&match=901756 |title=Oxford United 3 – 0 Newcastle United |publisher=The Football Association |date=28 January 2017 |accessdate=28 January 2017}} He made his League One debut in an away fixture against local rivals [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]], a game which Oxford won 2–1,{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38786523 |title=Swindon Town 1–2 Oxford United |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 February 2017 |accessdate=5 February 2017}} and scored his first league goal, a late consolation goal in a 3–2 home defeat at the hands of league leaders [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], on 7 March.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39111485 |title=Oxford Utd 2–3 Sheffield Utd |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 March 2017 |accessdate=8 March 2017}} ====Return to West Ham==== On 7 January 2018, Martínez made his full West Ham debut in an [[2017–18 FA Cup|FA Cup]] third round tie at [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]], replacing [[Javier Hernández]] after 71 minutes in a 0–0 draw.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42526171 |title=Shrewsbury Town 0–0 West Ham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 January 2018 |accessdate=8 January 2018}} ====Real Valladolid (loan)==== On 1 February 2018, it was announced that Martínez had made a deadline day loan switch to Spanish club [[Real Valladolid]] for the remainder of the [[2017–18 in Spanish football|2017–18]] season.{{Cite web | title = Toni Martínez apuntala la vanguardia | trans-title = Toni Martínez bolsters the forward lines | publisher = Real Valladolid | date = 1 February 2018 | accessdate = 1 February 2018 | url = http://www.realvalladolid.es/noticias/actualidad/01022018/Toni-Martinez-apuntala-la-vanguardia/ | language = es}} He contributed with one goal in ten appearances, as his side achieved promotion to [[La Liga]] in [[2018 Segunda División play-offs|the play-offs]]. ====Rayo Majadahonda (loan)==== On 13 August 2018, Martínez joined [[CF Rayo Majadahonda]] still in the [[Segunda División]], on loan for [[2018–19 Segunda División|the season]].{{cite web|url=https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2018/august/13-august/martinez-signs-loan-rayo-majadahonda|title=Martinez signs loan at Rayo Majadahonda |publisher=West Ham United F.C.|date=13 August 2018|access-date=13 August 2018}} He made his debut for Majadahonda on the opening weekend of the season, on 19 August against [[Real Zaragoza]], Majadahonda's first game at this level. He was introduced as a second-half substitute, replacing French midfielder [[Enzo Fernández|Enzo]]. He marked his debut, and secured his place in Majadahonda's history books, with the club's first goal in the Segunda División. The match finished in a 2–1 defeat.{{Cite web |title=Real Zaragoza vs. Rayo Majadahonda - 19 August 2018 |work=Soccerway |accessdate=14 February 2019 |url= https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2018/08/19/spain/segunda-division/real-zaragoza/rayo-majadahonda/2861551/}} ====Lugo (loan)==== On 18 January 2019, Martínez rescinded his loan deal with Majadahonda and moved to fellow second division team [[CD Lugo]], on loan until June.{{cite web|url=https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2019/january/18-january/martinez-links-la-liga-2-outfit-lugo-loan|title=Martinez links up with La Liga 2 outfit Lugo on loan|publisher=West Ham United F.C.|date=18 January 2019|accessdate=14 February 2019}} On his debut eight days later, he scored the opener in a 3–2 home win against his former club.{{cite web|url=https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2019/january/28-january/loan-round-martinez-scores-lugo-debut|title=Loan round-up: Martinez scores on Lugo debut|publisher=West Ham United F.C.|date=26 January 2019|accessdate=14 February 2019}} ==International career== Martínez played four matches for [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain U17]], making his debut on 22 January 2014 against [[Italy national under-17 football team|Italy]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} In 2015, he received a call from [[Spain national under-19 football team|Spain U19]] to participate in the [[2015 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|2015 UEFA Under-19 Championship]] in [[Greece]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} ==Career statistics== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" {{Portuguese name|Fernandes|Ribeiro}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Edimilson Fernandes | image = Edimilson Fernandes.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Fernandes with [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in 2016 | fullname = Edimilson Fernandes Ribeiro{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/84136|title=Squads for 2016/17 Premier League confirmed|publisher=Premier League|date=2 September 2016|accessdate=2 September 2016}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1996|4|15|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Sion, Switzerland|Sion]], Switzerland | height = {{height|m=1.90}} | currentclub = [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]]
(on loan from [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]) | clubnumber = 26 | position = [[Midfielder]] | youthyears1 = 2007–2013 | youthclubs1 = [[FC Sion]] | years1 = 2013–2016 | clubs1 = [[FC Sion]] | caps1 = 48 | goals1 = 2 | years2 = 2016– | clubs2 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps2 = 42 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2018– | clubs3 = → [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] (loan) | caps3 = 21 | goals3 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2016– | nationalteam1 = [[Switzerland national under-21 football team|Switzerland U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 5 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 2016– | nationalteam2 = [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] | nationalcaps2 = 8 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | pcupdate = 17 February 2019 | ntupdate = 18 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Edimilson Fernandes Ribeiro''' (born 15 April 1996) is a Swiss professional [[football (soccer)|footballer]] who plays as an [[attacking midfielder]] for [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] in [[Serie A]], on loan from [[Premier League]] side [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/edimilson-fernandes/298173/|title=Switzerland — E. Fernandes — Profile with news, career statistics and history — Soccerway|website=www.int.soccerway.com|publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=29 August 2015}} ==Club career== ===Sion=== Fernandes is a youth exponent from [[FC Sion]]. He made his [[Swiss Super League]] debut on 1 June 2013 against [[FC Zürich]] in 4–2 home win. He started in the first eleven and was substituted after 53 minutes.{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/06/01/switzerland/super-league/fc-sion/fc-zurich/1293283/|title=FC Sion vs. FC Zürich - 1 June 2013 - Soccerway|publisher=soccerway.com|accessdate=2015-08-29}} He scored his first senior goal on 1 March 2015 a 2–2 draw at home to [[FC Luzern]]. Fernandes played every minute of Sion's [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League]] campaign before the side was knocked out by [[S.C. Braga|Braga]] in the last 32. In all games he played 65 times for Sion's first team and 41 games for the club's under-21 side. ===West Ham United=== On 25 August 2016, Fernandes signed a four-year deal with English club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] for a fee of ₤5 million.{{Cite web|url=http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/August/August-25/Hammers-secure-Swiss-star-Fernandes|title=Hammers secure Swiss star Fernandes|date=25 August 2016|website=www.whufc.com|publisher=West Ham United F.C.|access-date=25 August 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160826094825/http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/August/August-25/Hammers-secure-Swiss-star-Fernandes|archivedate=26 August 2016|df=}} He made his West Ham debut on 25 September 2016 in a 3–0 home defeat by [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], coming on as an 82nd-minute substitute for [[Mark Noble]].{{cite web | url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/09/25/england/premier-league/west-ham-united-fc/southampton-fc/2241818/ | title=West Ham 0-3 Southampton | publisher=Soccerway | accessdate=28 October 2016}} On 26 October 2016, Fernandes scored his first goal for West Ham in a 2–1 win against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in the [[EFL Cup]], winning praise from manager [[Slaven Bilić]].{{cite web|url=http://bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37700008|title=West Ham United 2-1 Chelsea|publisher=BBC Spoer|date=26 October 2016|accessdate=27 October 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2016/10/27/slaven-bilic-admits-west-hams-edimilson-fernandes-has-surprised/ | title=Slaven Bilic admits West Ham's Edimilson Fernandes has surprised him this season | publisher=www.hitc.com | accessdate=28 October 2016}} ====Loan to Fiorentina==== On 13 August 2018, Fernandes joined Italian side [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] on a one-year loan deal with an option to buy.{{cite web | url = https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/west-ham-youngster-edimilson-fernandes-joins-fiorentina-on-loan-with-option-to-buy-a3910121.html | title = West Ham's Fernandes joins Fiorentina on loan with purchase option | first = James | last = Benge | work = London Evening Standard | date = 13 August 2018 | accessdate = 13 August 2018}} ==International career== Fernandes made his debut for the [[Switzerland national under-21 football team|Switzerland under-21 team]] in March 2016 in a 1–1 draw with [[England national under-21 football team|England]]. In his second game, on 2 September 2016, he scored his first international goal in a 3–0 win against [[Kazakhstan national under-21 football team|Kazakhstan]] in [[Biel/Bienne]].{{cite web | url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/edimilson-fernandes/298173/ | title=E Fernandes | publisher=Soccerway | accessdate=3 September 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/September/2-September/U21-pair-taste-victory | title=U21 pair taste victory | publisher=www.whufc.com | accessdate=3 September 2016}} In November 2016, Fernandes received his first call-up to the senior [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] squad for a match against the [[Faroe Islands national football team|Faroe Islands]].{{cite news |url=http://www.lematin.ch/sports/football/lacroix-edimilson-fernandes/story/29089329 |title=Football Avec Lacroix et Edimilson Fernandes |publisher=lematin.ch |date=4 November 2016 |accessdate=7 November 2016}} He made his senior debut against them, coming off the bench in the 69th minute. ==Personal life== Fernandes was born in [[Sion, Switzerland]], of Portuguese and Cape Verdean descent.{{cite web | url=http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/August/26-August/Ten-Fast-Facts-Edimilson-Fernandes | title=Ten Fast Facts — Edimilson Fernandes | publisher=www.whufc.com | accessdate=27 August 2016}} He is the cousin of Swiss international footballer [[Gelson Fernandes]], [[Manuel Fernandes (footballer, born 1986)|Manuel Fernandes]] and ex-[[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] midfielder [[Cabral (footballer)|Cabral]]. ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 10 March 2019}}{{cite web|title=E. {{pp-blp|small=yes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Use British English|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Josh Cullen |fullname = Joshua Jon Cullen{{cite web|url=http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/article.080815-2015-2016-premier-league-squad-numbers-released.html |title=Player shirt numbers for 20 Barclays Premier League clubs released |publisher=Premier League |date=8 August 2015 |accessdate=10 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150809220849/http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/article.080815-2015-2016-premier-league-squad-numbers-released.html |archivedate= 9 August 2015 |df= }} |image = Josh Cullen.jpg |image_size = 200 |caption = Cullen warming-up for West Ham United |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1996|4|7|df=y}}{{cite web |title=Josh Cullen |url=http://www.11v11.com/players/josh-cullen-248926/|publisher=11v11 |accessdate=12 January 2016}} |birth_place = [[Westcliff-on-Sea]], England |height = {{height|m=1.75}}{{cite web |url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/players/profile.html/josh-cullen |title=Premier League Player Profile Josh Cullen |author= |date=2016 |publisher=Barclays Premier League |accessdate=6 February 2016}} |position = [[Midfielder]] |currentclub = [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]
(on loan from [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]) |clubnumber = 24 |youthclubs1 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] |youthyears1 = 2010–2015 |years1 = 2015– |clubs1 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] |caps1 = 3 |goals1 = 0 |years2 = 2016–2017 |clubs2 = → [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] (loan) |caps2 = 55 |goals2 = 1 |years3 = 2017–2018 |clubs3 = → [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] (loan) |caps3 = 12 |goals3 = 0 |years4 = 2018– |clubs4 = → [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] (loan) |caps4 = 21 |goals4 = 0 |nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] |nationalteam2 = [[Republic of Ireland national under-19 football team|Republic of Ireland U19]] |nationalyears1 = 2011 |nationalyears2 = 2014–2017 |nationalcaps1 = 1 |nationalcaps2 = 3 |nationalgoals1 = 0 |nationalgoals2 = 0 |nationalyears3 = 2015– |nationalteam3 = [[Republic of Ireland national under-21 football team|Republic of Ireland U21]] |nationalcaps3 = 14 |nationalgoals3 = 1 |club-update = 10:17, 19 March 2019 (UTC) |nationalteam-update = 18:49, 18 April 2018 (UTC) }} '''Joshua Jon Cullen''' (born 7 April 1996) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a midfielder for [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] on loan from [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. He also represents the Republic of Ireland at [[Republic of Ireland national under-21 football team|under-21 level]]. ==Early life== Cullen was born in [[Westcliff-on-Sea]].{{cite web | url=http://www.the42.ie/all-you-need-to-know-west-ha-ireland-u19-international-2207959-Jul2015/ | title=All you need to know about the Ireland U19 starlet who’s just made his full debut for West Ham | work=The42 | accessdate=7 August 2015}} His grandparents on his father's side were from [[County Leitrim]], Ireland.{{Cite web |title=West Ham ace Cullen happy to stick with Ireland U-21s |first=John |last=Fallon |work=Independent.ie |date=9 October 2015 |access-date=4 October 2018 |url= https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/international-soccer/west-ham-ace-cullen-happy-to-stick-with-ireland-u21s-31595563.html}} He played junior football for Rayleigh Boys before joining [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] at the age of nine.{{Cite web |title=Cullen's final goal |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |date=9 May 2014 |accessdate=4 October 2018 |url= https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2014/may/09-may/cullens-final-goal}} He attended [[St Thomas More High School for Boys|St Thomas More High School]].{{Cite web |title=Teacher proud to see Josh Cullen make West Ham United debut |first=Chris |last=Phillips |work=The Echo |location=Essex |date=3 September 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2018 |url= https://www.echo-news.co.uk/sport/13643919.teacher-proud-to-see-josh-cullen-make-west-ham-united-debut/}} ==Career== ===West Ham United=== Cullen was first included in a West Ham matchday squad for their [[Premier League]] fixture against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] at the [[Emirates Stadium]] on 14 March 2015, remaining an unused substitute as they lost 3–0.{{cite news|last1=Magowan|first1=Alistair|title=Arsenal 3–0 West Ham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31776459|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 March 2015}} He was also called up and unused on 9 May, as West Ham lost 1–0 at [[Aston Villa]].{{cite news|last1=Whalley|first1=Mike|title=Aston Villa 1–0 Arsenal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32561783|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=9 May 2015}} On 2 July 2015, he made his first-team debut for the club in a 3–0 home victory over [[FC Lusitanos|Lusitanos]] of Andorra in the [[UEFA Europa League]] [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League qualifying phase and play-off round|first qualifying round]] first leg, replacing [[Joey O'Brien]] after 60 minutes;{{cite news|title=West Ham 3–0 Lusitanos|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33370216|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 July 2015}} he started in their 1–0 victory in the second leg a week later, making way for Amos Nasha after 63 minutes.{{cite news|title=Lusitanos 0–1 West Ham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33415530|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 August 2015|date=9 July 2015}} With manager [[Slaven Bilić]] putting priority on the team's [[Premier League]] performance, he made an array of changes for their third qualifying round second leg away to [[FC Astra Giurgiu]] on 6 August, including starting Cullen in his first competitive match against a professional opponent.{{cite news|title=Astra Giurgiu 2–1 West Ham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33738588|accessdate=6 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 August 2015}} Twenty-three days later he made his [[Premier League]] debut, replacing [[Diafra Sakho]] at the end of a 3–0 win over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]].{{cite news|title=Liverpool 0–3 West Ham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34025305|accessdate=29 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 August 2015}} Cullen returned from loan at Bolton Wanderers in January 2018 making an appearance in the FA Cup away at [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]]. He was praised for his performance by West Ham manager, [[David Moyes]], in a poor performance by West Ham which ended 0–0. Cullen also had two [[Incisors|front teeth]] kicked-out accidentally by Shrewsbury player [[Abu Ogogo]].{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2018/0107/931618-ireland-cullen-hammers/|title=Ireland U21 Cullen loses teeth but gains boss's praise|date=7 January 2018|publisher=|accessdate=8 January 2018}} ====Loans to Bradford City==== He signed on loan for [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] in February 2016.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35544929|title=Josh Cullen: West Ham midfielder joins Bradford on loan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 February 2016|accessdate=13 February 2016}} In March 2016 his loan was extended until the end of the 2015–16 season.{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/10200840/josh-cullen-extends-loan-with-bantams-from-west-ham|title=Josh Cullen extends loan with Bantams from West Ham|work=Sky Sports|accessdate=26 March 2016}} On 8 August 2016, Cullen re-signed for Bradford City on a five-month loan deal.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} He scored his first league goal for the club in the 2–1 victory at MK Dons on 16 August 2016.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} His loan at the club was extended on 3 January 2017 until the end of the season.{{cite news|url=http://www.bradfordcityfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/cullen-commits-to-promotion-push-3500049.aspx|title=Cullen commits to promotion push|publisher=Bradford City A.F.C.|date=3 January 2017|accessdate=5 January 2017}} ====Loan to Bolton Wanderers==== On 1 August 2017, Cullen, along with West Ham teammate [[Reece Burke]], joined [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on loan until the following January.{{cite web | url=https://www.bwfc.co.uk/news/2017/august/reece-burke-and-josh-cullen-join-on-loan/ | title=Reece Burke and Josh Cullen join on loan | publisher=Bolton Wanderers Official Site | date=1 August 2017 | accessdate=1 August 2017}} ====Loan to Charlton Athletic==== On 30 August 2018, Cullen joined [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] on loan until the end of the [[2018–19 Charlton Athletic F.C. season|2018–19]] season.{{cite news |title=Charlton sign Josh Cullen on loan from West Ham United |url=https://www.cafc.co.uk/news/view/5b87c0a61cfea/done-deal-charlton-sign-josh-cullen-on-loan-from-west-ham-united |accessdate=30 August 2018 |publisher=[[Charlton Athletic F.C.]] |date=30 August 2018}} Cullen dislocated his shoulder on 6 November 2018 playing against [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]], leaving the pitch in the 80th minute.{{cite web|url=https://www.football.london/west-ham-united-fc/players/josh-cullen-west-ham-injury-15383571|title=West Ham youngster faces spell on the sidelines after picking up 'unreal' injury|first=Rob|last=Guest|date=7 November 2018|website=footballlondon|accessdate=16 March 2019}} ==International career== Having already played for [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] in 2011,{{Cite web |title=Cullen helps England win |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |date=27 October 2011 |access-date=3 October 2018 |url= https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2011/october/27-october/cullen-helps-england-win}} Cullen made his debut for [[Republic of Ireland national under-19 football team|Republic of Ireland U19]] in September 2014, in a 1–0 victory against [[Netherlands national under-19 football team|Netherlands U19]].{{cite web | url=http://www.fai.ie/ireland/player/888841198 | title=Josh Cullen | publisher=www.fai.ie | accessdate=7 August 2015}} On 4 September 2015 Cullen made his debut for [[Republic of Ireland national under-21 football team|Republic of Ireland U21]] in a 4–1 victory against [[Qatar national under-23 football team|Qatar U23]] in a friendly at [[Gigg Lane]].{{cite news|title=King pleased as Ireland U21s beat Qatar U23s|url=http://www.fai.ie/ireland/news/king-pleased-as-ireland-u21s-beat-qatar-u23s|accessdate=6 September 2015|publisher=FAI.ie|date=4 September 2015}} On 25 March 2017, Cullen captained the Republic of Ireland U21s to a win 1-0 win over [[Kosovo national under-21 football team|Kosovo U21]] in a [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|UEFA Under-21 has Championship Qualifier]].{{cite news|url=http://www.fai.ie/ireland/news/report-ireland-u21s-beat-kosovo-in-uefa-campaign-opener|accessdate=27 March 2017|publisher=FAI.ie|title=Ireland U21 beat Kosovo U21 in UEFA Campaign Opener}} On 15 March 2019 he received his first international call-up to the Ireland first team.{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/12020/11666281/josh-cullen-and-kevin-long-called-up-by-republic-of-ireland|title=Josh Cullen and Kevin Long called up by Republic of Ireland|website=Sky Sports|accessdate=16 March 2019}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 16 March 2019}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=April 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Reece Oxford | image = Reece Oxford West Ham August 2014.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Oxford warming up for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in 2014 | fullname = Reece Joel Oxford{{cite web|url=http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/article.080815-2015-2016-premier-league-squad-numbers-released.html|title=Player shirt numbers for 20 Barclays Premier League clubs released|publisher=Premier League|date=8 August 2015|accessdate=9 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150809220849/http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/article.080815-2015-2016-premier-league-squad-numbers-released.html|archivedate=9 August 2015|df=dmy-all}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1998|12|16|df=y}}{{cite web |url=http://www.11v11.com/players/reece-oxford-242686/ |title=Reece Oxford |work=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=11 April 2016}} | birth_place = [[Edmonton, London|Edmonton]], England | height = {{convert|1.91|m|ftin|order=flip}} | position = [[Centre-back]]
[[Defensive midfielder]] | currentclub = [[FC Augsburg]]
(on loan from [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]) | clubnumber = 5 | youthyears1 = {{0|0000}}–2011 |youthclubs1 = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C. Reserves and Academy|Tottenham Hotspur]] | youthyears2 = 2011–2014 |youthclubs2 = [[West Ham United F.C. Reserves and Academy|West Ham United]] | years1 = 2014– | clubs1 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps1 = 8 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2017 | clubs2 = → [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] (loan) | caps2 = 5 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2017 | clubs3 = → [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]] (loan) | caps3 = 3 | goals3= 0 | years4 = 2018 | clubs4 = → [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]] (loan) | caps4 = 4 | goals4= 0 | clubs5 = → [[FC Augsburg]] (loan) | caps5 = 4 | goals5= 0 | years5 = 2019– | nationalyears1 = 2013 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 18 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalyears3 = 2016 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] | nationalcaps3 = 2 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2015–2017 | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps4 = 7 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalyears5 = 2016– | nationalteam5 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps5 = 5 | nationalgoals5 = 0 | club-update = 17:31, 24 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 20:39, 27 March 2018 (UTC) }} '''Reece Joel Oxford''' (born 16 December 1998) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[defender (association football)|defender]] for [[FC Augsburg|FC Augsburg]] on loan from [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. Oxford made his debut for [[West Ham United F.C.]] aged 16 years and 198 days, making him the club's youngest ever player, beating a record of 16 years and 221 days set in 1922 by [[Billy Williams (footballer, born 1905)|Billy Williams]].{{cite tweet|user=whufc_official|number=616265083187036160|title=OXFORD: @Reeceoxford_ will become #WHUFC's youngest-ever first-team player on Thursday, aged 16 years 198 days|date=1 July 2015|accessdate=2 July 2015}}{{cite tweet|user=whufc_official|number=616265561752911872|title=OXFORD: @Reeceoxford_ will beat Billy Williams' record. Billy was 16 years 221 days old when he debuted v @BlackpoolFC on 6 May 1922|date=1 July 2015|accessdate=2 July 2015}} ==Club career== Oxford was born in [[Edmonton, London]],{{cite web|first=Gary|last=Stonehouse|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2015/jul/england-u17s-captain-reece-oxford-makes-senior-west-ham-debut-020715|title=England U17s skipper enjoys winning senior Hammers debut|publisher=The Football Association|date=2 July 2015|accessdate=11 April 2016}} and was a boyhood supporter of [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].{{cite news | url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/boyhood-arsenal-fan-reece-oxford-delighted-with-west-hams-win-over-tottenham-a3195031.html | title=Boyhood Arsenal fan Reece Oxford delighted with West Ham's win over Tottenham | newspaper=London Evening Standard | date=3 March 2016 | accessdate=3 March 2016 | author=Benge, James}} He began playing football at [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]'s academy but was released from the club in 2011. He then joined [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] at under-13 level.{{cite news|title=Reece Oxford: West Ham teenager was rejected by Tottenham|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33840538|accessdate=10 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 August 2015}}{{cite news|title=West Ham youngster Reece Oxford reveals he was rejected by Tottenham|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/aug/10/reece-oxford-west-ham-tottenham|accessdate=10 August 2015|newspaper=The Guardian|location=London|date=10 August 2015}} He turned out for the under-18 team while still an under-15 schoolboy, and made the bench for a League Cup match in August 2014, still aged 15.{{cite web| url=https://www.shoot.co.uk/west-ham-united-and-england-prodigy-reece-oxford/| title=SHOOT for the Stars: West Ham United prodigy Reece Oxford| first=Daniel| last=Church| date=16 December 2016| magazine=Shoot!| access-date=3 November 2017}} On 11 January 2015, Oxford signed a long-term professional contract with West Ham.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2015/jan/england-u17s-captain-reece-oxford-pens-first-pro-deal-at-west-ham-140115|title=England U17s skipper Reece Oxford pens long-term contract with West Ham United on the pitch — England|publisher=The Football Association|accessdate=1 July 2015}} Four months later, he won the [[Dylan Tombides]] Academy Player of the Year Award.{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/9943960/reece-oxford-will-become-west-hams-youngest-ever-player-against-fc-lusitans-but-who-is-he|title=Who is Reece Oxford |publisher=Sky Sports}} Oxford made his competitive, first team debut on 2 July 2015, aged 16, starting in midfield in a 3–0 win against Andorran club [[FC Lusitanos|Lusitanos]] in a [[UEFA Europa League]] [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League qualifying phase and play-off round#First qualifying round|first qualifying round]] first leg tie. In so doing, he became West Ham's youngest ever player.{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/west-ham-30-lusitans-match-report-diafra-sakho-gives-hammers-winning-start-to-marathon-season-10362711.html | title=West Ham vs Lusitans match report: Diafra Sakho gives Hammers winning start to marathon season | newspaper=The Independent |location=London | date=2 July 2015 | accessdate=3 July 2015}} He then made his [[Premier League]] debut on 9 August, playing the first 79 minutes before being substituted for [[Kevin Nolan]] as West Ham won 2–0 away to Arsenal. Following his start, Oxford became the second-youngest Premier League starter of all-time, after [[Jose Baxter]].{{cite web|title=Arsenal 0–2 West Ham|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33750502|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=8 August 2015|date=8 August 2015}} Ahead of the [[2016–17 West Ham United F.C. season|2016–17 season]], Oxford was named in ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'''s list of the best youth prospects in English football.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/11755576/The-best-Premier-League-youth-prospects-in-pictures.html|publisher=The Telegraph|title=Reece Oxford and the best Premier League youth prospects — in pictures}} On his 18th birthday, 16 December 2016, Oxford signed a new, four-and-a-half year contract with West Ham.{{cite web|url=https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2016/december/16-december/oxford-signs-new-contract|title=Oxford signs new contract — West Ham United|website=www.whufc.com|accessdate=20 June 2017}} Just over one month later, he was sent on loan to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] for the remainder of the season.{{cite web|url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/defender-reece-oxford-signs-on-loan-from-west-ham-3547936.aspx|title=Reading FC Reece is a Royal!|publisher=|accessdate=20 June 2017}} He made his Reading debut on 11 March 2017 in a 3–0 away defeat to [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]], coming on as a second-half substitute for [[Paul McShane (footballer)|Paul McShane]]. He made five appearances, his final match being the 8 April away defeat to [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]], 7–1. On 21 June 2017, Oxford was sent on loan to German [[Bundesliga]] club [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]] for the [[2017–18 Borussia Mönchengladbach season|2017–18 season]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40333744|title=Reece Oxford: West Ham defender signs for Borussia Monchengladbach on loan|website=BBC.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/10920816/reece-oxford-joins-borussia-monchengladbach-on-loan|title=Reece Oxford joins Borussia Monchengladbach on loan|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=20 June 2017}} He did not make his debut until 28 October when he came on as an 89th-minute substitute for [[Lars Stindl]] in a 1–3 win against [[TSG 1899 Hoffenheim|Hoffenheim]].{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41792048| title=1899 Hoffenheim 1–3 Borussia Mönchengladbach| publisher=BBC Sport| date=28 October 2017| accessdate=29 October 2017}} On 12 December, Oxford made his first league start for Gladbach, against Freiburg. After the match, sporting director Max Eberl praised Oxford's development during his time at the club and stated exploratory talks had taken place over a permanent deal.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/soccer-transfers/story/3311951/borussia-monchengladbach-want-to-keep-west-hams-reece-oxford|title=Gladbach want to keep West Ham's Oxford|publisher=|accessdate=21 December 2017}} His loan was cut short and he returned to West Ham on 29 December 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.bundesliga.com/en/news/Bundesliga/borussia-monchengladbach-loanee-reece-oxford-returns-to-west-ham-467521.jsp?smartformat=true|title=Reece Oxford loan spell at Borussia Mönchengladbach ends as West Ham recall youngster| website=bundesliga.com| date=29 December 2017| accessdate=29 December 2017}} On 31 January 2018 Oxford was loaned to Borussia Mönchengladbach again.[https://www.bundesliga.com/en/news/Bundesliga/reece-oxford-returns-to-borussia-monchengladbach-from-west-ham-united-467500.jsp?smartformat=true%26] On 31 January 2019, Oxford again went out on loan, this time joining German team [[FC Augsburg]] until the end of the season.https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47079213 ==International career== Oxford has played for England up to under-20 level and captained his country at the [[2015 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2015/may/west-hams-reece-oxford-aims-to-put-sam-allardyces-lessons-into-practice-with-england-u17s-060515|title=West Ham and England U17s defender Reece Oxford aims to put Big Sam's lessons into practice against Europe's best — England|publisher=The Football Association|accessdate=1 July 2015}} The Young Lions reached the quarter-finals, and Oxford scored in the [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] as they defeated [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]] in a play-off for the [[2015 FIFA U-17 World Cup|2015 U-17 World Cup]].{{cite news|last1=Shergold|first1=Adam|title=England U17 0–0 Spain U17 (Pens 5–3): Young Lions win shootout to qualify for Under 17 World Cup in Chile|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3088218/England-U17-0-0-Spain-U17-Pens-5-3-Young-Lions-win-shootout-qualify-17-World-Cup-Chile.html|accessdate=4 July 2015|newspaper=Daily Mail|location=London|date=19 May 2015}} West Ham refused permission for him to play in the U17 World Cup in Chile, fearing that exposure to an international football tournament would lead to [[Occupational burnout|burnout]].{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/west-ham/11909926/West-Ham-refuse-to-let-exciting-midfield-prospect-Reece-Oxford-play-for-England.html | title=West Ham refuse to let exciting midfield prospect Reece Oxford play for England | newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London | date=3 October 2015 | accessdate=4 October 2015 | author=Edwards, Luke}} ==Style of play== UEFA.com has described his playing style as, "Tall and quick, he is not daunted in the face of illustrious opponents."{{cite web|publisher=Uefa.com|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=2322266.html|title=UEFA.com's weekly wonderkid: Reece Oxford}} On several occasions, Oxford has been compared to former West Ham academy graduate [[Rio Ferdinand]].{{cite web|publisher=HITC|url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2016/08/05/am-is-reece-oxford-west-hams-new-version-of-rio-ferdinand/|title=Is Reece Oxford West Ham's new version of Rio Ferdinand?}}{{cite web|title=Manchester United lodge transfer bid for West Ham's Reece Oxford|url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/05/30/manchester-united-lodge-transfer-bid-for-west-hams-reece-oxford-5913473/|publisher=Metro|accessdate=5 August 2016|date=30 May 2016}} ==Personal life== Oxford is of Jamaican descent through his grandfather. His grandfather, Karl, is the brother of the Jamaican footballer [[Neville Oxford]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/sport/Reece-gives--Oxford--new-meaning_19231807|title=Reece gives 'Oxford' new meaning|first=Walker|last=Howard|work=Jamaica Observer}} In December 2018, Oxford was the victim of a theft when his [[18-carat]] [[Rolex]] watch was stolen from the changing rooms at West Ham's [[Chadwell Heath]] training ground.[https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/11577976/west-ham-defender-reece-oxford-has-rolex-watch-stolen-prompting-police-investigation] ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 23 February 2019}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan="2"|Club !rowspan="2"|Season !colspan="3"|League !colspan="2"|National Cup !colspan="2"|League Cup !colspan="2"|Continental !colspan="2"|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- {{reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ==Honours== ===Club=== ====West Ham United==== *[[Premier League Cup (football)|Under-21 Premier League Cup]]: [[2015–16 Under-21 Premier League Cup|2015–16]]{{cite web| url=http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/May/4-May/Live-Hull-City-U21-v-Dev-Squad| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508110103/http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/May/4-May/Live-Hull-City-U21-v-Dev-Squad| |archivedate=8 May 2016| dead-url=yes| title=Dev Squad crowned Cup Champions| publisher=West Ham United F.C.| date=4 May 2016}} ===Individual=== *[[Dylan Tombides]] Academy Player of the Year Award: 2015 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons
