{{EngvarB|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Julian Dicks | image = JulianDicks2008.JPG | caption = Dicks at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]] in 2008 | image_size = 200 | fullname = Julian Andrew Dicks | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1968|8|8}} | birth_place = [[Bristol]], England | height= | currentclub = [[Heybridge Swifts F.C.|Heybridge Swifts]]
(manager) | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] | youthyears1= | youthclubs1= | years1 = 1985–1988 | years2 = 1988–1993 | years3 = 1993–1994 | years4 = 1994–1999 | years5 = 2001–2002 | clubs1 = [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] | clubs2 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | clubs3 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | clubs4 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | clubs5 = [[Canvey Island F.C.|Canvey Island]] | caps1 = 89 | goals1 = 1 | caps2 = 159 | goals2 = 29 | caps3 = 24 | goals3 = 3 | caps4 = 103 | goals4 = 21 | caps5 = 4 | goals5 = 1 | totalcaps = 379 | totalgoals = 55 | nationalyears1 = 1988 | nationalyears2 = 1992 | nationalteam1 = [[England under-21 national football team|England U21]] | nationalteam2 = [[England B national football team|England B]] | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalcaps2 = 2 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | manageryears1 = 2009 | manageryears2 = 2009–2011 | manageryears3 = 2013 | manageryears4 = 2014–2015 | manageryears5 = 2018– | managerclubs1 = [[Wivenhoe Town F.C.|Wivenhoe Town]] | managerclubs2 = [[Grays Athletic F.C.|Grays Athletic]] | managerclubs3 = [[Sealand national football team|Sealand]] | managerclubs4 = [[West Ham United L.F.C.|West Ham United Ladies]] | managerclubs5 = [[Heybridge Swifts F.C.|Heybridge Swifts]] }} '''Julian Andrew Dicks''' (born 8 August 1968) is an English former professional [[Association football|footballer]], manager and former professional golfer. He is currently the manager of [[Isthmian League]] North Division club [[Heybridge Swifts F.C.|Heybridge Swifts]]. Playing from 1985 until 2002, he was a [[defender (association football)|defender]], notably in the [[Premier League]] for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. He was voted West Ham's player of the year four times between 1990 and 1997. He also played in the [[Football League]] for [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] where he started his footballing career, ending it in 2002 in [[Non-League football|non-league football]] with [[Canvey Island F.C.|Canvey Island]]. He became manager of [[Wivenhoe Town F.C.|Wivenhoe Town]] in 2009, before moving to [[Grays Athletic F.C.|Grays Athletic]] later that year. He was capped by both the [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] and [[England B national football team|England B]] sides. He was known as a "hard man" adopting the nickname of [[The Terminator]]. He was a tough tackler with a strong shot in regular demand as a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] and free-kick taker. Dicks had a reputation for poor on-field discipline which brought him to the attention of referees, the press and footballing authorities. ==Early life== Dicks was born in Keynsham Hospital, [[Bristol]] to mother, Carol and father Ron who worked as a fork-lift truck driver for [[Courage Brewery]]. Ron played non-league football with [[Keynsham Town F.C.|Keynsham Town]], [[Welton Rovers F.C.|Welton Rovers]], [[Frome Town F.C.|Frome Town]] and [[Shepton Mallet F.C.|Shepton Mallet]] whom he would also go on to manage. Dicks attended Novers Lane Primary School, in [[Knowle, Bristol|Knowle]], Bristol and Merrywood Boys Secondary School also in Knowle. At age 11 he was watched by former [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] manager, [[Bill Nicholson (footballer)|Bill Nicholson]] who was [[Scout (sports)|scouting]] for West Ham United, but was turned down as he "was not quick enough". At age 13 he was spotted playing by Ron Veal who was scouting for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]. Veal recommended him to Villa manager, [[Ron Saunders]], however Saunders lost his job at Villa on 9 February 1982. When he was appointed as manager of Birmingham City nine days later,{{cite web | url=http://www.soccerbase.com/managers/manager.sd?manager_id=1090 | title=Ron Saunders — Managerial statistics | publisher=www.soccerbase.com | accessdate=13 October 2013}} Veal also changed his employer. Saunders was impressed when he watched Dicks play and he was offered a footballing apprenticeship with Birmingham City in 1982 when Dicks turned 14.{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | pages=19–35}} ==Career== ===Birmingham City=== He started his footballing career at [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], aged 14, having moved from his home in [[Bristol]].{{cite web|title=West Ham Legend For Europro Tour|url=http://www.theleader.info/article/6866/west-ham-legend-for-europro-tour/|publisher=www.theleader.info|accessdate=14 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022085036/http://www.theleader.info/article/6866/west-ham-legend-for-europro-tour/|archivedate=22 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} Playing as an apprentice he worked his way through the youth and reserve set-ups before making his debut in 1985 in a 2–0 away defeat to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. In 1988, he was signed by manager [[John Lyall]] for West Ham United, for £300,000, giving him the chance of [[Football League First Division|First Division]] football that Birmingham's relegation in 1986 had denied him. Although Dicks had been [[Yellow card (sport)|booked]] 33 times and [[Red card (sports)|sent-off]] once in all competitions, in his four seasons with Birmingham City, Lyall identified potential in the player enthusing "There was a great touch there. I wouldn't have signed just a physical player".{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=318}}{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=70}} ===West Ham United=== Dicks made his debut for West Ham on 2 April 1988 in a [[Football League Division One|Division One]] game against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]]. West Ham lost the game 2-1.{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=192&united=Julian_Dicks | title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics — Julian Dicks | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=9 October 2013}} He would go on to make eight appearances in the [[1987-88 West Ham United F.C. season|1987-88 season]], his first season with West Ham. The following season, he became a regular player and first choice [[left back]] for The Hammers, starting the first game of the season, a 4-0 away defeat to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and playing 34 of a possible 38 games that season. The season also saw his first goal for the club in a 2-1 defeat at [[Highbury Stadium|Highbury]] to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3626&united=04_Feb_1989 | title=Game played 4 February 1989 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=9 October 2013}} It was a poor season for West Ham who were relegated to [[Football League Division Two|Division Two]] having finished one place off the bottom of the league in 19th place with 38 points. Relegation had seen the sacking of manager [[John Lyall]] and the appointment of Scot, [[Lou Macari]]. The new manager and Dicks exhibited a poor working relationship from the outset.{{cite web | url=http://www.ex-hammers.com/page.php?21 | title=Julian Dicks exclusively told; | publisher=www.ex-hammers.com | accessdate=9 October 2013}} Despite this, and with West Ham now playing second tier football, Dicks retained his left back position and became their regular [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] taker following the exit of former first choice taker, [[Ray Stewart (Scottish footballer)|Ray Stewart]]. Dicks became well known for his penalties. During his West Ham career he scored 35, missing four.{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/game-over-for-super-mario-balotelli-misses-a-penalty-for-the-first-time-in-his-career-so-where-does-the-italian-stand-among-the-other-spot-kick-greats-such-as-eric-cantona-and-matt-le-tissier-8835149.html?action=gallery&ino=7 | title=Game over for Super Mario! Balotelli misses a penalty for the first time in his career, so where does the Italian stand among the other spot kick greats such as Eric Cantona and Matt Le Tissier? | work=The Independent | accessdate=9 October 2013 | location=London | first=James | last=Orr | date=23 September 2013}} His first penalty success came on 23 September 1989 proving to be the only goal in a win against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].{{cite news | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3654&united=23_Sep_1989 | title=Game played 23 September 1989 | work=www.whustats.info | accessdate=9 October 2013}} A future regular captain of the West Ham side, this season also saw his first captaincy, in a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] game on 19 September 1989 against his former club, Birmingham City, with manager Macari telling him "I'm making you captain today and I'm making you penalty taker too".{{cite book | title=Terminator: The Julian Dicks Story | publisher=Polar Publishing | author=Blows, Kirk | year=1996 | page=97 | isbn=1 899538 07 0}} Dicks was often cautioned and sent off by [[referee (association football)|referee]]s. His first red-card was in a match versus [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]] in the [[Football League Cup]] in the [[1989–90 in English football|1989–90 season]].{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3669&united=22_Nov_1989 | title=Game played 22 November 1989 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=9 October 2013}} It was an infamous encounter which included an on-pitch brawl between the opposing players. The fighting was sparked by a two-footed tackle by Wimbledon player, [[Dennis Wise]] on Dicks. Six players were booked with the game being described as "a disgrace to football" by journalist, [[Brian Woolnough]].{{cite book|title=Terminator: The Julian Dicks Story | page=100}} West Ham finished 7th in a season which saw the departure of Lou Macari and the appointment of former player, [[Billy Bonds]] as manager. Dicks and Bonds both had reputations as "hard men" and quarrelled frequently. ====Injury==== The [[1990-91 West Ham United F.C. season|1990-91]] season saw the start of Dicks' injury problems. On 13 October 1990, playing in a game against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] at [[Ashton Gate Stadium|Ashton Gate]], Dicks hit a dip on the edge of the pitch, his foot going over the edge resulting in a loss of feeling in his left leg.{{cite book | title=Terminator: The Julian Dicks Story | page=117}} He continued to play but after the game he could barely walk. Against the medical assessment of John Green, who was soon to take over as club physiotherapist, he was told to "crash-on" and in the words of manager Bonds "if the knee goes, it goes". Green believe Dicks was in need of an operation on his knee [[cartilage]]. He was picked to play in the next game, against [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] but lasted only 38 minutes. He played again in the next game on 24 October 1990, against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] but again had to be substituted. A knee operation followed and he would not play again until 21 December 1991 by which time West Ham had been promoted back to the First Division.{{cite book | title=Terminator: The Julian Dicks Story | page=118}} ====Another relegation and promotion==== He played in the second half of the [[1991–92 in English football|1991–92 season]]. Despite his presence, the team finished bottom of the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] and missed out on the [[1992–93 FA Premier League|first season]] of the [[Premier League]].{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1992&united=1st_Division_1991-92 | title=1st Division 1991-92 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=9 October 2013}} The [[1992–93 in English football|1992–93 season]] was an eventful one for Dicks, mainly for the wrong reasons. He was sent off three times and picked up a string of bookings which saw him miss significant periods of the season and he was subsequently stripped of the captaincy by manager Bonds. His first dismissal came after he threw his elbow into the face of [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] player [[Franz Carr]].{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=154}} There had been no friction between the two players with Dicks saying of the incident "Not to this day do I know why I did it. I had it in my mind that I was going to elbow him, and that was it — bang!". Only four games passed before he was dismissed again. In a game against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], Dicks clashed with [[Paul Birch (footballer, born 1962)|Paul Birch]] and [[Steve Bull]] before being sent-off, with Billy Bonds having to stop him attacking Birch who was still on the ground.{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=156}} Barely three months passed before his third dismissal of the season. In January 1993 after two bad fouls on [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] midfielder [[Ted McMinn]] he was sent-off, having to be escorted from the pitch by teammate [[Clive Allen]].{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=160}} Despite his disciplinary problems he earned a Division One runners-up medal as West Ham reached the [[Premier League]].{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football--ups-and-downs-west-hams-joy-pitches-portsmouth-into-the-minefield-2322074.html | title=Football / Ups and Downs: West Ham's joy pitches Portsmouth into the minefield | work=The Independent | date=10 May 1993 | accessdate=10 October 2013 | author=Haylet, Trevor | location=London}} Despite his dismissals he played 34 league games of a possible 46 in the promotion season, scoring eleven goals, placing third in the list of highest goal scorers for that season behind only Clive Allen and [[Trevor Morley]].{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1993&united=1st_Division_1992-93 | title=1st Division 1992-93 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=10 October 2013}} ===Premier League and Liverpool transfer=== Now playing in the Premier League for the first time, West Ham struggled in their first seven games. New signing [[Simon Webster (footballer)|Simon Webster]] had a long term injury having had his leg broken by Dicks in a training session accident.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-reid-keen-to-capture-stewart-1486920.html |title=Reid keen to capture Stewart |first=Clive |last=White |newspaper=The Independent |date=24 July 1993 |accessdate=10 October 2013 |location=London}}{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=173}} Fellow new signee [[Dale Gordon]] had failed to make the impression on the side his transfer had intended. In a move engineered by West Ham's then-Assistant Manager [[Harry Redknapp]], Dicks was transferred in order to bring in new players. Liverpool manager [[Graeme Souness]], on the recommendation of Redknapp, watched Dicks play in a West Ham match against Swindon Town on 11 September 1993. Souness thought Dicks to be "my kind of player" {{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=178}} and signed him for Liverpool that week in a swap deal which involved [[David Burrows (footballer)|David Burrows]] and [[Mike Marsh (footballer)|Mike Marsh]] moving to West Ham. Extra money received by West Ham from the transfer was used by Redknapp to buy veteran [[Forward (association football)|striker]], [[Lee Chapman]].{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eofQ_6gjZK0C&pg=PT109&lpg=PT109&dq=west+ham+dicks+marsh+burrows+chapman&source=bl&ots=0hohV66mYL&sig=7NYlf-X8ihXtADyk7XVF0eAfJvk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=LbZVUsDiFuHsiAfJg4HYAg&ved=0CFkQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=west%20ham%20dicks%20marsh%20burrows%20chapman&f=false | title=Hammers in the Heart | author=May, Pete | isbn=978-1-78057-450-9}} Dicks' signing had been part of an effort by Souness to "toughen up" the Liverpool team as he had planned to pair him with fellow hard man, [[Neil Ruddock]].{{cite news | url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/souness-adds-new-hard-man-1.741508 | title=Souness adds new hard man | work=Herald Scotsman | date=18 September 1993 | accessdate=12 October 2013}} Dicks debut on 18 September came in a high-profile game against local rivals, [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] at [[Goodison Park]]. In an eventful game, Liverpool lost 2-0. Former West Ham players, [[Mark Ward (footballer born 1962)|Mark Ward]] and [[Tony Cottee]] scored with Dicks' mistake on the ball allowing Cottee to control it and score.{{cite web | url=http://www.lfchistory.net/SeasonArchive/Game/1917 | title=Everton 2-0 Liverpool | publisher=www.lfchistory.net | accessdate=10 October 2013}} The game was also memorable for the on-pitch fighting of Liverpool teammates [[Steve McManaman]] and [[Bruce Grobelaar]].{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/1330070.stm | title=Football in-fighting | publisher=BBC Sport | date=14 May 2001 | accessdate=10 October 2013 | author=Austin, Simon}}{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=182}} By now a regular in the Liverpool side Dicks scored his opening goal, a shot from 25 yards, in a 3-0 away win against [[Oldham Athletic F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] in January 1994. His discipline had also improved and he had yet to be booked whilst in Liverpool colours.{{cite web | url=http://www.lfchistory.net/Articles/Article/945 | title=Dicks repays an act of faith | publisher=www.lfchistory.net | accessdate=10 October 2013}} Unfortunately for Dicks, Souness was proving to be an unpopular manager. He had dropped fan's favourites [[Ian Rush]] and [[John Barnes (footballer)|John Barnes]] to the reserve team due to perceived under performance and he had tried to integrate too many young and inexperienced players. In February 1994 after a shock [[FA Cup]] loss to Bristol City, a game in which Dicks did not play, the fans were calling for him to resign.{{cite web | url=http://www.lfchistory.net/SeasonArchive/Game/1958 | title=Liverpool 0-1 Bristol City | publisher=www.lfchistory.net | accessdate=10 October 2013}}{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=190}} Souness left Liverpool after three years in charge, in February 1994.{{cite web | url=http://www.lfchistory.net/articles/article/455 | title=Souness' Anfield agony | publisher=www.lfchistory.net | accessdate=10 October 2013}} He was replaced by [[Roy Evans]] who had always disliked Dicks and his style of play. Working under Souness he had kept his opinions to himself. Now with Evans as Liverpool manager Dicks' found himself out of favour.{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=197}} Dicks and Evans and his assistants [[Ronnie Moran]] and [[Steve Heighway]], disagreed over training methods, Dicks' fitness (they considered him to be overweight) and diet. Evans banished him to play with the reserve and to train with 15- and 16-year-olds.{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=201}} He played for Liverpool on 7 May 1994 in a 2-1 away defeat to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]. It proved to be his last first-team game for the club.{{cite web | url=http://www.lfchistory.net/SeasonArchive/Game/1958 | title=Aston Villa 2-1 Liverpool 1 | publisher=www.lfchistory.net | accessdate=10 October 2013}} The pre-season of the [[1994-95 Liverpool F.C. season|1994-95 season]] started badly for Liverpool and for Dicks. Picked to play in a [[friendly match|friendly game]] against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] at [[Burnden Park]] on 26 July 1994, Liverpool lost 4-1. Evans was again critical of Dicks' performance in the defeat; tired of such criticism he asked for a move from the club. He had played 28 games for Liverpool in all competitions, scoring three goals, although Dicks has the honour of being the last Liverpool player to score in front of the standing [[Spion Kop (stadiums)|Spion Kop]] at [[Anfield]] in a 1–0 win against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] near the end of the [[1993–94 in English football|1993–94 season]].{{cite web| url=http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/team/past_players/players/dicks/| title=PAST PLAYER PROFILE Julian Dicks| dead-url=yes| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070525112209/http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/team/past_players/players/dicks/ |archive-date=25 May 2007| website=www.liverpoolfc.tv}}{{cite web | url=http://www.lfchistory.net/Players/Player/Profile/289 | title=Player profile — Julian Dicks | publisher=www.lfchistory.net | accessdate=10 October 2013}} His Liverpool career lasted only 13 months, a short time considering his former manager Souness had said of Dicks, "if I was to pick the best 11 players I've ever worked with, he'd be one of them".{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=189}} ===Return to West Ham=== On re-signing Dicks, manager [[Harry Redknapp]] commented that he believed that his chairman thought he "was off his rocker" because Dicks was considerably heavier than when he had departed for Liverpool a year earlier. His first game in his second spell for the Hammers, on 22 October 1994, saw a 2-0 home win against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and, in keeping with his reputation, Dicks was booked.{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3925&united=22_Oct_1994 | title=Game played 22 October 1994 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=10 October 2013}} Dicks played a major part in helping to keep West Ham in the Premier League in [[1994–95 West Ham United F.C. season|1994–95]] scoring five goals.{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1995&united=Premier_League_1994-95 | title=Premier League 1994-95 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=10 October 2013}} The [[1995–96 West Ham United F.C. season|1995–96]] saw him equal highest goalscorer, with Tony Cottee, for West Ham in the Premier with ten league goals.{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1996&united=Premier_League_1995-96 | title=Premier League 1996-97 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=10 October 2013}} This season also included a game as goalkeeper in a game against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 19 December 1995. Dicks took over the goalkeeper's gloves after regular 'keeper, [[Ludek Miklosko]] had been sent-off for a foul on [[Daniel Amokachi]]. He let in two goals as Everton won 3-0. He was named Man of the Match.{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/everton-revel-in-mikloskos-misery-1525409.html | title=Everton revel in Miklosko's misery | work=The Independent | date=19 December 1995 | accessdate=21 November 2014 | author=Hodgson, Guy}} In [[1996–97 West Ham United F.C. season|1996–97]] he scored twice in a crucial London derby against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] on 24 February 1997 at [[The Boleyn Ground]] that West Ham won 4–3.{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4037&united=24_Feb_1997 | title=Game played 24 February 1997 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=10 October 2013}} Before the game West Ham had not won in nine games.{{cite web|url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20071018/spurs-lose-in-seven-goal-thriller_2236895_1328692 |title=Spurs lose in seven goal thriller |publisher=www.whufc.com |date=18 October 2007 |accessdate=10 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012035520/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20071018/spurs-lose-in-seven-goal-thriller_2236895_1328692 |archivedate=12 October 2013 }} The game signified the start of a fight back against relegation from the Premier League.{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2013/oct/04/joy-of-six-tottenham-hotspur-west-ham | title=The Joy of Six: Tottenham Hotspur and West Ham United | work=The Guardian | date=4 October 2013 | accessdate=12 October 2013}} West Ham had been in 18th place before the game but would go on the finish 14th at the end of the season.{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1997&united=Premier_League_1996-97 | title=Premier League 1996-97 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=10 October 2013}} [[File:Dicks in stone.jpg|thumb|200px|left|A commemorative stone for Dicks outside the [[London Stadium]]]] Another knee injury resulted in him missing the entire [[1997–98 in English football|1997–98 season]]. He did return to action in the [[1998–99 in English football|1998–99 season]] and West Ham finished fifth to qualify for the [[UEFA Cup]], but his injury problems failed to go away and he was restricted to just nine Premier League games. West Ham then terminated his contract and he retired from professional football after a 14-year career, 11 years of which had been spent at West Ham. In two spells at West Ham, he had played 315 competitive games and scored 64 goals, many of them penalties. His final appearance for the club came against Arsenal on 6 February 1999,{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-bergkamps-imperious-majesty-1069611.html?cmp=ilc-n |title=Bergkamp's imperious majesty |work=[[The Independent]] |date=6 February 1999 |accessdate=11 April 2010 | location=London | first=Peter | last=Conchie}} with his final goal coming in the FA Cup against Swansea City on 2 January 1999.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-fa-cup-hollins-draws-satisfaction-from-job-well-done-1045015.html |title=FA Cup: Hollins draws satisfaction from job well done |work=[[The Independent]] |date=2 January 1999 |accessdate=11 April 2010 | location=London | first=Ken | last=Jones}} In 2000 Dicks was granted a [[testimonial match]] by West Ham. On 13 August 2000 a West Ham eleven took on Spanish side [[Athletic Bilbao]] at the [[Boleyn Ground]]. The game was marred by a 17 player brawl in which West Ham player [[Igor Stimac]] was booked for a bad tackle and the West Ham captain for the day, [[Paolo Di Canio]], slapped several Spanish players in the face. West Ham manager Harry Redknapp was ordered to remove Di Canio for the pitch to defuse the tension. Bilbao coach, [[Txetxu Rojo]], was ordered to remove player [[Joseba Etxeberria]] for a similar reason. Bilbao won the game 2-1{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/w/west_ham_utd/879091.stm | title=Brawl mars Dicks' benefit match | publisher=BBC Sport | date=13 August 2000 | accessdate=13 October 2013}}{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2005/jun/29/theknowledge.sport | title=When testimonials go bad | work=The Guardian | date=29 June 2005 | accessdate=13 October 2013 | author=Dart, James}} Dicks received £200,000 from the game.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34647441|title=Testimonials: 1D, injuries, fights... what's ahead for Wayne Rooney?|date=27 October 2015|publisher=|accessdate=6 November 2017|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} ===Canvey Island=== In 2001, he made a brief return to football after signing for non-League [[Canvey Island F.C.|Canvey Island]].{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/3018043/FA-Cup-Dicks-dreaming-of-return-to-the-big-time.html | title=FA Cup: Dicks dreaming of return to the big time | work=Daily Telegraph | date=3 December 2001 | accessdate=10 October 2013 | author=Luscombe, Richard | location=London}} Only ten days after signing for Canvey Island, he was involved in an FA Cup [[Upset (competition)|shock]]. Playing against [[Football League]] side [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in the first round of the competition, Canvey turned-out 1-0 winners.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/1658794.stm | title=Wigan 0-1 Canvey Island | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=10 October 2013 | date=17 November 2001}}{{cite news | url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/Observer_Match_Report/0,,-36777,00.html | title=Canvey's 'monster' win | work=The Guardian | date=18 November 2001 | accessdate=10 October 2013 | location=London}} The success continued in the next round. Again facing Football League opposition in [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]], Canvey won 1-0 with a goal from [[Neil Gregory]] with a goal instigated with a move by Dicks.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/1697019.stm | title=Canvey Island 1-0 Northampton | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=10 October 2013 | date=7 December 2001}}{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/1701537.stm | title=Gregory's goal does it again | publisher=BBC Sport | date=10 December 2001 | accessdate=10 October 2013}} ==International career== Dicks made his debut for the [[England under-21 national football team|England under-21]] team in [[Lausanne]], Switzerland in a friendly game against the [[Switzerland national under-21 football team|Switzerland under-21]] team on 28 May 1988. The game finished 1-1 with the England goal being scored by [[Paul Gascoigne]]. Dicks' performance convinced manager [[Dave Sexton]] to call him into the squad for the 1988 [[Toulon Tournament]]. He played in England's first game of the competition against the [[Mexico national under-20 football team|Mexico under-21]] team in the [[Stade Mayol]] in [[Toulon]] on 5 June 1988. He was sent-off for a foul on a Mexican player.{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/1999/jan/09/newsstory.sport7 | title=Hammer hardman with another set of irons in his soul | work=The Guardian | date=9 January 1999 | accessdate=13 October 2013}} Undeterred by his sending-off, after missing one game through suspension, Sexton picked Dicks to play in the semi-final against the [[Morocco national under-20 football team|Morocco under-21]] team and for the final against the [[France national under-21 football team|France under-21]] team which England lost 4-2. Four years later, in 1992, Dicks was called in to the [[England B national football team|England B team]]. He played only two games for the side; a 1-0 win in the [[Stadion Střelecký ostrov]] stadium, [[České Budějovice|Budweis]], Czechoslovakia against the [[Czechoslovakia national football team|Czechoslovakia]] team and a 1-1 draw in the [[Luzhniki Stadium]], [[Moscow]] against the [[CIS national football team|CIS]] team.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablese/eng-u21-intres86.html |title=England — U-21 International Results 1986-1995 - Details |publisher=www.rsssf.com |accessdate=11 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125164210/http://rsssf.com/tablese/eng-u21-intres86.html |archivedate=25 January 2010 |df=dmy }}{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/1999/jan/09/newsstory.sport7 | title=Hammer hardman with another set of irons in his soul | work=The Guardian | date=9 January 1999 | accessdate=11 October 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslTmB.html | title=The B Team | publisher=www.englandfootballonline.com | accessdate=11 October 2013}} In 1995 [[England national football team|England]] first team manager, [[Terry Venables]], was putting together a squad to compete in [[UEFA Euro 96|Euro96]] in England. Dicks' performances had earlier given rise to journalists to call for his inclusion in the squad.{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-le-saux-is-so-forward-thinking-1427295.html | title=Football: Le Saux Is So Forward Thinking | publisher=The Independent | date=6 March 1994 | accessdate=14 October 2013 | author=Winter, Henry}} Two further disciplinary events ended such calls. On 11 September 1995 he was booked for stamping on the head of [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]'s [[John Spencer (Scottish footballer)|John Spencer]] in a 3-1 home defeat for West Ham. Spencer required eight stitches in his head.{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/the-year-of-men-behaving-badly-1527142.html | title=The year of men behaving badly | work=The Independent | date=23 December 1995 | accessdate=13 October 2013 | author=Moore, Glenn | location=London}}{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-dicks-to-face-fa-disrepute-charge-1602074.html | title=Football: Dicks to face FA disrepute charge | work=The Independent | date=20 September 1995 | accessdate=13 October 2013 | author=Shaw, John | location=London}} On 16 September 1995 at [[Highbury Stadium|Highbury]] he was dismissed for the eighth time in his career for a foul on [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]'s [[Ian Wright]].{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/arsenal-rely-on-wright-1601553.html | title=Arsenal rely on Wright | work=The Independent | date=17 September 1995 | accessdate=13 October 2013 | author=Fox, Norman | location=London}} The two incidents coming so close together caused the media to focus on the incident involving John Spencer. TV pundit [[Andy Gray (footballer, born 1955)|Andy Gray]] and politician, radio journalist and Chelsea supporter, [[David Mellor]] called for [[The Football Association|FA]] to get involved. The game had been televised live on [[BSkyB|Sky TV]] and a recording of it was provided to the match referee, [[Robbie Hart]] who had booked Dicks during the game. [[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] newspaper ran a full back-page on the incident with several pictures of the challenge and of blood on Spencer's face.{{cite book | title=Terminator:The Julian Dicks Story | page=6}} Mellor's radio program, [[606 (radio show)|606]],{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eofQ_6gjZK0C&pg=PT117&dq=julian+dicks+john+spencer&hl=en&sa=X&ei=I7tZUq2HG6S3igLDg4GAAw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=julian%20dicks%20john%20spencer&f=false | title=Hammers in the Heart | publisher=Mainstream Publishing | author=Pete May | isbn=978-1-78057-450-9}} had focused so intently on the clash that combined with The Sun's coverage, public focus was sufficient for Dicks' daughters to be attacked at their school in [[Essex]].{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/match-bitterness-1601761.html | title=Match bitterness | publisher=The Independent | date=19 September 1995 | accessdate=13 October 2013 | location=London}} The FA considered the video evidence provided and a report from referee Hart and Dicks was given a three-match ban.{{cite web | url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/MAD+KEANE+HAMMERED+ME+BECAUSE+I+REFUSED+TO+SAVE+HIS+BUTT%3B+JULIAN...-a061153336 | title=Mad Keane Hammered Me Because I Refused To Save His Butt; Julian Dicks | publisher=www.thefreelibrary.com | accessdate=13 October 2013}} This ban put in doubt any future involvement in England squads due to concerns over his indiscipline and although Venables watched him play in April 1996 he was not called into the Euro 96 squad.{{cite news| url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-110832327 | title=Stage Set for Dicks to Impress Venables | newspaper=Daily Mail | date=13 April 1996 | accessdate=13 October 2013 | author=Shepherd, Rob| url-access=subscription| via=[[Questia Online Library]]}} In 1997 with [[Glenn Hoddle]] now manager of England, Dicks met, by chance, his assistant, [[John Gorman (footballer)|John Gorman]] whilst on holiday. Dicks claims Gorman had told him he would stand a better chance of being picked if he had grown his hair. Dicks frequently shaved his head sporting a [[skinhead]] hairstyle. Gorman also said that Dicks had been a candidate for selection for a game against [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] in 1997. By this time Dicks had said he no longer wished to be considered for international selection.{{cite web | url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/DICKS+CAN+BE+HODD'S+JULE!%3B+SAYS+HARRY+REDKNAPP.-a061102981 | title=Dicks Can Bb Hodd's Jule!; Says Harry Redknapp | publisher=www.thefreelibrary.com | year=1997 | accessdate=15 October 2013}} ==Managerial career== [[File:Julian Dicks - West Ham coach.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Dicks as coach for West Ham United, July 2015]] ===Wivenhoe Town=== Dicks returned to football on 5 January 2009 when he was appointed manager of [[Eastern Counties League]] side [[Wivenhoe Town F.C.|Wivenhoe Town]],{{cite web|url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/sport/headlines/4019513.Julian_Dicks_named_as_Wivenhoe_Town_boss/|title=Julian Dicks named as Wivenhoe Town boss|work=Gazette|accessdate=12 September 2014}} but left the club shortly after the end of that season by mutual consent.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_conf/8091800.stm|title=Wivenhoe part company with Dicks|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2014}} ===Grays Athletic=== [[Conference National]] club [[Grays Athletic F.C.|Grays Athletic]] announced Dicks as their new manager on 15 September 2009.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1213748/Grays-Atheltic-West-Ham-connection-chairman-John-Moncur-appoints-Julian-Dicks-new-boss.html |title=Non League Grays Atheltic (''sic'') keep up West Ham connection as chairman John Moncur appoints former Hammer Julian Dicks as new boss |work=Mail Online |date=15 September 2009 |accessdate=7 October 2010 |location=London}} In his first season at Grays, he was relegated from the Conference, whilst the club voluntarily dropped three levels to the [[Isthmian League Division One North]]. After finishing 10th in the following season, Dicks left Grays by mutual consent in May 2011.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13438248.stm |title=Grays Athletic and Julian Dicks go separate ways |work=BBC Sport |date=18 May 2011 |accessdate=18 May 2011}} ===Sealand=== Dicks took take charge of the [[Sealand national football team|Sealand]] side at the Tynwald Hill International Football Tournament on the [[Isle of Man]] in July 2013.{{cite news | url=http://www.shropshirestar.com/sport/other-sport/2013/10/04/tim-flowers-and-julian-dicks-eye-up-market-drayton-role/ | title=Tim Flowers and Julian Dicks eye up Market Drayton role | work=www.shropshirestar.com | date=4 October 2013 | accessdate=10 October 2013}} ===West Ham United Ladies=== On 19 June 2014, Dicks was appointed as a new manager of the [[West Ham United L.F.C.|West Ham United Ladies]].{{cite web|title=Julian Dicks returns to West Ham|url=http://www.ironviews.com/julian-dicks-returns-west-ham/|publisher=Iron Views|accessdate=19 June 2014|date=19 June 2014}} His first competitive game was against Spurs Ladies.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N4dA-aVWgII|title=Behind the Scenes - West Ham United Ladies|first=|last=West Ham United FC|date=5 September 2014|publisher=|accessdate=6 November 2017|via=YouTube}} He helped to improve the team from their 10th-place finish that season and then to a sixth-placed finish in the 2014-15 season, along with a [[London FA]] Capital Women's Cup Final date against [[Charlton Athletic L.F.C.|Charlton Athletic Ladies]] which West Ham ladies lost 5-0.{{cite web | url=http://www.londonfa.com/news/2015/may/charlton-athletic-wfc-seal-treble-in-style?c=1 | title=Charlton Athletic WFC seal treble in style | publisher=www.londafa.com | accessdate=30 June 2015}} ===West Ham United=== On 29 June 2015, Dicks was appointed first-team coach for his former team, West Ham United, under new manager and former teammate, [[Slaven Bilic]].{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jun/29/julian-dicks-west-ham-coaching-staff-slaven-bilic | title=Julian Dicks joins former team-mate Slaven Bilic’s staff at West Ham | work=The Guardian | date=29 June 2015 | accessdate=29 June 2015}} In June 2016, Dicks signed a contract to keep him on the coaching staff at West Ham for a further two years.{{cite web|url= http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/June/22-June/Coaching-duo-sign-new-deals|title=Duo sign new deals|publisher=www.whufc.com|accessdate=22 June 2016}} When Bilic was sacked by West Ham in November 2017, Dicks also left the club.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41702779|title=Slaven Bilic: West Ham sack manager with team in the relegation zone|date=6 November 2017|publisher=|accessdate=6 November 2017|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} ===Heybridge Swifts=== On 4 October 2018, Dicks was appointed manager of [[Heybridge Swifts F.C.|Heybridge Swifts]].{{cite web | url=http://heybridgeswiftsfc.com/2018/10/juliandicks-2/| title=Julian Dicks appointed as new Heybridge Swifts manager| publisher=Heybridge Swifts F.C.|date=4 October 2018| accessdate=5 October 2018}} His first two games as manager, against [[Mildenhall Town F.C.|Mildenhall Town]] and [[Bury Town F.C.|Bury Town]], resulted in wins for The Swifts.{{cite web| url=http://nonleaguedaily.com/the-bosses-lounge-vol-9-julian-dicks-heybridge-swifts/#|title=The Bosses’ Lounge (Vol. 9) – Julian Dicks (Heybridge Swifts)|website=nonleaguedaily.com|date=18 October 2018|accessdate=18 October 2018}} ==Personal life== Dicks met his wife Kay in 1985 and they married in 1988. They had twin daughters Jessica and Katie in December 1988. The couple were married for 13 years until divorcing in 2001.{{cite web | url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/julian-dicks-what-happened-next | title=Julian Dicks: What Happened Next? | publisher=www.fourfourtwo.com | date=1 August 2005 | accessdate=10 October 2013}} His brother, Grantley is also a former footballer and coach.{{cite web|url=http://www.nonleaguedaily.com/news/index.php?newsmode=FULL&nid=58996 |title=Dicks reunited with Mogg at Yate |work=Non-League Daily |date=6 July 2009 |accessdate=14 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120923233309/http://www.nonleaguedaily.com/news/index.php?newsmode=FULL&nid=58996 |archivedate=23 September 2012 }} After retiring as a footballer, Dicks took up golf and soon turned professional, but was forced to give this career up due to his knee injury and the realization that he did not have the ability to win tournaments.{{cite web | url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20110115/julian-dicks_2236884_2301989 | title=Julian Dicks | publisher=www.whufc.com | date=15 January 2011 | accessdate=10 October 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801222740/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20110115/julian-dicks_2236884_2301989 | archivedate=1 August 2013 | df=dmy-all }} He went on to run the Shepherd and Dog Public House in [[Langham, Essex|Langham]], near [[Colchester]], Essex. ==Acting career== In 2014, he made a [[cameo appearance]] in the spoof football violence film ''[[The Hooligan Factory]]''.{{cite web|url=http://thepeoplesmovies.com/2013/02/nick-neverns-football-spoof-the-hooligan-factory-wraps/|title=Nick Nevern's Football Spoof The Hooligan Factory Wraps|work=The People's Movies|accessdate=12 September 2014}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Soccerbase}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070525112209/http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/team/past_players/players/dicks/ Liverpool F.C. profile] {{Navboxes |title=Awards |bg=gold |fg=navy |list1= {{1986–87 Football League Second Division PFA Team of the Year}} {{1989–90 Football League Second Division PFA Team of the Year}} {{West Ham United F.C. Player of the Year}} }} {{Grays Athletic F.C. managers}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dicks, Julian}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English footballers]] [[Category:England under-21 international footballers]] [[Category:England B international footballers]] [[Category:Association football defenders]] [[Category:Footballers from Bristol]] [[Category:Birmingham City F.C. players]] [[Category:Liverpool F.C. players]] [[Category:West Ham United F.C. players]] [[Category:Canvey Island F.C. players]] [[Category:Grays Athletic F.C. managers]] [[Category:English Football League players]] [[Category:Premier League players]] [[Category:National League (English football) managers]] [[Category:Isthmian League players]] [[Category:English football managers]] [[Category:West Ham United L.F.C. managers]] [[Category:West Ham United F.C. non-playing staff]] [[Category:Heybridge Swifts F.C. managers]] [[Category:Association football players who received a testimonial]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use British English|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Billy Bonds
[[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] | image = BillyBonds.JPG | image_size = 250 | caption = | fullname = William Arthur Bonds | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1946|9|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Woolwich]], [[London]], England | height = | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]], [[Midfielder]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] | years1 = 1964–1967 | years2 = 1967–1988 | clubs1 = [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] | clubs2 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps1 = 95 | caps2 = 663 | goals1 = 1 | goals2 = 48 | totalcaps = 758 | totalgoals = 49 | nationalyears1 = | nationalteam1 = | nationalcaps1 = | nationalgoals1 = | manageryears1 = 1990–1994 | managerclubs1 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | manageryears2 = 1997–1998 | managerclubs2 = [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] }} '''William Arthur Bonds''' [[Member of the Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (born 17 September 1946) is a former professional [[Association football|footballer]] and [[coach (sport)|manager]], who is most often associated with [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] with whom he spent 27 years as player and manager. He played 799 first-team games for West Ham in a career spanning 21 seasons. ==Background== Born in [[Woolwich]], south-east [[London]], Bonds grew up in nearby [[Eltham, London|Eltham]], where he played for a Sunday boys' team, Moatbridge, and Kent Schoolboys and joined the groundstaff at [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] after leaving school at 15.{{cite book| last =Bonds| first =Billy| authorlink =| title =Bonzo| publisher =Barker| year =1988| location =London| pages =4–14| url =| doi =| id = | isbn =978-0-213-16960-2}} He played in the youth and A team and occasionally in the reserves before joining the playing staff shortly before his 18th birthday in September 1964.{{cite book | last =Northcutt | first =J. |author2=R. Shoesmith | title =West Ham United: A Complete Record | publisher =Breedon Books | year= 1993 | location =Derby | pages =110, 304–345 | id = OCLC: 30031590 | isbn =1-873626-44-4 }} ==Playing career== ===Club career=== Bonds made his League debut for Charlton against [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] in February 1965 and became a regular in the first team, going on to make 95 League appearances, scoring one goal, before being signed by [[Ron Greenwood]] for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] for a fee of £50,000 in May 1967.{{cite book | last =Cameron| first =C.| title =Home and Away with Charlton Athletic 1920–2004| publisher =Voice of the Valley| year= 2003 | location =London| pages =211–225 | id = | isbn =0-9518125-2-1 }} He made his first appearance for West Ham in a testimonial match for [[Kenneth Brown (footballer born 1934)|Ken Brown]] in the same month and made his League debut against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] in the opening game of the 1967–68 season.{{cite book | last =Hogg| first =T.| title =Who's Who of West Ham United | publisher =Profile Sports Media | year= 2005 | location =London| pages =30–31 | id =| isbn =1-903135-50-8 }} He was ever-present in the 1968–69 and 1969–70 seasons and played 124 consecutive league games until injury ended his run of appearances in October 1970.{{cite book | last =McDonald| first =T.| title =West Ham In My Day | publisher =Football World | year= 2007 | location =Essex| pages =103–113 | isbn =0-9551176-8-2 }} Bonds played his first three seasons as a right-back before Greenwood switched him to midfield in the 1970–71 season where he counterbalanced the skills of [[Trevor Brooking]]. Bonds was at his peak in the early 1970s, helping West Ham to the semi-final of the [[Football League Cup]] in the 1971–72 season, where they lost to [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] after a second replay, and topping the scorers list at West Ham in the 1973–74 season with 13 goals, including a hat-trick against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].{{cite book | last =Hayes| first =D.| title =The Upton Park Encyclopedia: an a-z of West Ham United| publisher =Mainstream | year= 1998 | location =Edinburgh| pages =24–25 | id = OCLC: 60220812 | isbn =1-84018-043-9 }} After the departure of [[Bobby Moore]] in March 1974, Bonds was appointed to the captaincy and led the club to an [[FA Cup]] final victory over [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in 1975 and to the final of the [[1976 UEFA Cup Winners' Cup Final|1976 European Cup Winners' Cup]] despite a groin injury that interrupted the latter half of the 1974–75 season and part of the 1975–76 season. Greenwood moved Bonds from midfield to the back four as centre-half alongside [[Tommy Taylor (footballer b. 1951)|Tommy Taylor]] shortly before the end of the 1976–77 season, where he was able to come out from defence with the ball. He experienced relegation with West Ham at the end of the 1977–78 season but led West Ham to a second FA Cup victory over [[Football League First Division|First Division]] club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in 1980, becoming the only West Ham captain to lift the FA Cup on two occasions. In 1980–81, he led West Ham to the final of the League Cup, which was lost to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] after a replay, and to promotion back to the First Division. Bonds passed Bobby Moore's club record of appearances in 1982–83 and 'officially' retired in May 1984, relinquishing the captaincy to [[Alvin Martin]]. A spate of injuries to first-team players saw him return to the squad and make 26 league and cup appearances in 1984–85. He missed the entire 1985–86 season due to a toe injury but, having passed his 40th birthday, he was able to re-establish himself in the first-team during the 1986–87 season. A knee injury that forced him out of the last two games of the 1987–88 season led to a decision to finally retire in the summer of 1988, having played his last game at [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in April 1988 at the age of 41 years and 226 days.{{cite web |url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/archive/Billy-Bonds-previously-unseen-pictures-of-the-West-Ham-legend-plus-original-Daily-Mirror-features-and-stories-from-our-archive-article361.html |title=Billy Bonds 6'2", eyes of blue... Billy Bonds is after you! |publisher=Mirrorfootball.co.uk |accessdate=16 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828062624/http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/archive/Billy-Bonds-previously-unseen-pictures-of-the-West-Ham-legend-plus-original-Daily-Mirror-features-and-stories-from-our-archive-article361.html |archivedate=28 August 2010 |df=dmy-all }} Bonds had remained at the club as a player for over 20 years, scoring 48 goals in a club record 663 [[the Football League|League]] appearances. He established himself as a local hero and was the supporters' choice for [[West Ham United#Hammer of the Year|'Hammer of the Year']] in 1971, 1974, 1975 and 1987. He was appointed [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] (MBE) in January 1988 and was presented with the [[Professional Footballers' Association|PFA]] Merit Award in April 1988 by his fellow professional players. In May 2013 Bonds was awarded West Ham United's first ever lifetime achievement award.{{cite web |title=Bonzo honoured at Awards Night |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20130508/bonzo-honoured-at-awards-night_2236884_3171503 |publisher=Www.whufc.com |accessdate=9 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511193859/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20130508/bonzo-honoured-at-awards-night_2236884_3171503 |archivedate=11 May 2013 |df=dmy }} On 6 February 2019 it was announced that the East Stand at The [[London Stadium]] will be renamed the Billy Bonds Stand.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47141319|title=West Ham: Billy Bonds gets London Stadium stand named after him|date=6 February 2019|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 February 2019}} The unveiling took place ahead of West Ham's home fixture against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 2 March.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47340494|title=West Ham 2-0 Newcastle United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 March 2019}} ===International career=== Bonds was capped twice at England Under-23 international level and was on the bench as a non-playing substitute for the senior international team for a [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] qualifying match against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in November 1977. A collision with goalkeeper [[Phil Parkes (footballer born 1950)|Phil Parkes]] in the last game of the [[1980–81 in English football|1980-1981 season]] broke two of Bonds' ribs, and ruled him out of selection for England against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in May 1981. Bonds and [[Alvin Martin]] were in line to make their England debuts in that game. ==Career statistics== {{BLP unsourced section|date=September 2016}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ League First Division|First Division]] |22||0||2||0||0||0||0||0||24||0 |- !colspan="2"|West Ham United Total !663!!48!!48!!2!!67!!6!!21!!5!!799!!61 |} ==Managerial career== After Bonds retired as a player in 1988, West Ham manager [[John Lyall]] appointed him as youth coach. He unsuccessfully applied for the manager's post when Lyall left the club in July 1989 after West Ham had been relegated. However, when new manager [[Lou Macari]] resigned seven months later, Bonds was appointed manager in February 1990. In his first full season in charge, he took the club to promotion, when they finished as runner-up to [[Oldham Athletic F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] in [[1990–91 West Ham United F.C. season|1990-91 season]], also reaching the semi-finals of the [[FA Cup]] where they lost to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]]. He was awarded a second testimonial in the same season. West Ham were relegated in the [[1991-92 West Ham United F.C. season|1991–92 season]] in bottom place, but the board kept faith in Bonds and he led them to promotion the [[1992-93 West Ham United F.C. season|following season]], when they finished as runner-up to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. Bonds guided West Ham to a 13th-place finish in the [[1993–94 Premier League]]. He resigned in August 1994, just before the new season began, when he was replaced by [[Harry Redknapp]]. He had spells in coaching at [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] and [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] before making a return to management with [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] in May 1997. He managed 53 games before being sacked by the club{{cite web|url=https://metro.co.uk/2014/06/20/the-ten-most-bizarre-uses-for-a-retired-west-ham-united-footballer-4769428/|title=The ten most bizarre uses for a retired West Ham footballer|date=20 June 2014|publisher=|accessdate=3 March 2019}} the following year as they finished in the bottom half of Division Two. ==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite book | last =Northcutt | first =J. |author2=R. {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Alvin Martin | image = Alvin Martin, he's got no hair.jpg | caption = | fullname = Alvin Edward Martin | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|7|29|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Walton, Liverpool]], England | death_date = | height = {{height|ft=6|in=1}} | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] | youthyears1 = 1974–1976 | youthclubs1 = [[West Ham United F.C. Reserves and Academy|West Ham United]] | years1 = 1976–1996 | clubs1 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps1 = 469 | goals1 = 27 | years2 = 1996–1997 | clubs2 =[[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] | caps2 = 17 | goals2 = 0 | totalcaps = 486 | totalgoals = 27 | nationalyears1 = 1981–1986 | nationalteam1 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps1 = 17 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | manageryears1 = 1997–1999 | managerclubs1 = [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] }}
'''Alvin Edward Martin''' (born 29 July 1958) is an English retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]].
Playing most of his footballing career for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] he appeared in 598 games for them, scoring 34 goals. With the club for 21 years, and winning the [[1980 FA Cup Final|1980 FA Cup]] Martin left West Ham in 1996 and played one season with [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] before moving into football management with [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]]. This lasted two seasons before he started a career in the media on radio station [[talksport|talkSPORT]] and also as a [[Pundit (expert)|pundit]] on [[Sky Sports]] TV football talk shows. Playing 17 times for [[England national football team|England]] during the 1980s, Martin represented them at the [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986 World Cup]].
==Club career== Born in [[Walton, Liverpool]], [[Lancashire]], Martin played schools football for Bootle and Lancashire and was attached to [[Merseyside]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] as a schoolboy, but left in 1974 after the [[Goodison Park]] club only offered him an apprenticeship on a part-time basis. An unsuccessful trial later that summer with [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] was followed the very next day by one for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], where he was awarded a contract as an apprentice 19 August 1974.<ref>West Ham handbooks 1986-87 and 1988/90</ref> He appeared in the FA Youth cup final of 1975 and signed as a professional on 29 July 1976. He did not make his first team debut until 18 March 1978 as a substitute against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]. His final appearance was as an 88th-minute substitute on 5 May 1996 against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]].
Martin went on to amass nearly 600 first-team appearances for the Hammers in a successful 19-year professional career at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]], in which he became one of only two players, along with [[Billy Bonds]], to be awarded two [[Testimonial match|testimonials]].<ref name="SCOUSER">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/scouser-martins-heart-with-the-hammers--at-a-stretch-477140.html|title=Scouser Martin's heart with the Hammers – at a stretch|first=Ronald|last=Atkin|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=7 May 2006|accessdate=25 January 2008}}</ref> The first was against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Spurs]] on 21 August 1988 and the second against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 11 November 1995.<ref>Handbooks 1988/89 and 1996/97</ref> It was alongside Bonds in the centre of defence that Martin — nicknamed 'Stretch'<ref name="SCOUSER"/> — enjoyed his most rewarding years, winning the [[FA Cup]] and [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] winners medals in successive seasons, [[1979–80 FA Cup|1980]] and 1981.
Martin also achieved the rare feat of scoring a [[hat-trick]] against three different [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]]s — [[Martin Thomas (footballer born 1959)|Martin Thomas]], who was then injured, and outfield players [[Chris Hedworth]] and [[Peter Beardsley]] — in a [[Football League First Division]] match in April 1986 which the Hammers won 8–1. This was among the most successful seasons the club ever saw, as it [[1985–86 Football League|finished third in the top level]], just four points behind champions [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/3485602.stm|title=The hat-trick Hall of Fame|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|first=Phil|last=McNulty|date=25 February 2004|accessdate=25 January 2008}}</ref> with the player contributing with 40 games and four goals.
Martin remained loyal to West Ham despite their [[1988–89 Football League|relegation from the top flight in 1989]], and helped them gain promotion two years later. The club lasted just one season before again dropping down a level, only to bounce back at the first attempt. Martin, for decades the club's longest serving player, spent three more years with the team in the [[Premier League]] before finally departing at the end of the [[1995–96 FA Premier League|1995–96 season]] after 21 years service, aged 37.<ref>[http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=434&united=Alvin_Martin Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics Alvin Martin]</ref> After leaving West Ham, Martin had a brief spell with [[East End of London|East London]] neighbours [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]], before managing [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] for two years, during which the club was relegated to the [[Football League One|League One]].
==International career== Martin was given his first [[England national football team|England]] [[Cap (sport)|cap]] by [[Ron Greenwood]] against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley]] in May 1981. Injury ruled him out of the [[1982 FIFA World Cup]] finals in Spain, but he was playing some of the finest football of his career when the next manager, [[Bobby Robson]], included him in his squad for the [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986 edition in Mexico]]: he played in the victory over [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planetworldcup.com/CUPS/1986/r2_eng_v_par.html|title=England - Paraguay 3-0 (1-0)|publisher=Planet World Cup|date=18 June 1986|accessdate=22 November 2011}}</ref>, replacing the suspended [[Terry Fenwick]], but was dropped for the next game, the quarter-final defeat by [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]]'s infamous [[Hand of God goal|'Hand of God']]; in total, he made 17 international appearances.
==Career after football== After retiring from management, he joined national radio station [[talksport|talkSPORT]], while also being a regular pundit on [[Sky Sports]] TV football talk shows.
==Personal life== Martin's sons, [[David Martin (footballer, born 1986)|David]] and [[Joe Martin (footballer)|Joe]], are also footballers. The former is a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]], whilst the latter is a [[Defender (association football)|defender]].
