Lazio|Lazio]] | caps10 = 50 | goals10 = 11 | years11 = 2006–2008 | clubs11 = [[Atletico Roma F.C.|Cisco Roma]] | caps11 = 46 | goals11 = 14 | totalcaps = 534 | totalgoals = 126 | nationalyears1 = 1988–1990 | nationalteam1 = [[Italy national under-21 football team|Italy U-21]] | nationalcaps1 = 9 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 1989 | nationalteam2 = [[Italy national football B team|Italy B]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablese/eng-b-intres-det.html |title=England - International Results B-Team - Details |work= |publisher=RSSSF |first=Barrie |last=Courtney |date=22 May 2014 |accessdate=21 April 2017}}</ref>
| nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | manageryears1 = 2011–2013 | managerclubs1 = [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] | manageryears2 = 2013 | managerclubs2 = [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] }} '''Paolo Di Canio''' (born 9 July 1968) is an Italian [[Association football|football]] manager and former professional footballer. During his playing career he made over 500 league appearances and scored over one hundred goals appearing primarily as a [[Forward (association football)#Second striker|deep-lying]] [[Forward (association football)|forward]] but could also play as an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]], or as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]]. A talented yet controversial player, Di Canio was known for his creativity, technical ability, and [[Dribbling#Association football|dribbling]] skills, as well as his temperamental character, tenacity and aggression on the pitch.<ref name="Di Canio, Paolo">{{cite web|url=http://www.tuttocalciatori.net/Di_Canio_Paolo|title=Di Canio, Paolo|website=tuttocalciatori.net|language=Italian|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="Il Pallone Racconta: Paolo Di Canio">{{cite web|url=http://ilpalloneracconta.blogspot.ca/2007/07/paolo-di-canio.html|title=Paolo Di Canio|publisher=Il Pallone Racconta|language=Italian|date=10 July 2014|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="Paolo di Canio">{{cite web|url=http://www.magliarossonera.it/protagonisti/Gioc-Dicanio.html|title=Paolo di Canio|website=magliarossonera.it|language=Italian|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=tuttojuve.com>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuttojuve.com/gli-eroi-bianconeri/gli-eroi-in-bianconero-paolo-di-canio-196426|title=Gli eroi in bianconero: Paolo DI CANIO|publisher=Tutto Juve|language=Italian|author1=Stefano Bedeschi|date=10 July 2014|accessdate=1 February 2016}}</ref>
Di Canio began his career in the Italian [[Serie A]], playing for [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]], [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]] and [[A.C. Milan]], before a brief spell with the Scottish club [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]. He subsequently spent seven years in the English [[Premier League]] with [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] and [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]. He returned to Italy in 2004, playing for Lazio and [[Atletico Roma F.C.|Cisco Roma]] before retiring in 2008. He played for the [[Italy national under-21 football team|Italian under-21s]], making 9 appearances and scoring 2 goals, and was notably a member of the squad that finished in third place at the [[1990 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] under manager [[Cesare Maldini]], but was never capped for the [[Italy national football team|senior team]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.figc.it/nazionali/DettaglioConvocato?codiceConvocato=401&squadra=1|title=Nazionale in Cifre: Convocazioni e presenze in campo - Di Canio, Paolo|website=figc.it|publisher=FIGC|language=Italian|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref>
Among the individual awards he received as a player, Di Canio was named [[SPFA Players' Player of the Year]] in 1997 and West Ham's [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer of the Year|player of the season]] in 2000. However, his career was at times characterised by controversy: he received an eleven-match ban in 1998 for pushing a referee and attracted negative publicity over his self allegiance to [[Italian fascism|fascism]].
In 2011, Di Canio entered football management in England with [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]], guiding them in his first full season as manager to promotion to [[Football League One|League One]]. He was appointed as the [[Sunderland F.C.|Sunderland]] manager at the end of March 2013. His controversial appointment lasted 13 games until he was sacked on 22 September after Sunderland had won only three games under his managership.
==Early life== Di Canio was born in Rome, in the district of Quarticciolo, a working-class area populated mainly by [[A.S. Roma]] fans. However, Di Canio was drawn to their local rivals [[S.S. Lazio]]. As a young boy, he was addicted to cola and similar drinks and called ''Pallocca'', a slang term meaning ''lard-ball''. He was fat, and knock-kneed, and needed to wear orthopedic shoes – "But I never hid. My response was to exercise; to try to become the kind of person I am."<ref name="independent1">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/paolo-di-canio-my-life-speaks-for-me-6273526.html |title=Paolo Di Canio: 'My life speaks for me' – Profiles – People |work=The Independent |date=11 December 2011 |accessdate=2013-04-03 |location=London}}</ref>
==Playing career== He signed for [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] in 1985 and remained there until 1990. Lazio won promotion to Serie A in 1988, having narrowly escaped relegation to [[Serie C1]] the year before. He finally made his first-team debut in October 1988 and went on to play 30 games during the [[1988–89 Serie A|1988–89 season]].<ref name="ffile">{{cite news|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12028/8936979/paolo-di-canio-factfile|title=Paolo Di Canio factfile|publisher=Sky Sports|date=23 September 2013|accessdate=29 January 2014}}</ref> Di Canio scored the winner in the first [[Derby della Capitale|Rome derby]] of the season, a goal which contributed to Lazio's survival in Serie A that season and earning him hero status. In 1990, he was sold to another of Italy's biggest clubs, [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]];<ref name="ffile" /> although he won the [[1992–93 UEFA Cup|UEFA Cup]] with the Turin side in 1993, he struggled to gain playing time during his tenure with the club, due to the presence of other forwards and creative midfielders in the team, such as [[Roberto Baggio]], [[Salvatore Schillaci]], [[Pierluigi Casiraghi]], [[Fabrizio Ravanelli]], [[Gianluca Vialli]], and [[Andreas Möller]].<ref name=tuttojuve.com/> He left Juventus after an "animated exchange" with then manager [[Giovanni Trapattoni]]<ref name="independent1" /><ref name="agr">{{cite web|last=Fisher|first=Stewart|title=Is Di Canio a martyr or does he have a hidden agenda?|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/football/is-di-canio-a-martyr-or-does-he-have-a-hidden-agenda.20274802|publisher=Herald Scotland|accessdate=29 January 2014|date=20 February 2013}}</ref> and spent the [[1993–94 Serie A|1993–94]] season with [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]].<ref name="independent1" /> Two seasons followed at [[A.C. Milan]], where, despite winning the [[1995–96 Serie A|Serie A title in 1996]], he once again struggled to gain playing time due to heavy competition from his teammates, culminating in another row, this time with [[Fabio Capello]].<ref name="independent1" /><ref name="agr" /><ref name=tuttojuve.com/><ref name="Paolo di Canio"/>
===Celtic=== In July 1996 he joined [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] in Scotland, and enjoyed a successful season in [[Glasgow]], scoring 15 goals in 37 appearances<ref>{{cite web|last=Haggerty|first=Anthony|title=Subbuteo team was reason I joined Celtic, admits Paolo Di Canio|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/subbuteo-team-was-reason-i-joined-celtic-1002987|publisher=Daily Record|accessdate=29 January 2014|date=24 December 2008}}</ref> and winning the [[PFA Scotland Players' Player of the Year|SPFA Player of the Year]] award.<ref name="celt1">{{cite web|title=Di Canio’s Celtic years: good, bad and ugly|url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/spfl/di-canio-s-celtic-years-good-bad-and-ugly-1-3106641|publisher=The Scotsman|accessdate=29 January 2014|date=23 September 2013}}</ref> His time in Glasgow was dogged by controversy though; sent-off during a 2–2 draw against [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]] in November 1996<ref>{{cite news|title=Paolo's Italian for loco|url=http://www.thecelticwiki.com/page/1996-11-30%3A+Celtic+2-2+Hearts,+Premier+Division|accessdate=30 January 2014|newspaper=Scotland on Sunday|date=1 December 1996}}</ref> and heavily involved in an acrimonious league match against [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] in March 1997 where he behaved aggressively towards [[Ian Ferguson (footballer born 1967)|Ian Ferguson]] and gestured in the direction of Rangers’ bench as he was led from the field by teammates.<ref name="celt1" /> The Italian was called to the referee’s room after the teams had returned to the dressing room and was shown another yellow card in addition to the one he had received earlier in the game.<ref name="celt1" /> Di Canio then demanded a large wage rise at the end of the season, but this was rebuffed by Celtic.<ref name="celt1" /> He then refused to join the Celtic squad in the Netherlands for their pre-season training during July 1997.<ref name="ffile" />
===Sheffield Wednesday=== On 6 August 1997, Di Canio moved to the English [[Premier League|Premiership]] as he joined [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] in a transfer deal valued at around £4.2 million.<ref name="celt1" /> Whilst in Sheffield, Di Canio was the club's leading goal scorer for the [[1997–98 in English football|1997–98]] season with 14 goals and he became a favourite of the fans.
In September 1998, Di Canio pushed referee [[Paul Alcock]] to the ground after being sent off while playing for Sheffield Wednesday against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] at Hillsborough, which resulted in an extended ban of 11 matches<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/199792.stm|title=Di Canio gets 11-match ban for push on ref |date=23 October 1998|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> and him being fined £10,000.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/fa_carling_premiership/199527.stm|title=Di Canio ban too short, say referees |date=24 October 1998|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
===West Ham United=== [[File:Paolo Di Canio playing at Tony Carr's testimonial, May 2010.jpg|thumb|upright|Di Canio playing in [[Tony Carr]]'s testimonial match in 2010]]
In January 1999, Di Canio signed for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] for £1.5 million. He had not played football since his ban following his push on Paul Alcock. West Ham manager, [[Harry Redknapp]] on signing Di Canio admitted he was taking a chance but said of the player "He can do things with the ball that people can only dream of". Di Canio said of his ban, "I made a mistake and I'm sorry, West Ham have given me a big chance and I'm very happy"<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/1999/jan/28/newsstory.sport | title=West Ham sign £1.5m Di Canio | work=The Guardian | date=28 January 1999 | accessdate=30 January 2014 | author=Brodkin, Jon}}</ref> He scored his first goal for West Ham on 27 February 1999 in his fourth game. Playing against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], Di Canio made the first goal in a 2–0 win, for [[Ian Pearce]] in the 27th minute and scored the second in the 31st minute.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://football.theguardian.com/Observer_Match_Report/0,,-12997,00.html | title=Di Canio strikes right note | work=The Guardian | date=27 February 1999 | accessdate=31 January 2014 | author=Callow, Nick}}</ref> He helped them to achieve a high league position (5th) and qualify for the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]] through the [[UEFA Intertoto Cup|Intertoto Cup]]. He was also the OPTA player of the season [[1998–99 in English football|1998–99]]. He scored the BBC [[BBC Goal of the Season|Goal of the Season]] in March 2000 with a flying volley against [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/westham/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/00/03/26/SOCCER_West_Ham.html&TEAMHD=westham&DIV=prem&TEAM=WEST--HAM&RH=West--Ham&PREV_SEASON=1998 |title=West Ham 2 Wimbledon 1 |work=Sporting Life|location=UK |accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref> which is still considered among the best goals in Premiership history<ref>{{cite web|last=Raynor |first=Dominic |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=688402&cc=5739 |title=Paolo Di Canio: Explosive Italian |publisher=ESPN FC |date=23 October 2009 |accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref> and was named as the Premiership's goal of the decade in a December 2009 [[Sky Sports News]] viewers' poll, scoring 30% of votes.<ref>{{Cite episode | title = Football Tonight| network = [[British Sky Broadcasting|BSkyB]]| series = [[Sky Sports News]]| airdate = 31 December 2009 | minutes = 50 (approx)}}</ref> In this season he was also voted [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer of the Year|Hammer of the Year]] by the club's fans.
In December 2000, late in a game against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] and with both sides vying for the winning goal, Di Canio shunned a goal-scoring opportunity and stopped play, grabbing the ball from a cross inside the [[penalty area|box]], as the Everton goalkeeper [[Paul Gerrard]] was laying injured on the ground after he twisted his knee attempting a clearance on the edge of the box. The [[Goodison Park]] crowd reacted with a standing ovation. FIFA officially lauded Di Canio's gesture, describing it as "a special act of good sportsmanship,"<ref name="Fair Play award">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/1682501.stm |title=Di Canio wins Fair Play award |publisher=BBC News |date=17 December 2001 |accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref> and awarded him next year the [[FIFA Fair Play Award]].
[[Alex Ferguson|Sir Alex Ferguson]] tried to sign him for [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] halfway through the [[2001–02 in English football|2001–02 season]], but his attempts were unsuccessful and Di Canio remained in [[East End of London|East London]] for another season and a half.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/sport/football/manchester_united/s/1023534_ferguson_21_that_got_away |title=Ferguson: 21 that got away – Manchester Evening News |publisher=Menmedia.co.uk |date=8 November 2007 |accessdate=2013-04-03}}</ref>
In 2003, with the Hammers struggling at the bottom of the league, Di Canio had a very public row with manager [[Glenn Roeder]] and was dropped from the first team. However, he returned at the end of the season (after Roeder, stricken by a brain tumour, was replaced by [[Trevor Brooking]]) and scored a winner against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in the penultimate game of the season, a game that boosted West Ham's chances of staying in the Premiership.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/2968013.stm |title=Di Canio grabs West Ham lifeline |publisher=BBC News |date=3 May 2003 |accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref> However, they were relegated on the final day of the season after a 2–2 draw away to [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], where Di Canio scored an 89th-minute equaliser.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/cc_championship/westham/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/03/05/11/SOCCER_Birmingham.html&TEAMHD=westham&DIV=nat1&TEAM=WEST--HAM&RH=West--Ham&PREV_SEASON=2001 |title=Birmingham 2 West Ham 2 |work=Sporting Life|location=UK |accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref> He was released on a free transfer and signed with [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] for the start of [[2003–04 in English football|2003–04]].<ref name="ch1">{{cite news|title=Di Canio joins Charlton|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/charlton_athletic/3142339.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 January 2014|date=11 August 2003}}</ref>
===Charlton Athletic=== In his one season at [[The Valley (London)|The Valley]], Di Canio helped [[Charlton Athletic]] finish the season in 7th position, the club's highest league finish since the 1950s. However, he only scored four league goals for the Addicks, all of which came from the penalty spot (one from a rebound). one of the penalty kicks was an audacious '[[Antonín Panenka#Panenka penalty|Panenka]]' style penalty kick against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Arsenal back on top|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/3206860.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 January 2014|date=26 October 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wright|first=Matt|title=Extra time with Paolo Di Canio|url=http://www.votvonline.com/back-issues/memories-of-paolo/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140130134621/http://www.votvonline.com/back-issues/memories-of-paolo/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=30 January 2014|publisher=Voice of the Valley|accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> Di Canio however continued to be a provider of goals as well, notably in October 2003 when he came on as second-half substitute with Charlton trailing 0–1 away at [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]]. He provided most of the spark for Charlton's much-improved second-half display, and after [[Jonathan Fortune]] had equalised for Charlton, it was from Di Canio's corner kick in the last minute that [[Shaun Bartlett]] headed home the winning goal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Charlton snatch late win|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/3123632.stm|accessdate=30 January 2014|date=4 October 2003|work=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Stone|first=Jimmy|title=CAFC Moments: Di Canio inspires comeback|url=http://www.cafc.co.uk/news/article/20131121-cafc-moments-paolo-di-canio-1188285.aspx|publisher=cafc.co.uk|accessdate=30 January 2014|date=21 November 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201194633/http://www.cafc.co.uk/news/article/20131121-cafc-moments-paolo-di-canio-1188285.aspx|archivedate=1 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Return to Italy=== Even though he had already signed an extension to his Charlton contract, in August 2004 he returned to his home team of [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] taking a massive pay cut in order to return to the economically stretched Roman team.<ref>{{cite news|title=Di Canio apologises to Charlton|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-313592/Di-Canio-apologises-Charlton.html|publisher=Mail Online|accessdate=30 January 2014|location=London|date=11 August 2004}}</ref> Lazio fans were happy to have a Rome-bred Lazio supporter in the team again, something missing since the departure of [[Alessandro Nesta]] in 2002. He scored in the [[Rome derby]], just as he had in 1989, leading the team to a 3–1 victory over [[A.S. Roma]] in January (6 January 2005). However the negative publicity that Di Canio generated for Lazio, including his intimate relationship with club's [[ultras]] and their increased influence thanks to his presence in the team, coupled with problems with some teammates and coaches, exasperated club president and majority shareholder, [[Claudio Lotito]], with whom he already had a difficult relationship. As a result, Di Canio's contract was not renewed in the summer of 2006. During several of his games for Lazio – including during [[goal celebration]]s – Di Canio made a fascist salute to their right-wing fans.<ref>{{cite news |title=I'm a fascist, not a racist, says Paolo di Canio |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1506262/Im-a-fascist-not-a-racist-says-Paolo-di-Canio.html |accessdate=9 October 2018 |work=Telegraph}}</ref> He subsequently signed with [[Atletico Roma F.C.|Cisco Roma]] of [[Serie C2]] on a free transfer. In his first season with Cisco Roma, his team failed promotion to playoffs, despite a runners-up position in the regular season. He subsequently agreed to stay with Cisco for another season, in a second attempt to win promotion to [[Serie C1]] with the Roman side.
On 10 March 2008, Di Canio announced his retirement from football, ending his 23-year playing career before the end of the season due to physical issues. It was his intention to begin coaching lessons at [[Coverciano]] to gain a coaching position.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://it.eurosport.yahoo.com/10032008/44/canio-smette-giocare-addio-cisco-roma-86.html|title=Di Canio Smette di giocare, addio alla Cisco Roma|date=10 March 2008|publisher=[[Eurosport|Yahoo! Eurosport Italia]]}}</ref> In an interview he revealed that his dream would be to manage former club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham]], and applied for the position after the resignation of [[Alan Curbishley]] in September 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/west_ham_utd/7598744.stm|title=Di Canio wants to be Hammers boss|date=4 September 2008|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Di Canio played in [[Tony Carr|Tony Carr's]] testimonial game at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]] on 5 May 2010, which featured a West Ham team against West Ham [[The Academy of Football|Academy]] old boys. He played for both sides during the match. The West Ham team won 5–1.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20100506/paolos-pride_2236884_2044685 |title=Paolo's pride |publisher=Whufc.com |accessdate=12 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100509041725/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20100506/paolos-pride_2236884_2044685 |archivedate=9 May 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In July 2010, in honour of Di Canio, West Ham announced the opening of the Paolo Di Canio Lounge, within the West Stand, at their [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]] ground,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20100716/take-your-seat-in-the-di-canio-lounge_2236884_2093957 |title=Take your seat in the Di Canio Lounge | West Ham United |publisher=Whufc.com |accessdate=17 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100718092059/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20100716/take-your-seat-in-the-di-canio-lounge_2236884_2093957 |archivedate=18 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> which was formally launched by the unveiling of a plaque by Di Canio himself, on 11 September 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20100913/di-canio-lounge-a-hit_2236884_2152448 |title=Di Canio Lounge a hit |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |accessdate=13 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100916014138/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20100913/di-canio-lounge-a-hit_2236884_2152448 |archivedate=16 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Managerial career== ===Swindon Town=== [[File:Paolo Di Canio at Upton Park.jpg|thumb|upright|Di Canio at the [[Boleyn Ground]], [[Upton Park, London|Upton Park]] in 2010]]
On 20 May 2011, Di Canio was appointed manager of [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] on a two-year contract, following the club's relegation to League Two.<ref>{{cite news |title=Swindon Town confirm Paolo Di Canio as new manager |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/13466915 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 May 2011 |accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> Di Canio began his career as a manager with a 3–0 win over [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] on 6 August 2011.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} On 30 August 2011, Di Canio was involved in a pitch-side altercation with Swindon striker [[Leon Clarke]] after their defeat in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swindonadvertiser.co.uk/sport/sportlatest/9226141.Time_called_on_Clarke/ |title=Time called on Clarke |work=Swindon Advertiser |date=1 September 2011 |accessdate=1 September 2011}}</ref> In January 2012, Swindon caused a [[2011–12 FA Cup|FA Cup]] shock by defeating [[Premier League]] club [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] 2–1. Di Canio stated that he believed his players deserved to have their names put on the stadium and dedicated the victory to his father, who died late in 2011.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16372054.stm | title=Swindon 2 – 1 Wigan | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | date=7 January 2012 | accessdate=7 January 2012}}</ref> He was sent to the stands later in the month in a league game against [[Macclesfield Town F.C.|Macclesfield Town]] for vociferously venting his frustration at his side not being awarded a free-kick. Swindon won the match 1–0 and with over half the season gone, his team were fighting for promotion to [[Football League One|League One]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16559842.stm | title=Swindon 1 – 0 Macclesfield | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | date=21 January 2012 | accessdate=21 January 2012}}</ref>
Under Di Canio, Swindon reached the [[2012 Football League Trophy Final]], where they were defeated 2–0 by [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]].{{citation needed|date=March 2017}}
On 21 April 2012, Swindon were promoted to the League One after [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]]'s 1–1 draw with [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]] and [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]]'s 2–0 loss to [[AFC Wimbledon]], despite Di Canio's side having lost 3–1 to [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] on the same day. He dedicated the promotion to his parents, his mother having died shortly after his father in April of that year.<ref name=Robinspromotion>{{cite news|last=Crook|first=Alex|title=Gillingham 3 Swindon Town 1: match report|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/league-two/9218843/Gillingham-3-Swindon-Town-1-match-report.html|accessdate=22 April 2012|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=21 April 2012|location=London}}</ref> One week later, Swindon won the [[Football League Two]] thanks to an emphatic 5–0 victory over [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17795329 |title=Swindon 5–0 Port Vale |publisher=BBC |date=28 April 2012 |accessdate=2013-04-03}}</ref> Swindon finished the season on 93 points.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footballsite.co.uk/Statistics/LeagueTables/Season2011-12/League22011-12.htm |title=Football League 2 table 2011/12 |publisher=footballsite |accessdate=2013-04-03}}</ref>
Although in the 2012–13 season, Swindon were knocked out of the [[FA Cup]] and the [[Football League Trophy]] in their first game against opposition from lower leagues, they did have a solid run in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] in which they won against three teams from higher leagues. They beat [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] 3–0, won against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] 3–4 [[Overtime (sports)|after extra time]], and beat [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] 3–1 before narrowly missing out against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] 3–2 at home.
In January 2013, with Swindon under a transfer embargo and in financial difficulty, Di Canio offered to pay £30,000 of his own money to keep loan players [[John Bostock]], [[Chris Martin (footballer born 1988)|Chris Martin]], and [[Danny Hollands]] at the club.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paolo Di Canio offers own money to keep Swindon players|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20928212|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=20 January 2013}}</ref>
On 18 January 2013, ahead of Swindon's Saturday clash with [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]], Di Canio worked into the night alongside approximately 200 volunteers to clear a snow-covered pitch at the [[County Ground, Swindon|County Ground]], thus allowing the game to go ahead. He showed his appreciation by ordering everyone pizza. Swindon won the match 2–0, which Di Canio publicly deemed a present to the volunteers.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/01/19/paolo-di-canio-shovels-snow-off-swindon-pitch-and-orders-pizza-for-helpers-3358148/ | title=Paolo Di Canio shovels snow off Swindon pitch and orders pizza for helpers | publisher=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] | date=19 January 2013 | accessdate=20 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.swindontownfc.co.uk/news/article/pdcvictoryapresent-608835.aspx | title=PDC – Victory a present | publisher=Swindon Town FC | date=19 January 2013 | accessdate=20 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.swindontownfc.co.uk/news/article/shrewsgameon-607948.aspx | title=Shrewsbury game on | publisher=Swindon Town FC | date=19 January 2013 | accessdate=20 January 2013}}</ref>
In January 2013, the Swindon Town chairman announced that due to financial difficulties, no money would be made available for future signings. Di Canio offered to pay £30,000 of his own money to keep loan players at the club. With the possibility of the club entering administration, a new buyer was found, subject to Football League approval, and without the knowledge of Di Canio, player [[Matt Ritchie]] was sold to [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]. Further attempts to sign players by Di Canio were rejected by the Football League due to the club's financial situation with Di Canio "considering his future" at Swindon due to off-field financial problems. In February, Di Canio offered his resignation but said he would withdraw this if approval for the new owners, by the Football League, was received by 18 February. This did not happen and he resigned as manager of Swindon Town.<ref>{{cite news |title=Paolo Di Canio quits as manager of Swindon Town |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/21499926 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 February 2013 |accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>
===Sunderland=== On 31 March 2013, [[Sunderland A.F.C|Sunderland]] appointed Di Canio as manager on a two-and-a-half-year contract, following the dismissal of [[Martin O'Neill]] the previous day.<ref>{{cite news |title=Paolo Di Canio appointed Sunderland head coach |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/21990117 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 March 2013 |accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> The appointment prompted the immediate resignation of club vice-chairman [[David Miliband]] due to Di Canio's "past political statements".<ref name="miliband">{{cite news|title=David Miliband quits Sunderland FC in Di Canio protest|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/apr/01/david-miliband-resign-sunderland-di-canio|newspaper=The Guardian|date=1 April 2013|accessdate=1 April 2013|location=London|first=Ben|last=Quinn}}</ref> The appointment of Di Canio also sparked opposition from the [[Durham Miners' Association]],<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-tyne-22049080 | work=BBC News | title=Miners' Di Canio protest 'will only end with Sunderland campaign support' | date=6 April 2013}}</ref> which decided to remove one of its mining banners from Sunderland's [[Stadium of Light]], which is built on the former site of the [[Wearmouth Colliery]], as a symbol of its anger over the appointment.<ref>[http://tyneandwear.sky.com/news/article/62109/durham-miners-association-our-issues-with-di-canio-now-resolved Durham Miners' Association: Our Issues With Di Canio At Sunderland Now Resolved - Sky Tyne and Wear<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625103549/http://tyneandwear.sky.com/news/article/62109/durham-miners-association-our-issues-with-di-canio-now-resolved |date=25 June 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/apr/02/paolo-di-canio-sunderland-miners-banner | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Matthew | last=Taylor | title=Sunderland miners demand return of banner after Paolo Di Canio's arrival | date=2 April 2013}}</ref> The background to the opposition was past statements made by Di Canio supporting [[fascism]].<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/miners-join-opposition-to-paolo-di-canios-appointment-at-sunderland-8556525.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title=Miners join opposition to Paolo Di Canio's appointment at Sunderland | date=2 April 2013}}</ref>
Di Canio was tasked with keeping Sunderland in the [[Premier League]], following a run of only three points from a possible 24. His first game as manager of Sunderland resulted in a 2–1 away defeat to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11661/8624046/Premier-League-round-u | work=Sky Sports | title=Premier League round-up – Sky Sports}}</ref> Di Canio's second game in charge was the [[Tyne-Wear derby]] against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] at [[St James' Park]] on 14 April. Sunderland defeated their fierce rivals 3–0, their first away victory in the fixture in over a decade. Each goal sparked wild celebrations from Di Canio and the Sunderland bench.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22056537|title= Newcastle 0 Sunderland 3|date=14 April 2013|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=24 April 2013 }}</ref> Di Canio then got his first win at the Stadium of Light against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/10007646/Sunderland-1-Everton-0-match-report.html|title=Sunderland 1 Everton 0|date=20 April 2013|work=Daily Telegraph |accessdate=24 April 2013|location=London|first=Luke|last=Edwards}}</ref>
Although the team did not win the next three matches, including drawing the final two home games and a heavy 6–1 defeat to [[Aston Villa]], Sunderland secured their Premier League survival when [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] were defeated at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and relegated, trailing then-17th placed Sunderland by four points with only one game to play.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/130514/football-podolski-double-condemns-wigan-relegation-0|title=Podolski double condemns Wigan to relegation|date=14 May 2013|work=Global Post |accessdate=15 May 2013}}</ref>
For the [[2013–14 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2013–14]] season, Di Canio signed fourteen new players and sold experienced players such as [[Simon Mignolet]],<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/10142422/Liverpool-sign-Sunderland-goalkeeper-Simon-Mignolet.html | title=Liverpool sign Sunderland goalkeeper Simon Mignolet | publisher=Daily Telegraph | date=25 June 2013 | accessdate=24 September 2013 | author=Edwards, Luke | location=London}}</ref> [[James McClean]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23631972 | title=Wigan: James McClean took pay cut to join - Owen Coyle | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=24 September 2013}}</ref> and [[Stéphane Sessègnon]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/sunderland/10322293/Sunderland-manager-Paolo-Di-Canio-I-had-to-sell-Stephane-Sessegnon-to-West-Bromwich-Albion.html | title=Sunderland manager Paolo Di Canio: I had to sell Stephane Sessegnon to West Bromwich Albion | publisher=Daily Telegraph | date=20 September 2013 | accessdate=24 September 2013 | author=Edwards, Luke | location=London}}</ref> After five league games, Sunderland had gained only a single point, from an away draw with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23737155 | title=Southampton 1-1 Sunderland | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=24 September 2013}}</ref> Di Canio was dismissed on 22 September 2013, the day after the fifth match of the season, a 3–0 defeat to [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], and only his 13th match in charge.<ref name="Paolo Di Canio: Sunderland reign that lasted only six months">{{cite news |first=Gary |last=Rose |title=Paolo Di Canio: Sunderland reign that lasted only six months |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/24199482 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 September 2013 |accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> Sunderland chief executive officer Margaret Byrne stated that Di Canio had been sacked after senior players had approached her and that his situation became untenable due to his "brutal and vitriolic" criticism of the squad.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24214706 | title=Paolo Di Canio: Sunderland players met CEO before sacking | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=24 September 2013}}</ref> Di Canio denies this.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24356449|title=Paolo Di Canio denies bust-up with players caused Sunderland exit|publisher=[[BBC]]|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=1 October 2013|accessdate=1 October 2013}}</ref>
===Subsequent managerial links=== Di Canio was linked with the [[Celtic FC|Celtic]] job in May 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/may/26/paolo-di-canio-celtic-manager|title=Paolo Di Canio puts himself forward for Celtic manager’s job|date=26 May 2014|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref> and applied for vacant managerial positions at [[Bolton Wanderers]] in October 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/oct/08/paolo-di-canio-neil-lennon-bolton-wanderers|title=Paolo Di Canio and Neil Lennon apply for job as Bolton Wanderers manager|last=Hunter|first=Andy|date=8 October 2014|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref> [[Rotherham United]] in September 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/sep/30/paolo-di-canio-reject-rotherham-united|title=Rotherham reject approach from Paolo Di Canio over manager’s job|date=30 September 2015|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref> and Rotherham again in February 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/feb/08/paolo-di-canio-rotherham-job|title=Paolo Di Canio applies for Rotherham manager job for second time|date=8 February 2016|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref>
==Political views== In 2005, he characterised his political views by declaring that he was "a fascist, not a racist".<ref name="telegraphreport">{{cite news|last=Fenton |first=Ben |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1506262/Im-a-fascist-not-a-racist-says-Paolo-di-Canio.html |title=I'm a fascist, not a racist, says Paolo di Canio |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=24 December 2005 |accessdate=1 May 2010 |location=London}}</ref>
His use of the [[Roman salute]] toward [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] supporters, a gesture adopted by [[Italian Fascism|Italian fascists]] in the 20th century, has created controversy. Documented uses of the salute include in matches against arch-rivals [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] and [[A.S. Livorno Calcio|Livorno]], a club inclined to left-wing politics.<ref name="Kassimeris">{{cite book|last=Kassimeris|first=Christos |title=European football in black and white: tackling racism in football |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2008|page=70|isbn=9780739119600}}</ref> Di Canio received a one-match ban after the second event and was fined €7,000.<ref name="Bar-On">{{cite book|last=Bar-On|first=Tamir |title=Where have all the fascists gone?|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|year=2007|page=1|isbn=9780754671541}}</ref> He was later quoted as saying, "I will always salute as I did because it gives me a sense of belonging to my people ... I saluted my people with what for me is a sign of belonging to a group that holds true values, values of civility against the standardisation that this society imposes upon us."<ref name="Nursey">{{cite news|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-139900733 |title=Football: ll Di Canio new salute row |last=Nursey |first=James |date=19 December 2005 |work=Daily Mirror |location=London (UK), |accessdate=28 February 2013 }}</ref> His salute has been featured on unofficial merchandise sold outside [[Stadio Olimpico]] after the ban.<ref name="Kassimeris" />
He has also expressed admiration for the fascist dictator [[Benito Mussolini]]. In his autobiography, he praised Mussolini as "basically a very principled, ethical individual" who was "deeply misunderstood".<ref name="independentarticle">{{cite news|title=Paolo Di Canio: 'My life speaks for me'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/paolo-di-canio-my-life-speaks-for-me-6273526.html|work=The Independent|date=11 December 2013|accessdate=1 April 2013|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4158591.stm|title=Footballer's 'fascist salute' row |last=Duff|first=Mark|date=9 January 2005|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=16 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1506262/Im-a-fascist-not-a-racist-says-Paolo-di-Canio.html|title=I'm a fascist, not a racist, says Paolo di Canio|last=Fenton|first=Ben |date=24 December 2005|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=16 February 2010|location=London}}</ref>
In 2010, Di Canio attended the funeral of senior fascist Paolo Signorelli, where mourners were photographed making mass fascist salutes towards Signorelli's coffin.<ref>[http://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/scotsol/homepage/news/4878249/Di-Canio-is-ugly-side-of-beautiful-game.html Di Canio is ugly side of beautiful game | The Sun |Scottish News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.hopenothate.org.uk/news/article/2644/paolo-di-canio-at-bomb-fascists-funeral HOPE not hate news: Paolo Di Canio at bomb fascist’s funeral<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130406032230/http://www.hopenothate.org.uk/news/article/2644/paolo-di-canio-at-bomb-fascists-funeral |date=6 April 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2303650/Paolo-Di-Canio-attends-funeral-fascist-bomber.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | title=Di Canio says he's not one... but why was he at the funeral of an Italian fascist bomber?}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/4870918/Paolo-Di-Canio-at-bomb-fascists-funeral.html | location=London | work=The Sun | first=Robin | last=Perrie | title=Exclusive: Paolo Di Canio at bomb fascist’s funeral – The Sun –News}}</ref> Signorelli had been convicted of involvement in the [[Bologna massacre]], a neo-fascist terrorist attack which killed 85 people and wounded more than 200.
Di Canio's political ideology has been a source of controversy in the course of his managerial career. When Di Canio was appointed as the manager of [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] in 2011, the trade union [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]] terminated its sponsorship agreement with the club, worth around £4,000 per season, due to Di Canio's fascist views.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1389305/Sponsors-cut-ties-Swindon-Paolo-di-Canios-fascist-views.html|title=Sponsors cut ties with Swindon over Paolo di Canio's fascist views|last=Mokbel|first=Sami |date=21 May 2011|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=21 May 2011|location=London}}</ref>
He was appointed as manager of [[Sunderland F.C.|Sunderland]] on 31 March 2013. The club's vice-chairman [[David Miliband]], a [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] politician and former [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|foreign secretary]], subsequently stepped down. Miliband stated that he had taken the decision to resign "in the light of the new manager's past political statements".<ref name="miliband" />
In a profile piece in 2011, an unnamed source asserted that Di Canio was not "an ideological fascist", attributing his behaviour to "his psychological history, particularly his former compulsive tendencies and pronounced mood swings". In the same article, Di Canio said that he was not politically active: "I don't vote, I haven't voted for 14 years. Italian politicians — all of them — think only about themselves, and making money."<ref name="independentarticle" />
==Personal life== Di Canio has several tattoos, including on his right [[biceps]] the [[Latin language|Latin]] word "''DUX''", meaning "''leader''" or, in Italian, [[duce|Il Duce]]—a nickname for [[Benito Mussolini]].<ref name=Tatts>{{cite news|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/sports/political%2Bfootball%2Bpaolo%2Bdi%2Bcanio/1643547.html |title=Political Football: Paolo Di Canio|date=26 April 2008|publisher=Channel 4 |accessdate=19 May 2011}}</ref> [[Sky Italia|Sky Sport Italia]] was forced to apologize after Di Canio appeared as a pundit in September 2016 in a short-sleeved shirt, thus revealing the tattoo to television viewers; he was later suspended by the station.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/sep/14/sky-sport-italia-suspends-paolo-di-canio-after-showing-dux-tattoo|title=Sky Sport Italia suspends Paolo Di Canio after showing ‘dux’ tattoo|last=Dobson|first=Mark|date=14 September 2016|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref> His back is covered with a tattoo of fascist imagery, including an eagle, [[fasces]] and a portrait of Mussolini.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2305295/Paolo-Di-Canio-tattoo-Just-days-renouncing-fascism-Mussolini-design-revealed.html|title=Paolo Di Canio Tattoo: Just days after renouncing fascisme, Mussolini Design Revealed|date=7 April 2013|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=2013-06-11|location=London}}</ref> He also has a [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] tattoo on his left upper arm<ref name=Tatts2>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1388312/Paolo-Di-Canio-wants-West-Ham-job.html|title=I'm on my way to England! Di Canio throws his hat into the ring for West Ham hotseat|date=18 May 2011|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=19 May 2011|location=London}}</ref> and a tattoo of his father on his chest.<ref>{{cite web|last=Warren |first=Andy |url=http://www.swindonadvertiser.co.uk/sport/sportlatest/9679359.The_man_with_the_Swindon_tattoo/ |title=The man with the Swindon tattoo (From Swindon Advertiser) |publisher=Swindonadvertiser.co.uk |date=1 May 2012 |accessdate=2013-04-03}}</ref>
Di Canio has spoken also of the growing influence in his life of [[Samurai]] culture, and of the Japanese spiritual mentality from reading [[Yukio Mishima|Mishima]], and the teachings in the traditions of [[Hagakure]] and [[Bushido]].<ref name="independent1"/>

==Honours== ===As a player=== '''Lazio'''<ref name="Paolo di Canio"/> *[[Serie B]] promotion: [[1987–88 Serie B|1987–88]] *[[Supercoppa Italiana]] runner-up: [[2004 Supercoppa Italiana|2004]]
'''Juventus'''<ref name="Il Pallone Racconta: Paolo Di Canio"/> *[[Serie A]] runner-up: [[Serie A 1991–92|1991–92]] *[[Coppa Italia]] runner-up: [[1991–92 Coppa Italia|1991–92]] *[[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]] winner: [[1993 UEFA Cup Final|1992–93]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Alan Devonshire | image = Devonshire, Alan.jpg | image_size = 220 | caption = Devonshire in 2011 | fullname = Alan Ernest Devonshire<ref name="PFA 168">{{Cite book | editor-first = Barry J. | editor-last = Hugman | title = The PFA Premier & Football League Players' Records 1946–2005 | publisher = Queen Anne Press | year = 2005 | isbn = 1-85291-665-6 | page = 168 }}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|4|13|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Park Royal]], England | height = | position = [[Midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Maidenhead United F.C.|Maidenhead United]] (manager) | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | years1 = {{0|0000}}–1976 | years2 = 1976–1990 | years3 = 1990–1992 | clubs1 = [[Southall F.C.|Southall]] | clubs2 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | clubs3 = [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] | caps1 = | caps2 = 358 | caps3 = 25 | goals1 = | goals2 = 29 | goals3 = 1 | totalcaps = 383+ | totalgoals = 30+ | nationalyears1 = 1980–1983 | nationalteam1 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps1 = 8 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | manageryears1 = 1995 | managerclubs1 = Osterley | manageryears2 = 1995–1996 | managerclubs2 = [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford Women]] | manageryears3 = 1996–2003 | managerclubs3 = [[Maidenhead United F.C.|Maidenhead United]] | manageryears4 = 2003–2011 | managerclubs4 = [[Hampton & Richmond Borough F.C.|Hampton & Richmond Borough]] | manageryears5 = 2011–2015 | managerclubs5 = [[Braintree Town F.C.|Braintree Town]] | manageryears6 = 2015– | managerclubs6 = [[Maidenhead United F.C.|Maidenhead United]] }} '''Alan Ernest Devonshire''' (born 13 April 1956) is an English former professional [[Association football|footballer]] who is the current manager of [[Maidenhead United F.C.|Maidenhead United]]. He was a wide [[midfielder]] who played for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], with whom he won the [[FA Cup]] in 1980, and [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], where he finished his career in 1992. Devonshire won eight caps for [[England national football team|England]] between 1980 and 1983. He subsequently became a manager with Maidenhead United, [[Hampton & Richmond Borough F.C.|Hampton & Richmond Borough]] and [[Braintree Town F.C.|Braintree Town]].
==Playing career==
===Early career=== Born in [[Park Royal]], then a part of [[Middlesex]], Devonshire had been a schoolboy footballer but had been turned away by [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] at age 14 for being too small.{{sfn|Hogg|1995|p=54}} He returned to [[Selhurst Park]] two years later and played a couple of youth team games but was again released by the club, this time by former West Ham player and Palace manager, [[Malcolm Allison]]. Devonshire started playing for non-league [[Southall F.C.|Southall]] and in doing so came to the attention of [[Football League|league]] clubs such as [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], and [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]].{{sfn|Hogg|1995|p=54}} By day he worked as a fork-lift truck driver at the [[Hoover Building|Hoover Factory]] in [[Perivale]], Middlesex. During this time he was spotted playing for Southall by West Ham United [[Scout (sport)|scout]]s, [[Eddie Baily]] and Charlie Faulkner who recommended him to West Ham manager, [[Ron Greenwood]]. Devonshire signed for West Ham United in 1976 for a fee of £5,000, a transfer which has led to him being referred to as "West Ham's best ever buy".{{sfn|Hogg|1995|p=54}}
===West Ham United=== Devonshire made his debut for West Ham on 27 October 1976 in a League Cup tie against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], in which West Ham lost 2–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3002&united=27_Oct_1976 |title=Game played on 27 Oct 1976 |publisher=Westhamstats.info |date=27 October 1976 |accessdate=21 January 2011}}</ref> He made his League debut three days later on 30 October 1976 against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], where he played in a 3–0 defeat. He soon became a fans' favourite, who referred to him by his nickname "Dev". His workman-like attitude was one to which the fans could relate. He also enhanced his rapport with supporters by travelling to home game on the [[London Underground]] from his West London home.{{sfn|Hogg|1995|p=54}}
He played 29 games in all competitions, without scoring, in his first season, the [[1976-77 in English football|1976–77]] season. It was a poor season for West Ham who finished only two points above a relegation place in 17th place in the [[Football League First Division|First Division]].<ref name="WHU7677">{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1977&united=1st_Division_1976-77 | title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics 1st Division 1976–77 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=20 December 2013}}</ref> The following season, the [[1977-78 in English football|1977–78]] season saw Devonshire's first goals for the club, in a 3–3 at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]] on 12 November 1977.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3051&united=12_Nov_1977 | title=Game played 12 November 1977 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=20 December 2013}}</ref> It also saw him play 38 games in all competitions, scoring three goals. Unfortunately for West Ham his efforts could not prevent them from relegation to the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] after they finished in 20th place.<ref name="WHU197778">{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1978&united=1st_Division_1977-78 | title= Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics 1st Division | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=22 December 2013}}</ref> The [[1978-79 in English football|1978–79]] season saw West Ham rebuilding their side following relegation. Devonshire was a regular member of the side which finished 5th in the Second Division. He had played 41 of a possible 42 league games that season and was voted [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer of the Season|Hammer of the Season]].<ref name="Alan Devonshire WHU stats"/><ref name="WHU7879">{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1979&united=2nd_Division_1978-79 | title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics 1978–79 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=23 December 2013}}</ref> West Ham failed to gain promotion again in the [[1979-80 in English football|1979–80 season]]. They did however reach the [[1980 FA Cup Final]] where Devonshire collected an [[FA Cup]] winner's medal as West Ham beat favourites, holders and Cup Winners Cup finalists [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] 1–0 at [[Wembley Stadium|Wembley]] with a single goal from [[Trevor Brooking]] from a cross by Devonshire. He had also scored a goal in a semi-final replay at [[Elland Road]] in a 2–1 win against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].<ref name="efcsemi">{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3176&united=16_Apr_1980 | title=Game played on 16 Apr 1980 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=23 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="1980shock">{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/8435400.stm | title=When the Hammers shocked Arsenal | publisher=BBC Sport | date=1 January 2010 | accessdate=23 December 2013}}</ref> {{sfn|Hogg|1995|p=54}}
In the [[1980-81 in English football|1980–81 season]] Devonshire's career flourished. His partnership with Trevor Brooking formed the cornerstone of West Ham's push for promotion back to the First Division. He also played in [[West Ham United F.C. in European football|European football]] for the first time and was a member of the side which reached to [[1981 Football League Cup Final|1981 League Cup Final]]. He collected a Second Division title medal as they won promotion, losing only four games.{{sfn|Hogg|1995|p=55}} Devonshire continued to be a regular member of the West Ham side in the First Division until a game on 7 January 1984. Playing against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in the FA Cup, he snapped three [[ligament]]s in his right knee. He tried to make a comeback in March 1985 in two cup games against [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]] but again broke down. It was 19 months from his first injury to his full return, in a game against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] on 17 August 1985.<ref name="Alan Devonshire WHU stats">{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=186&united=Alan_Devonshire | title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics Alan Devonshire | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=22 December 2013}}</ref> His long spell out injured had resulted in him losing some of his pace but still maintaining his ability to pass the ball well. He made the [[Assist (football)|final pass]] for many of the goals scored by teammates, [[Tony Cottee]] and [[Frank McAvennie]] in the [[1985-86 in English football|1985–86 season]] as West Ham finished third in the First Division.<ref name="WHU8586">{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1986&united=1st_Division_1985-86 | title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics – 1st Division 1985–86 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=26 December 2013}}</ref>
Injury struck Devonshire again in the first game of the [[1987-88 in English football|1987–88]] season. Just 15 minutes in a game against Queens Park Rangers, he snapped his [[Achilles tendon]]. This forced him out of the game for over a year and by the time of his return the West Ham team were in decline. The [[1988-89 in English football|1988–89]] season saw him play only 20 league game without scoring as West Ham were relegated back to the Second Division.<ref name="WHU8889">{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1989&united=1st_Division_1988-89 | title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics – 1st Division 1988–89 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=26 December 2013}}</ref> For the [[1989-90 in English football|1989–90]] season manager [[John Lyall]] was replaced by [[Lou Macari]] who undertook the rebuilding of the West Ham side. Devonshire was rarely used making only seven league appearances that season. Macari was replaced in the same season by [[Billy Bonds]] who granted Devonshire a free transfer in May 1990.{{sfn|Hogg|1995|p=55}} His last appearance for West Ham came on 14 February 1990 when he was a substitute for [[Gary Strodder]] in a 6–0 away defeat to [[Oldham Athletic F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] in a League Cup semi-final. His performance, and that of other experienced West Ham players, [[Liam Brady]], [[Phil Parkes (footballer, born 1950)|Phil Parkes]], [[Alvin Martin]] and [[Julian Dicks]], was described as "embarrassingly helpless" in a game known as the "St. Valentine's Day massacre".{{sfn|Blows|2000|p=174}} <ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2010/jan/15/joy-of-six-league-cup-semi-finals | title=The Joy of Six: League Cup semi-finals | work=The Guardian | date=15 January 2010 | accessdate=26 December 2013 | author=Smyth, Rob}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3684&united=14_Feb_1990 | title=Game played on 14 Feb 1990 | publisher=www.westhamstats.info | accessdate=26 December 2013}}</ref> Devonshire had played 448 competitive games over 14 years, scoring 32 goals.<ref name="Alan Devonshire WHU stats"/>
===Watford=== In 1990 Devonshire signed for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], where he played for two years before dropping out of league football in 1992.<ref name="watfordfcarchive">{{Cite web |url=http://www.watfordfcarchive.com/downloads/players/+Cullip-Dickson.pdf |title=Watford Football Club archive 1881–2017 » Players – Cullip to Dickson |page=36 |access-date=22 June 2018}}</ref> He went on to serve non-league club Chippenham Sports as a player-coach.<ref name="watfordfcarchive" />
==International career== Devonshire was selected to play for [[England national football team|England]] by his former manager at West Ham, Ron Greenwood. He made his debut on 20 May 1980 in a 1–1 draw against [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]].<ref name="englandint">{{cite web|url=http://www.englandfc.com/Profiles/php/PlayerProfileByName.php?id=309 |title=Alan Devonshire England |publisher=www.englandfc.com |accessdate=26 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104212811/http://www.englandfc.com/Profiles/php/PlayerProfileByName.php?id=309 |archivedate=4 January 2014 }}</ref> Greenwood selected him again on 31 May 1980 in a friendly game against [[Australia national association football team|Australia]], which England won 2–1.<ref>{{cite web | title=England | url=http://www.sporting-heroes.net/football/england/alan-devonshire-4684/biography-1980-83_a11309/ | publisher=www.sportingheroes.net | accessdate=26 December 2013 | author=Rudd, Matthew}}</ref> Unfortunately for Devonshire his position and style of play were also those of [[Glenn Hoddle]] who was preferred as an international selection. He would have to wait two years for his next cap, on 25 May 1982 in a 2–0 win against [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]]. Another game followed on 2 June 1982, a 1–1 draw against [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]]. Both of these games were warm-up games before the [[1982 FIFA World Cup|1982 World Cup]]. Devonshire was omitted from the final squad for the tournament. New England manager, [[Bobby Robson]] attempting to rebuild an aging England team, selected Devonshire in October 1982. The game, against [[West Germany national football team|West Germany]] finished 2–1 to the Germans in a bad defeat for England.<ref name=englandint/> His final two appearances, against [[Greece national football team|Greece]] and [[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]] came towards the end of 1983 and were Devonshire's only appearances in competitive international games, the games being qualifiers for the [[1984 UEFA European Football Championship]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/luxembourg-v-england-16-november-1983-238156/ | title=Luxemburg v England 16 November 1983 | publisher=www.11v11.com | accessdate=26 December 2013}}</ref>
==Management career== Devonshire began his management career as manager of non-league club Osterley and Brentford Women.<ref name="watfordfcarchive" /> He then became the manager of [[Hampton & Richmond Borough F.C.|Hampton & Richmond Borough]] in the [[Conference South]]. He was previously manager of [[Maidenhead United F.C.|Maidenhead United]].
As manager of Hampton & Richmond, he took the club from [[Isthmian League Division One South]] to the play-off-final of the Conference South. In his first season, he guided them to fifth place in the Isthmian Division One South which due to re-organization of the leagues was enough to see the club promoted to the [[Isthmian League Premier Division]]. He then guided the club to a sixth-placed finish in their debut season at that level missing out on the play-offs on goal difference on the final day of the season. The 2005–06 season would see Devonshire take the team into the play-offs. Having won a dramatic play-off semi-final on penalties away to [[Heybridge Swifts F.C.|Heybridge Swifts]] the team then faced [[Fisher Athletic F.C.|Fisher Athletic]] away who beat Hampton 3–0. Devonshire finally managed to get Hampton & Richmond Borough promoted the following season in style by bringing the Isthmian Premier Division title to the Beveree. In their debut season in the Conference South he has managed to guide his team to third place in the league and into the play-offs for the [[Conference National]].
On 23 May 2011, Devonshire was appointed the manager of newly promoted Conference National club [[Braintree Town F.C.|Braintree Town]].<ref name="Devonshire looking forward to Iron challenge">{{cite news | url = http://www.braintreeandwithamtimes.co.uk/sport/9043708.Devonshire_looking_forward_to_Iron_challenge/ | title = Devonshire looking forward to Iron challenge | publisher = ''Braintree & Witham Times'' | first = Jonathan | last = Waldon | date = 23 May 2011 | accessdate = 23 May 2011 }}</ref> Having declined the offer of a new contract, Devonshire left the club on 17 April 2015.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.braintreeandwithamtimes.co.uk/sport/localsport/12896091._/ | title=Alan Devonshire departs as Braintree Town manager | work=www.braintreeandwithamtimes.co.uk | date=17 April 2015 | accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref> He was appointed manager of one of his former clubs, [[National League South]] side Maidenhead United, on 5 May 2015.<ref>{{cite news|first=Graeme |last=Copas |url=http://www.maidenhead-advertiser.co.uk/Sport/Football/Maidenhead-Utd-FC/Alan-Devonshire-has-been-appointed-Maidenhead-United-manager-05052015.htm/ |title=Alan Devonshire has been appointed Maidenhead United manager |newspaper=Maidenhead Advertiser |date=5 May 2015 |accessdate=6 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150606122121/http://www.maidenhead-advertiser.co.uk/Sport/Football/Maidenhead-Utd-FC/Alan-Devonshire-has-been-appointed-Maidenhead-United-manager-05052015.htm |archivedate=6 June 2015 }}</ref>

==Personal life== Devonshire's father, [[Les Devonshire|Les]], was a professional footballer with clubs including [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City]] and [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].
He has a race horse named after him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislocallondon.co.uk/sport/2316261.a_horse_to_make_hammers_happy/ |title=A horse to make Hammers happy (From This Is Local London) |publisher=Thisislocallondon.co.uk |date=5 June 2008 |accessdate=21 January 2011}}</ref>
